Monday's announcement trims by one the small number of countries worldwide with which the United States does not have diplomatic relations. Last week, the State Department said it was ready to pursue normal relations with Albania after a break of more than 50 years.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.TEXT: Golden tans have been big business in this desert oasis for decades. Now it's official. To obtain an official Palm Springs tan, sun worshipers will have to baste themselves with the only line of browning balms bearing city approval. Starting in May, bottles of Palm Springs Desertan lotions will have a small tag with the sun setting over a cluster of palm trees certifying it is an ``officially licensed product of the City of Palm Springs.'' Competing for precious tourist dollars, city leaders value the name recognition benefits of the endorsement deal. ``Licensing is a double plus for the city,'' said Councilman Tuck Broich. ``It gets our name out in a lot of new ways and it generates revenue for the city.'' Proposals for Palm Springs gourmet potato chips, towels, clothing, dishware, sheets and a board game called Palm Springsopoly also are in the works, officials said. But celebrity Mayor Sonny Bono does not plant to plug the Desertan products marketed by Greg Ackerman. ``That's not part of the deal,'' Bono said. ``I've got to draw the line somewhere or pretty soon someone will want me to promote something else and then something else and it would just get out of hand.'' Councilman Earl Neel said the licensing deal may generate only about $2,000 a year, but hoped it could launch a trend of endorsements. Broich acknowledged no one on the council had given Desertan products the poolside test, saying ``I don't have time to go out and lie in the sun.'' But he said the council insisted that Ackerman carry insurance in case lawsuits were filed against the city by sunbathers unhappy with his products. ``We're not totally crazy,'' Broich said.

A new species of termite _ a tiny black-winged pest that swarms in summer and hunts for dead wood _ has been discovered in this Gulf Coast town. Rudy Scheffrahn, a termite expert with the University of Florida's Institute of Food and Agricultural Sciences, calls it ``the biggest termite find in the last 40 years.'' The recently found termite, which is less than an eighth-inch long, is called amitermes floridensis. The relatively harmless creature is half the size and one-fifth the weight of its more robust Florida cousins. And it's content to gnaw on dead tree branches rather than 2-by-4s. Scheffrahn doesn't know yet whether amitermes floridensis is a native St. Petersburg resident or was brought from out of state. Some 16 termite species are in Florida, and 44 throughout the United States. ``Anytime you find a new species, it's exciting, because we've come to believe there isn't anything new in the world,'' Scheffrahn said.

DOC.HEAD: Savings Rate Increases for Americans
DOC.TEXT: Americans' saving rate rose to 5.8 percent of their disposable income in March as consumer spending failed to match the increase in personal incomes, the government reported Monday. But analysts cited rising prices for the subdued spending and not consumer intent to increase their savings rate. ``For each of the months of the first quarter, we had very strong inflation that cut into purchasing power,'' said David Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association. ``It's likely to see that reverse itself in the second quarter.'' Stephen S. Roach, senior economist at Morgan Stanley & Co. in New York, agreed, saying inflation remains the ``single biggest threat to the consumer support of this expansion'' although he too expects it to moderate in the current quarter. ``That will enable consumers to continue to expand their capacity to spend,'' he said. Consumer spending is watched closely as a barometer of economic health because it accounts for about two-thirds of the nation's economic activity. It has been in the forefront of the economic expansion now in its eighth year following the 1981-82 recession. Consumer spending totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $3.66 trillion, slowing to a 0.4 percent gain after a 0.6 percent advance in February, the Commerce Department reported. It was the lowest since a 0.3 percent increase in October. The department said personal incomes grew 0.8 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of $4.67 trillion on top of 0.8 percent jumps in both January and February. The increases originally were reported to have been 0.7 percent in January and 0.9 percent in February. ``The March and February increases in personal income were boosted by increases in subsidy payments to farm proprietors,'' the department said. ``Excluding these payments, personal income increases $24.6 billion, or 0.5 percent, in March and $28.9 billion, or 0.6 percent, in February.'' Americans' income after taxes rose 0.8 percent in March, the largest increase since an 0.9 percent gain in December, the department said. The key component of the income category, wages and salaries, rose $14.1 billion at an annual rate after a $22 billion gain in February. The increase in personal consumption, which includes everything except interest payments on debt, totaled $13.8 billion, down from $21.3 billion in February. Purchases of durable goods _ big-ticket items expected to last more than three years _ fell $6.8 billion. Purchases of non-durable goods also fell, down $2.5 billion, while services gained $23.1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Cancer-Stricken Sammy Davis Jr. Resting at Home
DOC.TEXT: Entertainer Sammy Davis Jr., in failing health in a battle with throat cancer, was resting at home seven weeks after his release from a hospital, his publicist said Monday. ``There has been no change. He's resting,'' Davis spokeswoman Susan Reynolds said when asked for an update on the song-and-dance man's condition. Davis, 64, was released from Cedars-Sinai Medical Center on March 13 to recuperate at home from chemotherapy. He was first diagnosed for carcinoma of the throat last September. He was admitted to Cedars-Sinai in mid-January for treatment of a gum infection and doctors later found that he had a recurrence of throat cancer. No further chemotherapy was planned.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Welcomes Release of Hostage Frank Reed
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; editing thruout; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today welcomed the release of hostage Frank H. Reed, thanked both Syria and Iran but said again, ``We cannot rest ... until all hostages are free.'' He called the news of Reed's release by kidnappers in Lebanon cause for joy, but expressed concern about the plight of six other Americans and 10 other Westerners who remain hostage. ``This is a joyous day for Mr. Reed, his family, his friends and all Americans,'' Bush said in a written statement. ``With Mr. Reed's release, we have six innocent Americans that are still being held hostage in Lebanon,'' as well as the other foreign hostages, he said. ``Their predicament weighs on our mind and tempers the joy we feel today.'' As he did eight days ago when hostage Robert Polhill was let go, Bush thanked Syria and Iran _ two states the United States has accused in the past of sponsoring terrorism. ``Once again, we wish to express our gratitude to all those who through their efforts helped in Mr. Reed's release,'' said Bush. ``In particular we would like to thank the government of Syria for facilitating this release. We would also like to thank the government of Iran for using its influence to help bring about this humanitarian step.'' Bush was meeting later this afternoon at the White House with Polhill, the rail-thin educator still recuperating from his 39 months in captivity. Bush said, ``We cannot rest, however, until all hostages are free. We urge all parties who either hold hostages or have any influence over the hostage takers to work for the expeditious and unconditional release of the remaining hostages.'' Earlier, the Bush administration today dispatched a special recovery team to West Germany to greet Reed. There was no immediate word from State Department officials on Reed's condition after 43 months in captivity. In Malden, Mass., Reed's wife Fahima said she was ready to travel overseas ``as soon as I see the picture of my husband.'' Reed was the second American hostage released in a little more than a week. Robert Polhill was freed by his captors on April 22, and returned to the United States late last week. Reed's release left six Americans still hostage in the Middle East, including Terry Anderson of The Associated Press. He is the longest held, and has been captive for more than five years. Earlier in the day, as optimism rose over the prospect of a release, the White House said it was ``very hopeful'' that a hostage would be freed. But it it reiterated its policy of no deals with the kidnappers. Reed, a hostage in Lebanon for 43 months, was liberated by Islamic militants and turned over to Syria, which played a middle-man role for the Bush administration, the State Department said in the first word of his release. ``We've got confirmation that he's been released and is in Syrian hands in Lebanon,'' said Kim Hoggard, a State Department spokeswoman, after receiving word from the U.S. Embassy in Damascus. The State Department had kept an open telephone line to the Embassy in the expectation that Reed, former director of the Lebanon International School in Beirut, would be liberated. Reed was seized in the Lebanese capital Sept. 9, 1986. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater aid the State Department hostage reception team was being dispatched to Wiesbaden, West Germany, where hostage Reed will be taken for treatment. Amid reports in Iran that the planned release follows ``extensive talks'' between the Iranian government and the hostage-holders, Fitzwater said, ``We've had a lot of third party intermediary kinds of messages back and forth with Iran. But there's nothing we can point to in terms of any specific reasons for this release.'' ``It is virtually impossible for us to know exactly the contributions of Iran in these kinds of matter,'' the spokesman added. He reiterated that there will be ``no deals'' with the kidnappers. ``We know very little'' about the Islamic Revolutionary Dawn, the group saying it would release Reed, Fitzwater said. At the State Department, Ms. Tutwiler said the Islamic Dawn group ``was unknown to us before yesterday's announcement.'' Ms. Tutwiler said it is probably associated with the Islamic Jihad, but added: ``We know next to nothing about this group.'' ``No one knows precisely what motivates the hostage-takers in any of their activities, either in the taking of hostages or holding them or releasing them,'' Fitzwater said. ``There is considerable speculation that Iran and Syria and others in that part of the world would like to have better relations with the United States. The president has said goodwill begets goodwill. And we are hopeful that indeed that is the case, that they do want better relations.'' Reed, 57, was director of the Lebanese International School when he was seized from his chauffeur-driven car near the Beirut airport on Sept. 12, 1986, as he was driven to play golf. The Massachusetts native had lived in Beirut for eight years. He is a convert to Islam married to a Syrian Moslem.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Hostage's Wife Gets Word From State Dept.: Husband Is Free
With PM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10-11th grafs, `She said...', with 2 grafs to add background on Mrs. Reed. Picks up 12th graf, `I hope...'. ' SUBS 17th graf, `Reed's daughter..., to add that Ms. Langston is one of two daughters from previous marriage.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos BX2, BX3
DOC.TEXT: An overjoyed Fifi Reed got the word today from the State Department that her husband, Frank, had been turned over to Syrian authorities after nearly 40 months in captivity in Lebanon. The call came shortly before 2 p.m. at her home in this Boston suburb, where relatives and a crowd of reporters were gathered awaiting word. Mrs. Reed, 39, said she would wait for another call from the State Department on what plans she should make to leave for a rendezvous with her husband. ``They have words that Frank is with the Syrians now,'' she said. ``He's been handed over to the Syrians.'' The family first got word Sunday morning that a statement had claimed that Reed, 57, would be released in 48 hours. While the Reed family waited to see if that statement would come true, Reed's 91-year-old mother, Leota Sprague, said she had never lost faith that her son would be free one day. ``I haven't been able to cry for four years,'' Mrs. Sprague said. ``Now I can smile and say thank God.'' ``We have to keep faith,'' she said, but added a word of caution: ``It's an awful thrust in your side when you find out these things aren't true.'' When she first heard of the kidnappers' communique, Mrs. Reed jumped up and down and hugged friends and relatives. ``Oh my God, no!'' she shouted. ``I'm going to die! I don't believe this!'' Mrs. Reed was born in Syria; her husband converted to Islam to marry her. She said her sister in Damascus would try to meet him in the Middle East, and she planned to travel to Wiesbaden, West Germany, to meet him there. Shown a photograph the kidnappers sent along with the statement Sunday, Mrs. Reed said her husband looked much thinner and much older. ``I hope he'll be OK,'' she said, her voice wavering. ``But how can you be completely OK when you've been chained and blindfolded so long. He'll need lots of love and affection. He used to say, `Let's have some tender loving care.' He'll need that when he gets out.'' Mrs. Reed said she had a premonition after hostage Robert Polhill's release on April 22 that her husband would be freed next. ``But I pushed that to the back of my mind,'' she said. ``I don't want to be too optimistic. I'd rather be surprised.'' Last year, their 9-year-old son, Tarek, wrote President Bush asking for help in freeing his father. The boy's third-grade classmates wrote similar letters, and in March he received a response from the president, advising him to ``stay strong.'' When Bush was asked about Sunday's report, he declined to comment except to say, ``If that proves to be true, that's wonderful.'' Marilyn Langston, 33, one of Reed's two daughters from a previous marriage, expressed concern about her father's health, noting reports that said Reed tried to escape and was beaten severely. ``It really depends on how they were treated,'' she said. ``If you think about being held almost four years without any contacts from the outside world, there's got to be something you'll have to go through.'' Reed made two trips to Lebanon before leaving his post as school principal in Whitefield, N.H., to become director of elementary education at Beirut's International College in 1977. At the time of his abduction on Sept. 9, 1986, he was running the private Lebanese International School, which he founded after his former school, the International College, was bombed out. After his abduction, a caller to a Western news agency claimed the American was a CIA spy and was taken hostage by Islamic Jihad. That Shiite fundamentalist organization denied holding him and other callers claimed responsibility in the name of the Moslem fundamentalist Hezbollah and the little-known Resurrection Cells. Reed's family called the espionage charge ridiculous.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Attorneys Accuse Govt. of Tying up Funds; Threaten to Withdraw
DOC.TEXT: Manuel Noriega's attorneys on Monday filed a motion to withdraw from the case, saying the government was trying to sabotage the defense by freezing the ousted Panamanian leader's money. Trying a penniless Noriega ``is like shooting fish in a barrel,'' lead defense attorney Frank Rubino said. ``The only thing the general owns at this time is essentially the clothes on his back.'' U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler set a meeting Wednesday with federal prosecutors to discuss the issue. Rubino said he expected a hearing by the end of the week. If the judge grants the motion, that could delay the April 1991 trial. Prosecutors refused to comment on details of the motion, but U.S. Attorney Dexter Lehtinen issued a statement defending the seizures. ``Nothing the government has done regarding illegally obtained assets has infringed on (Noriega's) rights in any way,'' Lehtinen said The government has been freezing Noriega's assets around the world as they are discovered. An initial list following his capture showed bank accounts and property worth about $30 million, but the Panamanian government has estimated Noriega's fortune could be $700 million. The withdrawal motion said the government continued to freeze Noriega's assets even when there was no reason to suspect they were drug-related, and had spurned defense requests to negotiate a solution. The Bush administration ``would very much like this case disposed of without a trial,'' the motion said. ``We have no doubt that the administration's refusal to negotiate over legal fees is in part motivated by its belief that without experienced counsel and adequate resources the general will decide to fold.'' Rubino said Noriega had been gainfully employed for 25 years in the Panamanian military and as leader of his country, and owned several businesses. He said it was ``ludicrous'' for the government to say Noriega had no legal assets. Defense attorney say they have received only a few thousand dollars from private sources for expenses since Noriega's capture, and nothing for their fees. Rubino said he needs $20,000 a month just to cover office expenses, and because of the complexity of the drug-smuggling trial, cannot handle other cases. The court could order the defense to continue, but the fixed $40-per-hour rate would not pay even minimal costs, he said. The motion said the defense needs money to travel, take depositions, and do research, but lacks the resources because of the frozen accounts. The defense wants to hire more attorneys and secretaries, and needs a team of investigators to go through a warehouse of documents in Panama, Rubino said. ``The government is spending $20 million to $30 million on their case,'' said Steven Kollin, another defense attorney. ``We don't need anywhere near that amount, but we may need $5 million to defend General Noriega.'' He emphasized that the defense is not asking for money the U.S. government claims is drug-related and subject to forfeiture laws. Rubino said fees in seizure cases usually are negotiated informally by the prosecution and defense, but on Friday, the prosecutor's office formally rejected any deal on the fees or expenses. They noted that the issue, according to the U.S. attorney's office, had been forwarded to Washington after the defense requested negotiations two weeks ago. Noriega is jailed at the federal Metropolitan Correctional Center on charges springing from a February 1988 indictment accusing him of accepting bribes to turn Panama into a safe haven for Colombia's Medellin drug cartel. He surrendered to U.S. authorities Jan. 4, two weeks after the United States invaded Panama. The trial had been set for January 1991, but was recently reset for April 1991, the attorneys said Monday. Kollin cautioned, however, that if the defense team withdraws, that date is likely to be set back further.

DOC.HEAD: New Home Sales Down in March
DOC.TEXT: High mortgage interest rates continued to hammer new home sales in March, driving them down 5 percent in the fourth consecutive monthly decline, the government said Monday. ``We're getting killed by high interest rates,'' said Richard Peach, deputy chief economist for the Mortgage Bankers of America. David Berson, chief economist for the Federal National Mortgage Association, agreed, saying that ``as long as they (rates) stay up, the housing market is going to be slow.'' ``It's not a recession pace,'' Berson said, ``but it's clearly not a boom period for housing either.'' The Commerce Department said new single-family homes were sold at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 574,000 units in March after dropping a revised 1.5 percent in February. Sales originally were reported to have risen 3.1 percent in February. The March level of sales was the lowest since an annual rate of 556,000 units a year earlier. Sales began to pick up in mid-1989 as mortgage interest rates declined, peaking at 741,000 units in July. But rates returned to their double-digit level in January and ranged between 10.22 percent and 10.34 percent in March, according to a survey by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corp. The National Association of Realtors also blamed high rates for flat sales of existing homes in March. They were unchanged from February's seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.4 million units. Rates have continued to rise this month, reaching 10.56 percent Friday, their highest level since averaging 10.61 percent in May, according to the Freddie Mac survey. The outlook for rates ``is not particularly positive,'' said Robert Villanueva, director of forecasting for the National Association of Home Builders. ``We had hoped that as we got into the summer building season, that interest rates would begin to drop,'' he said. ``But there's so many factors suggesting that rates will stay up that that's probably a forlorn hope.'' But while rates were rising, the median price of new homes was falling, down 1.4 percent to $123,200. The median price means that half of the homes cost more, half less. On the other hand, the average price of a new home rose 0.7 percent to $150,300. Sales in the South led the March decline, down 14.8 percent to 219,000 units. They were off 13.4 percent in the West to 161,000 units. But in the Northeast, where housing has been in the doldrums, sales rose 33.8 percent to 99,000 units. They also were up in the Midwest, 9.2 percent to 95,000 units. Berson said both increases were rebounds from the fourth coldest December on record. He said it takes an average of seven weeks between the time buyers start looking at homes to the time they sign a purchase contract. On the other hand, sales in the South and West were not as adversely affected by the winter weather and more closely followed the movement in interest rates, he said. For the first three months of 1990, sales have fallen 5 percent to an annual rate of 153,000 homes.

DOC.HEAD: Fawcett Says Marriage Isn't for Her
DOC.TEXT: Actress Farrah Fawcett likes her independence and has decided that marriage is definitely out of the question. Why? ``Because marriage is purely a business contract. It kills romance,'' she said. She said men don't like her independence, and longtime love Ryan O'Neal is the only man so far who has accepted it. She said O'Neal still proposes marriage, even after 10 years. She recalled the time in 1977 when she divorced Lee Majors, fired her manager and quit the television series ``Charlie's Angels.'' Unlike O'Neal, who doesn't hesitate to show his emotions or pick a verbal fight, Majors was the silent type, she said in an interview published Monday in The Denver Post. ``Lee didn't talk. He thought I should come home and make the dinner. And he didn't support me leaving the show,'' she said. And at ``Charlie's Angels,'' she said, ``the male producers kept patting me on the head while I was complaining that the characters had no depth.'' Fawcett said she has taken control of her career and has since starred in such acclaimed movies as ``Extremities'' and ``The Burning Bed.'' She said O'Neal accepts her the way she is. ``I'm my own woman and Ryan likes me that way,'' she said. ``He's never said `Don't do it.'''

DOC.HEAD: Former Phoenix Mayor Dies at 66
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS final graf to CORRECT that Galen is a daughter, sted son
DOC.TEXT: Margaret T. Hance, a pro-business leader who presided over eight years of explosive growth as Phoenix's first woman mayor, has died of cancer. She was 66. Hance, a national co-chairwoman of President Reagan's 1984 re-election campaign, died Sunday. The type of cancer was not immediately disclosed. Mrs. Hance was elected mayor in November 1975 and served four two-year terms before retiring in 1983. In 1988, she directed George Bush's presidential campaign in Arizona. Reagan appointed Mrs. Hance to the Advisory Commission on Intergovernmental Relations and the Presidential Federalism Advisory Committee. She also was a trustee of the U.S. Conference of Mayors, a director of the National League of Cities and a former president of the National Conference of Republican Mayors. Born Margaret Taylor in Spirit Lake, Iowa, on July 2, 1923, Mrs. Hance had lived in Arizona since 1926. She was a graduate of Scripps College in Claremont, Calif. Survivors include a daughter, Galen, and two sons, Richard and Ted.

DOC.HEAD: Hostage Freed in Lebanon
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 11 grafs to UPDATE with Bush reax, Iran warning that there will be no more releases without a goodwill gesture. Pick up 9th pvs, ``They have...' Minor editing to conform.
DOC.TEXT: Syrian officials said today that kidnappers freed U.S. hostage Frank Reed in Beirut after 43 months of captivity. In Washington, the State Department confirmed the release. ``We've got confirmation that he's been released and is in Syrian hands in Lebanon,'' said Kim Hoggard, a State Department spokeswoman. Reed was the second American to be freed by pro-Iranian Moslem kidnappers in nine days. U.S. professor Robert Polhill was freed on April 22. President Bush welcomed Reed's release, but said: ``We cannot rest ... until all hostages are free.'' Iran, however, cautioned that unless the United States reciprocates with a goodwill gesture, no more American hostages will be walking to freedom. ``Now the ball is in the court of the U.S. and the Western countries,'' said the English-language Tehran Times, considered close to President Hashemi Rafsanjani. The comments were in a Tuesday editorial. The Syrian officials, who refused to be identified further, said Reed, 57, was freed in Beirut at 8:30 p.m. (1:30 p.m. EDT) and was en route to the Syrian capital by car. They said they expected him in Damascus within two hours. Reed was being escorted by officers of the Syrian army contingent that controls east and north Lebanon as well as Moslem west Beirut, where he was kidnapped Sept. 9, 1986. The Syrian offcials would not say where in Beirut the hostage was freed. Journalists crowding the seaside Summerland Hotel, where previous hostages were released, said they did not see any hostage. Earlier today in Washington, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said a hostage reception team was being dispatched to Wiesbaden, West Germany. U.S. officials were in Wiesbaden just last week, debriefing Polhill after his 39-month-long ordeal. In Malden, Mass., Reed's hometown, an overjoyed Fahima ``Fifi'' Reed got word from the State Department that her husband had been turned over to Syrian authorities. ``They have word that Frank is with the Syrians now,'' she said. ``He's been handed over to the Syrians.'' Reed's release came a day after kidnappers released two statements promising to free him. One was signed by The Organization of Islamic Dawn. Shiite Moslem leader Hussein Musawi, who along with Syria and Iran played a key role in Polhill's release, said today he had ``not heard of this American hostage or the kidnap group'' before Sunday. ``No Islamic organization loyal to Jerusalem and following Ayatollah Khomeini's line will hand the Americans a new gift after its support of the Jerusalem resolution,'' he said. He referred to a non-binding resolution passed by the U.S. House of Representatives last Tuesday endorsing a united Jerusalem as the capital of Israel. Musawi called the resolution a demonstration of American ill will, and on Wednesday urged kidnappers not to free another American hostage. Musawi spoke to The Associated Press by telephone from his headquarters in the ancient Roman city of Baalbek in the Syrian-controlled Bakaa Valley of east Lebanon. He is the reputed mentor of Islamic Jihad for the Liberation of Palestine, the Shiite group that kidnapped Polhill and U.S. educators Alann Steen and Jesse Turner in Beirut Jan. 24, 1987. Turner and Steen are still captives. Iranian state radio, meanwhile, accused Washington of damaging efforts to free the Western hostages remaining in Lebanon by not reciprocating for Polhill's release. ``With regard to Washington's reaction .... the process of solving the hostage-taking crisis is much slower than was previously expected,'' Tehran Radio said in a commentary. The dispatch was monitored in Cyprus. After Polhill's release, Iranian officials and Lebanese Shiite leaders called for the reciprocal releases of Shiite fundamentalists held by Israel and Kuwait. President Bush has said he refuses to deal for the hostages. The Tehran Times today quoted an unnamed Iranian official today as saying Reed's captors agreed to free him after ``extensive talks'' that followed Polhill's release. Rafsanjani, leader of Iran's so-called pragmatists, is seeking to improve ties with the West after a decade of hostility. He is opposed at home by fundamentalist radicals allied to the Shiite militants in Lebanon. Reed, 57, was the director of the Lebanese International School. The promise to free him was made in two typewritten statements, accompanied by three photographs of the hostage. The messages and photos were delivered to Beirut's independent daily An-Nahar and a Western news agency. No demands was made for Reed's release. The kidnappers said he would carry a message to the Bush administrtaion. The first statement was unsigned. The second identified the kidnap faction as the Organization of Islamic Dawn. His abduction was earlier claimed by the Organization of Arab Revolutionary Cells-Omar Mukhtar Brigade. Reed had lived in Beirut since late 1977, before he was kidnapped. He had converted to Islam to marry his second wife, Fahima Dalati, a Syrian Moslem. He has a son, 9-year-old Tarek with Fahima, who prefers to be called Fifi, and two other children, Jacqueline and Marilyn, from his first marriage. They live in Medford, Mass. Mrs. Reed has been staying with her mother-in-law in Malden since leaving Beirut last year. The 16 hostages remaining in Lebanon include six Americans, four Britons, two West Germans, two Swiss, an Irishman and an Italian. The longest-held is American Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The AP. He was kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Train and Truck Carrying Molten Aluminum Collide Near Spokane
DOC.TEXT: Members of a train crew chased more than 100 runaway cars but were unable to prevent derailments, a spectacular fire and a collision with a truck carrying molten aluminum, authorities said. The four-man crew was relieved of duty pending an investigation into Sunday night's accident about five miles east of Spokane, said Howard Kallio, Burlington Northern Railroad spokesman in Seattle. The crew was undergoing urinalysis tests for drugs, he said Monday. No serious injuries were reported in the accidents, which caused an estimated $218,000 damage to railroad equipment and signals, Kallio said. ``We're chalking it up to human error,'' Kallio said. ``It looks like the crew made an error in not properly fitting the brakes on that train.'' Failure to properly set brakes while uncoupling three locomotives from a 101-car train let the cars roll free on a 2{-mile westbound runaway. One of the locomotives chased the runaway cars but struck a Kaiser Aluminum & Chemical Co. truck at a crossing and derailed, Kallio said. He said the truck was carrying two 15,000-pound crucibles of molten aluminum. The containers, carrying its load from Kaiser's Mead smelter to its Trentwood rolling mill, remained intact, spokeswoman Susan Ashe said. To save energy costs, the company has been hauling molten metal from its smelter to its rolling plant since 1971 without a major incident, Ms. Ashe said. The runaway cars continued westbound, striking an eastbound Montana Rail Link train, derailing its locomotive and 16 cars of the runaway train. The derailments ignited a 1,000-gallon propane tank, said West Valley Fire Chief Rod Tedrow. The tank's blast was loud enough to trigger burglar alarms in nearby homes. ``I heard these two loud explosions that rattled my windows,'' said Tara Havers. ``Then I looked out my kitchen window and I saw this big fireball.'' The tank held fuel for switch heaters, which are used to keep track switches from freezing during winter, Kallio and Tedrow said. The blaze was extinguished before midnight, Tedrow said. Tedrow said the Spokane rail yard was not notified that the cars were running loose so that safety signals and switches could be thrown. Kallio said he did not know how fast any of the cars or the locomotive were traveling at the time of the collisions. ``There were cars popping off the track here and there all along'' the route after the two trains collided, Tedrow said. The railroad's main line east of the city was closed while repair crews removed wreckage, Kallio said. Several trains, including Amtrak passenger trains, were rerouted to Union Pacific tracks between Spokane and Sandpoint, Idaho, about 75 miles to the northeast, without significant delay, Kallio said.

DOC.HEAD: Convicted Official Links Reagan White House to HUD Woes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 7-10, beginning `Pierce's lawyer ...' with 5 grafs to UPDATE with more comment from Pierce lawyer, ADD figure on amount Gilliam said he accepted. Picks up 11th graf pvs `Gilliam said ...' SUBS 22nd graf pvs `In another ...' to RESTORE dropped first reference to Lance Wilson.
DOC.TEXT: The Reagan administration's Department of Housing and Urban Development was a ``domestic political machine'' under Samuel R. Pierce Jr., handing out grants to the well connected, a former HUD official later convicted of bribery told a House subcommittee Monday. Dubois L. Gilliam, a former deputy assistant secretary under Pierce, disputed the former housing secretary's assertion that he didn't decide who got federal grants. Pierce himself ordered federal grants in some cases, Gilliam said. He linked the Reagan White House to the HUD controversy in at least one specific instance, saying the administration ordered federal money for a New Mexico project that had encountered problems. ``We dealt strictly with politics,'' he told the panel that has spent more than a year investigating allegations of fraud, mismanagement, influence peddling and political favoritism at HUD. ``During the period I was there ... the Department of Housing and Urban Development was the best domestic political machine I have ever seen,'' Gilliam said. Gilliam's testimony was the first the panel has heard from a former top HUD insider about Pierce's eight years as secretary. Pierce's lawyers, who attended the hearing, dismissed Gilliam's testimony as lacking credibility. Attorney Paul Perito called the testimony ``a sordid menu from an admitted felon.'' He said Gilliam never accused Pierce of violating the law, and that Gilliam was testifying in an effort to win early release from prison. Pierce testified before the panel last May, later invoking his Fifth Amendment right against self-incrimination to avoid further testimony. Three former top aides also refused to testify. Gilliam is serving an 18-month prison sentence after pleading guilty to accepting gratuities and conspiracy to defraud the government for abuse of HUD programs. Testifying under a court-ordered grant of immunity, he described receiving as much as $100,000 in clothes, money, travel and other gratuities from developers and consultants. Gilliam said he did not believe Pierce ever took any illegal gratuities. Subcommittee Chairman Tom Lantos, D-Calif., called Gilliam ``the key missing piece in the jigsaw puzzle.'' Gilliam's testimony about the Urban Development Action Grant program raised new allegations about a program under which grants were to be based on numerical formulas. He said HUD under Pierce considered who outside the agency supported projects when deciding which ones got money. Lantos asked Gilliam if he would agree with statements Pierce made in a September magazine interview and to his committee in May 1989, saying he never told his top assistants to fund particular projects by developers seeking HUD grants. ``I know for a fact the secretary made decisions'' on HUD grants, Gilliam said. He said Deborah Gore Dean, once Pierce's executive assistant, would not allow approval of discretionary grants ``without first clearing it with him.'' Dean also has refused to testify before the Hose Government Operations subcommittee on employment and housing. Gilliam said Pierce took a direct role in a proposed UDAG project at Hampton Institute, a predominantly black college in Virginia. ``He told me he wanted me to assist them and he wanted it funded,'' Gilliam said, referring to Pierce. Gilliam said that order came despite the lack of an application or financing for the project. Pierce later removed himself from the Hampton decision at the suggestion of the HUD general counsel because of his ties to the school, Gilliam said. ``The project was way down the road (toward approval) at that time,'' Gilliam said. Gilliam also testified that Dean told him Carol Crawford, associate director of the White House's budget office, ordered a UDAG grant go to an Albuquerque project in 1987. He said Dean learned that Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M., had appealed to Howard Baker, then the White House chief of staff, for help on the project. In another case, Gilliam said Pierce took a direct role in ordering the transfer to another job of a career HUD employee, David Sowell. He said Sowell had raised questions about the financial commitment offered on a proposed UDAG project by Lance Wilson, a former top aide to Pierce who was then working for a Wall Street investment firm. Gilliam said he suggested the transfer, and Pierce ordered it, after he expressed concern that Sowell was calling the department inspector general's fraud hot-line number. He said Wilson, after leaving HUD, was providing letters of financial commitment to get projects past application hurdles when the intent was that the project would obtain other financing later. Gilliam agreed with Lantos' description of Wilson's financial commitment as ``fraudulent.'' Pierce also acted to block grants for those in his disfavor, Gilliam said, citing a long-running feud between Pierce and Rep. Henry B. Gonzalez, D-Texas. Gilliam said that when Pierce learned that Gonzalez wanted a San Antonio project, the HUD secretary rejected it. Gilliam's testimony was to continue Wednesday and Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Text of Tehran Times Commentary on U.S. Hostages
DOC.TEXT: Here is the text of a commentary to be published Tuesday in the English-language Tehran Times on the hostage issue. The editorial was made available to The Associated Press in advance: By releasing a second American hostage, Lebanese Moslem groups proved their good will to the United States and the Western countries. Release of the two American hostages without any pre-conditions and solely for humanitarian and Islamic causes was an extreme gesture of good will and self-sacrifice by Lebanese Moslem groups. This important and major step showed that Lebanese Moslem groups are fully prepared for the resolution of the hostage crisis in the shortest possible time. They proved this readiness in practice. From the viewpoint of the Islamic republic of Iran, which put in months of hard effort, something miraculous has happened. The U.S. reaction after the release of the first U.S. hostage was not likeable, and it was also very unexpected. The U.S. House of Representatives in an ugly move declared Jerusalem as Israel's capital. President Bush declared he will show no good will until the release of all the hostages. Pro-Israeli and pro-Western groups released only four Lebanese Moslems from the hundreds of hostages they hold. Such moves were distantly hostile and also insufficient for creation of a serious humanitarian move. Moreover, the barbaric attacks of the occupier regime of Israel increased in the past week after the release of the first hostage. These actions in response to the Lebanese Moslem groups' humanitarian move showed that the U.S and other Western countries are not seriously determined to solve the hostage issue. With respect to these actions, the Lebanese Moslem groups were seriously doubtful about releasing a second hostage, thus endangering the entire effort of the Islamic republic. In order to pave the way for the release of all the hostages and to give the U.S. and the West a second opportunity so that they can give an appropriate response and show mutual good will, the Islamic republic insisted the Lebanese groups release a second hostage. Fortunately, with the unconditional release of a second hostage the extreme good will of the Lebanese Moslem groups and the Islamic republic of Iran was proved to the world. Now the ball is in the court of the U.S. and the Western countries. Through a mutual show of good will they can pressure Israel and pro-Western groups to release Lebanese prisoners and hostages, thus giving fresh life to the moves started by the Islamic republic, causing the release of the hostages to continue. The Islamic republic used its maximum power and credibility for the release of the hostages. Naturally, without an appropriate response from the West, there is no chance for the continuation of Iranian mediation and requests. Release of only four Lebanese from among hundreds of hostages and prisoners is nothing. It would be appropriate if, as the next step, a significant number of hostages including a few Iranian hostages and Sheik Obeid be released so that we can celebrate the year 1990 as the end of the hostage crisis.

DOC.HEAD: May Day Holiday Looking Grim For Brazilian Unionists
DOC.TEXT: An economic austerity program decreed six weeks ago has brought massive layoffs, and Tuesday's May Day holiday is no cause for celebration among Brazilian unionists. ``The economic situation has us with our backs against the wall,'' said Gilmar Carneiro, a union leader in Sao Paulo, the nation's largest city. The austerity plan was announced by President Fernando Collor de Mello on March 16, one day after he took office. It included spending cuts, the sale of state companies, and firing of government workers. It also froze $115 billion in savings accounts and money market deposits for 18 months. The measures, which Collor said were necessary to combat annual inflation of nearly 5,000 percent, have drastically cut the cost of living. But the economy appears headed for a steep recession. An estimated 300,000 workers have already been fired nationwide and about 700,000 more were put on collective holiday. On Friday, 1,470 metalworkers were laid off by three Sao Paulo firms. After giving workers a pay increase in March of 73 percent _ 10 percent less than the month's inflation _ the government froze wages in April. Labor and independent groups estimate inflation was at least 24 percent in April. The Inter-Union Department of Statistics and Socio-Economic Studies, a respected labor research group, said this month's minimum wage will be worth only $50, its lowest level since being created in 1940. Many Brazilians support Collor's efforts against inflation, but unions say workers are paying too high a price. Despite their opposition, no major strikes have been declared since March 16, and labor leaders say workers are so fearful of losing their jobs that unions are unable to act. ``Before, if paychecks were even a day late, there were strikers at factory gates,'' Carlos Aparicio Clemente, secretary-general of the Metalworkers Union in Osasco, Sao Paulo, told the major newsweekly Isto E. ``Important conquests by workers are being lost overnight.'' ``(Strikes) now would be stupidity. Our priority is the maintenance of jobs,'' said Jair Meneguelli, president of the leftist Workers Central Union, the country's largest labor federation representing 12 million workers. Unions, which represent about a third of Brazil's 65 million-strong workforce, are even having a hard time preventing workers from accepting salary cuts, as some businesses have demanded. ``We are against making concessions to the bosses,'' said Carneiro. ``When companies are making profits they never want to share the gains.'' But about 30 salary reduction pacts have already been signed in the past month, compared with a total of only five such deals during the country's last recession between 1981 and 1983. Many union leaders say companies are using the economic turmoil as a smokescreen. ``The mentality (of businessmen) is to take advantage of short-term difficulties,'' said Luis Antonio Medeiros, president of the Sao Paulo Metalworkers Union. But business leaders say wage cuts are the only way to prevent wider layoffs, as sales and revenues have plunged. ``Our sector is not going to return to the same level of production of before March 16,'' said Domicio dos Santos Junior, of the National Sindicate of Automobile Manufacturers. ``Reducing the work week and salaries is an attempt to minimize the effects of unemployment.'' Last Friday, the Sindicate proposed 130,000 industry metalworkers accept a temporary 30 percent cut in hours _ and thus salary. The average industry wage is currently $500 monthly. Meanwhile, union leaders fear darker days are ahead. A survey of 755 firms conducted by the Federation of Industries of Sao Paulo State, revealed 14.3 percent intend to fire workers over the next months. Carneiro estimated up to 250,000 bank workers, about 30 percent of the industry total, may be laid off if the economy doesn't pick up speed soon. ``If the situation worsens there may be strikes, but right now we don't have the forces,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Testimony Given About Boxes of Pesos and Jewelry
DOC.TEXT: Jurors in Imelda Marcos' fraud trial were told Monday about $1 million in newly-minted Philippine pesos and jewelry that were seized after the Marcoses fled to Hawaii. Twenty-two boxes of currency and jewelry, including a diamond tiara, were on a U.S. Air Force plane that followed the Marcoses to this country on Feb. 26, 1986, the day after Ferdinand Marcos was ousted as president, U.S. Customs agent Leslie E. Kinney said. Kinney returned to the stand after his testimony was interrupted Thursday, when Mrs. Marcos, 60, became ill from high blood pressure. On Monday, Mrs. Marcos was hooked up to a portable blood pressure monitor that beeped intermittently during Kinney's testimony. Mrs. Marcos is accused of helping her husband steal more than $220 million from the Philippine treasury to buy Manhattan real estate and art. She has pleaded innocent to charges of racketeering, racketeering conspiracy, mail fraud and obstruction of justice. Marcos, who also had been charged, died last September in Hawaii. Her co-defendant, Saudi businessman Adnan Khashoggi, is charged with mail fraud and obstruction of justice for allegedly helping the Marcoses conceal their ownership of four Manhattan buildings. Kinney identified four suitcases and a cardboard box, which he said were among the 300 to 400 pieces of luggage that came with the Marcos entourage to Hickam Air Force Base in Honolulu. He said the box was one of 22 that contained a total of 27 million pesos. He described the majority of the currency, whose value in 1986 was $1.4 million, as being ``in mint condition and consecutively numbered.'' Kinney also testified that jewelry was found in two suitcases, one containing an embossed card with Mrs. Marcos' name on it and the other had an invitation addressed to Mrs. Marcos tucked inside. Although jurors did not see the contents, Kinney identified seven pieces of jewelry, including two tiaras, necklaces and brooches, from photographs entered into evidence. The other suitcases were a battered aluminum case that Kinney said was filled with financial documents and a designer case marked: ``Properties -New York.'' He said the latter held Marcos' business documents and certificates of bearer stock. Kinney said the pesos, jewelry, documents and stock certificates were first stored in an underground ammunition bunker at Hickam, and later moved to a Customs vault in Honolulu. Most of the other luggage was returned. During cross-examination, Mrs. Marcos' lawyer, Gerry Spence, presented Customs declaration forms that had been filed on behalf of the Marcoses in February and March 1986. The forms reported more than 15 million pesos, the stock certificates, $315,000 in U.S. currency and 24 gold bars, which were worth about $286,000 in 1986. Spence also read from an attachment to the forms that said neither Marcos nor his agents were aware of the specific contents of the cargo and that receipt of the luggage ``is not an admission of ownership.''

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Researcher Suspended After Probe
DOC.TEXT: A government AIDS researcher hid his financial interest in a business while steering nearly $1 million worth of National Institutes of Health contracts to the company, congressional investigators said Monday. As a result of the congressional probe and a resulting investigation by a federal grand jury, researcher Syed Zaki Salahuddin was suspended Monday without pay, NIH officials said. ``The National Cancer Institute and NIH take violations of standards of conduct and concealment of financial interests in companies with which the government does business extremely seriously,'' William Raub, acting director of NIH, said in announcing the suspension. Salahuddin was out of the country Monday, according to his brother, S.M. Salahuddin. Raub disclosed the suspension at a hearing before the House Commerce investigations subcommittee, whose chairman, Rep. John D. Dingell, D-Mich., called the affair ``a sorry tale of gross conflict of interest.'' ``We appear to have an atmosphere of waste and abuse'' at NIH, Dingell said. ``It is no great surprise that one or more NIH scientists may have taken advantage of the lax atmosphere for personal gain.'' Raub said he was unaware of any potential ``sweetheart deal,'' such as the one charged to Salahuddin, that has been rooted out by NIH procedures over the past five years. ``Either we have a situation where human beings involved in NIH contracts are not falling victim'' to temptation or NIH procedures for detecting such conduct are not very good, said Rep. Ron Wyden, D-Ore. ``I have the same concerns you have,'' Raub replied. Investigators from the General Accounting Office, an arm of Congress, have spent 16 months probing the case of Salahuddin and Pan-Data Systems, a small computer and biomedical company in Rockville, Md. Among the findings: _The company's growth has been due in good part to a large number of NIH contracts for goods and services, most of which were bought by the laboratory headed by Robert G. Gallo, where Salahuddin worked until Monday. _Salahuddin was one of two people authorized access to Pan-Data's new post office box in 1984, shortly after the company was incorporated. His wife, Firoza, was listed as 25 percent owner in the papers of incorporation. Corporate minutes submitted to the Small Business Administration a few months later indicated Salahuddin was an equal shareholder and director. _In 1985 and 1986, NIH was assured by the president of Pan-Data that ``neither Mr. or Mrs. Salahuddin has any connection to this company. Neither have ever received, nor are they entitled to, any gratification in any form, monetary or otherwise.'' Said Raub: ``It certainly appears that the letters ... were false.'' _Salahuddin filed required annual financial-disclosure statements with NIH and never indicated any ownership of Pan-Data. In 1986, Gallo confronted Salahuddin with rumors of a financial interest in the company; Salahuddin said only his wife had been an employee and that she would quit. _Documents submitted to SBA identified Salahuddin as a Pan-Data owner and director of corporate development. _In 1988, Salahuddin and another scientist in Gallo's lab were assigned to evaluate two proposed contracts for testing a herpes virus. ``Prior to participating in the technical evaluation, Salahuddin told the assistant project director that Pan-Data Systems was the `only competent lab' to perform the required assays,'' said GAO investigator Clark B. Hall. NIH awarded contracts to Pan-Data and a competitor. Salahuddin told NIH officials Wednesday that his wife had been a founder of Pan-Data. In 1987 or 1988, Raub quoted Salahuddin as saying, the company had paid for the painting of the couple's home and had made mortgage payments on the house to compensate for Mrs. Salahuddin's services as a founder. Raub said NIH has tightened contract-review procedures in the wake of the Salahuddin investigation.

DOC.HEAD: List of Western Hostages of Lebanese Kidnappers
With AM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a list of the six Americans and 10 other non-Lebanese kidnap victims still missing in Lebanon: AMERICANS: 1. Terry A. Anderson, 42, chief Middle East correspondent of The Associated Press, kidnapped March 16, 1985. 2. Thomas Sutherland, 58, acting dean of agriculture at the American University of Beirut, abducted June 9, 1985. 3. Joseph James Cicippio, 59, acting comptroller at the American University in Beirut, kidnapped Sept. 12, 1986. 4. Edward Austin Tracy, 59, west Beirut resident. Revolutionary Justice Organization claimed on Oct. 21, 1986, to have abducted him. 5. Alann Steen, 51, a communications instructor at Beirut University College, kidnapped Jan. 24, 1987. 6. Jesse Jonathan Turner, 42, professor of mathematics and computer science at Beirut University College, kidnapped Jan. 24, 1987. OTHERS: 1. Terry Waite, 50, British envoy of the Anglican Church, disappeared Jan. 20, 1987. 2. Alec Collett, 68, British journalist, kidnapped March 25, 1985. 3. John McCarthy, 33, British television journalist, kidnapped April 17, 1986. 4. Alberto Molinari, 70, Italian businessman who lived in Beirut, kidnapped Sept. 11, 1985. 5. Brian Keenan, 39, an Irish teacher of English at the American University of Beirut, kidnapped April 11, 1986. 6. Jack Mann, 75, British missing in west Beirut since May 12, 1989. 7-8. Heinrich Struebig, 49, and Thomas Kemptner, 28, West German relief workers, kidnapped May 16, 1989. 9-10. Elio Erriquez, 24, and Emmanuel Christen, 33, Swiss Red Cross workers abducted Oct. 16, 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Woman's Fight Means Poor Families Get More Housing Choices
DOC.TEXT: A woman's fight for better housing with government assistance means that families across the country will have a wider choice of places to live, her lawyer says. Ann Smith, a nursing student with three children, sued federal and local housing authorities after she could not find an affordable apartment in Narragansett and the town's housing officials would not allow her to use a rent-subsidy certificate elsewhere. Narragansett officials cited federal regulations that the certificates could be used only in the town in which they were issued. But Ms. Smith complained that the $691-a-month limit on rent and utilities for a three-bedroom apartment ``wasn't even close'' to rents in the city. However, she did find a suitable apartment in North Kingstown. As a result of her suit, officials at the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development now acknowledge they misinterpreted a 1987 change in federal law and that the certificates can be used outside the community in which they are issued. ``The opportunity for finding decent housing is going to be expanded greatly,'' said Robert M. Sabel, a Rhode Island Legal Services lawyer who represented Ms. Smith. In Rhode Island, 4,417 families use the certificates for housing. Families must earn less than half the average local annual income and must contribute 30 percent of their income for rent. Ms. Smith's only income was $626 a month in Aid to Families with Dependent Children. She said she did not have time to work between her nursing studies and caring for her children, the oldest of whom is 10. HUD officials admitted they were wrong in January, and later U.S. District Judge Ronald R. Lagueux approved a settlement, The Providence Journal reported Monday. The 1987 law said a certificate issued in a metropolitan area can be used anywhere within it, so poor people aren't forced to congregate in one area. But HUD officials originally interpreted that to mean the certificate must be used in the city where it was issued. The agency now has ruled that a certificate is good for an area that includes a city and all the surrounding communities with strong economic and social ties to it. For Providence, that includes all of Rhode Island, as well as eight communities in Massachusetts. HUD spokesman Bill Glavin said the federal agency soon would tell all housing authorities of the change.

DOC.HEAD: Latvia Congress Pushes Secession; Lithuania to Honor Burned Man
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 20 grafs to UPDATE with memorial for man who burned himself to death, Soviet TV showing crowds, Landsbergis comment; pick up 20th graf pvs, `The suicide...'
DOC.TEXT: A Latvian citizen's group claiming to represent hundreds of thousands of Latvians demanded Monday that the republic follow Lithuania's lead and declare independence from the Soviet Union, a spokeswoman said. In Lithuania, about 20,000 people gathered to honor a countryman who burned himself to death in Moscow to protest the Kremlin's efforts to end Lithuania's independence drive. Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis called the man ``the first victim'' in the struggle for independence. ``And we hope he is the last,'' he told the crowd, according to Giedrius Drukteimis of the Sajudis pro-independence movement. The Latvian spokeswoman, voicing sentiments identical to those heard in Lithuania, said, ``This is an occupied country. We are under Soviet power here, under an occupying army.'' The Latvian Citizens' Congress, elected mainly from among ethnic Latvians, convened Monday and called for restoration of Latvian independence, spokeswoman Iveeta Buicke said. Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia were independent countries between World War I and World War II but were forcibly annexed by the Soviet Union in 1940. Ethnic Latvians make up just over half of Latvia's population of 2.7 million, and a poll published Monday by the Soviet government newspaper Izvestia said that 92 percent of those polled favor secession. Non-Latvian residents make up 46 percent of the republic, and 45 percent were for independence. The congress met three days before the official Latvian Supreme Soviet parliament was to consider whether to emulate Lithuania's March 11 declaration of independence. The Estonian parliament also has made clear it intends to follow Lithuania in seceding from the Soviet Union, but more cautiously. The Latvian congress claims the right to replace the republic's Supreme Soviet during the transition to independence. Its members were elected in March by registered ethnic Latvian voters. It says it represents about 700,000 Latvians. Latvian politicians are predicting a heated parliamentary battle on the independence issue later this week. ``May 3 and 4 are going to be very hot days,'' said Anda Anspoka of the pro-independence Latvian People's Front, which won a majority in the Supreme Soviet in elections held in March. Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev recently warned Latvian delegates that he would offer the republic special status in a reconfigured Soviet federation but he would not accept outright secession. Gorbachev embargoed oil and natural gas shipments to Lithuania in response to its parliament's declaration of independence, although the sanctions do not seem to have dampened the Lithuanians drive for sovereignty. Official Vilnius Radio reported on Sunday that Moscow planned to ease the sanctions by increasing natural gas deliveries to a large fertilizer plant at Jonova. However, deliveries did not increase Monday, and it was impossible to learn whether they would start before the end of the May Day holiday on Wednesday. The Lithuanians continued their protests. The body of the suicide victim, Stanislovas Jamaitis, 52, was flown to Vilnius from Moscow on Monday and taken to the Supreme Council parliament building in central Vilnius, Drukteimis said. Lithuanian radio and television broadcast announcements of the memorial service for Jamaitis, and Soviet TV showed brief footage Monday night of the crowds gathered near the parliament building. Jamaitis is to be buried Wednesday in his home village of Ezherelis near Kaunas, the republic's second city. Landsbergis, in a television appearance Monday, discouraged other Lithuanians from similar actions. In his speech at the gathering, he emphasized that ``we don't need victims,'' Drukteimis said. The suicide recalled the self-immolation of Lithuanian student Roman Kalanta in Kaunas in 1972. Kalanta became a martyr of Lithuanian nationalism, and the independence movement appeared to be preparing a similar role for Jamaitis. In the text of Jamaitis' suicide note released in Lithuania on Friday, he said ``Lithuanians will not live in a Lithuania that is not independent.'' Jamaitis died Thursday of burns he received when he doused himself with gasoline and set fire to himself in front of Moscow's Bolshoi Theater. Gorbachev has said that republics have the right to secede from the Soviet Union, but only if they do so in accordance with Soviet law. A law on secession requires two-thirds of a republic's voters to approve independence in a referendum and calls for a subsequent waiting period of five years in which the republic and Soviet Union would negotiate the terms of secession.

DOC.HEAD: Mental Gymnastics: The Wave of the '90s
DOC.TEXT: Walk into Maryellen Visconti's Center for Peak Performance and she shoots words like ``neurosensory development'' your way faster than a buzzing beta wave. She runs a health club for the mind in a mall in this university town, believing that ``mind-brain fitness is to the '90s what body fitness was to the '80s.'' Instead of slogans like ``no pain, no gain,'' Visconti urges her clients to ``find the zone'' and ``get in the flow.'' Instead of weight machines, Visconti 2000, as the center is known, offers a sound and light show using specially-designed goggles. The goggles have little flashing red lights inside, around the eyeholes. Anybody who kept their eyes open while wearing the goggles would shoot right out of the zone and into hyperactivity. But with the eyes closed, the lights flash subtle, changing patterns on the lids. The light shows are supposed to help clients reach a sort of meditative state so they can enhance creativity and accelerate learning, or, in Visconti-speak, to access ``personal skills and resources for creating the state of excellence to be in the flow.'' A session with the goggles, which usually lasts about 20 minutes, costs $25. Visconti stresses that she uses tapes, books and workshops to educate clients. But the nerve center of her mind gym is a room with two comfortable black chairs, where customers settle in for sessions with goggles programmed to take them to ``the zone.'' There are also headphones designed to produce the same effect via a low hum in the ears. And what is ``the zone?'' Something like a hypnotic or meditative state, achieved when brain waves go from the beta to the alpha level. Visconti describes the beta state as ``chatter, chatter, chatter because of outside stimulation.'' The alpha state is a relaxed level where creativity and the ability to learn are at their peak, she said. For Gary Antonick, winding up his studies at Harvard University's business school, Visconti 2000 sounded like a great idea. Antonick, a fit and trim 27-year-old, said his experience as a swimmer first sparked his interest in mental gymnastics. In college, at the University of Michigan, Antonick said he improved his performance on the school swim team through a technique called visualization. ``I went from terrible to all-American due to just a few minutes a day imagining what I was going to do in the water,'' said Antonick. Antonick said he has several goals for his mental workouts. One is to improve his game, literally. ``I'm a terrible squash player and I worked on it for two months and I was still terrible,'' he said. The other is to improve his mental skills _ maybe pick up a language. And the third is to keep himself healthy. ``Is it possible to cure a cold by visualization?'' he wondered. Visconti cautions that her company is not a health center; more an educational clinic. She has no formal training in psychology, but lists in her resume certifications in accelerated learning, stress management and self-talk technology. She originally was trained as a nutritionist and worked as a communications consultant for 20 years. Visconti's image is hardly that of the new-age crystal wearing, crunchy granola type. In fact, she looks every inch the businesswoman, bustling about a high-tech office decorated in stark black and white. ``What got me really going on this was as a young child, people told me I was very creative,'' Visconti said. ``Throughout my life I was very attracted to what the creative process was all about.'' She opened the Visconti 2000 center last fall. Although she won't say how many people now come to her on a regular basis, she says the center has sparked inquiries from as far away as Japan. There are scientists who say so far, research shows the best way to improve learning ability is the old-fashioned way: with hard work. ``There isn't any shortcut to that,'' said James McGaugh, director of the Center for Neurobiology of Learning and Memory at the University of California, Irvine. ``Everything is pretty straightforward. Pay attention. Stay alert. Study hard.''

DOC.HEAD: Hostage Had Remained in Lebanon Despite Danger
With PM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Frank Herbert Reed, freed Monday after being held hostage in Lebanon for more than 3{ years, had remained in the war-battered country because he felt he was ``doing good'' as an educator, his brother said. Even so, he had become convinced it was too dangerous to stay, and at the time of his abduction was trying to obtain a permanant resident visa for his Syrian-born wife, Fahima ``Fifi'' Dalati. A native of Boston's northern suburb of Malden, Reed attended Harvard University, the University of Maine and Northeastern University. At the time of his abduction, Reed was running the private Lebanese International School, which he founded after his former school, the International College, had been bombed out. According to Reed's older brother Edward, ``he thought it was a challenge to be there. He thought he was doing good there.'' But because of the increasing danger to Americans in Lebanon, Edward Reed said, he ``had intentions of coming home.'' Red had converted to Islam to marry his second wife, and the couple has a 9-year-old son, Tarek. Reed also has two grown daughters from a previous marriage. Reed's wife was to fly to West Germany, where her husband was to be flown from Damascus. She said he looked thinner and older in a photograph furnished by his captors, and she added, ``He'll need lots of love and affection.'' Reed's 91-year-old mother, Leota Sprague, said she had never lost faith that her son would be freed. ``I haven't been able to cry for four years,'' Mrs. Sprague said. ``Now I can smile and say thank God.'' One of Reed's daughters by his first marriage, Marilyn Langston, expressed concern about her father's health, noting reports that said Reed tried to escape and was beaten severely. ``It really depends on how they were treated,'' she said. ``If you think about being held almost four years without any contacts from the outside world, there's got to be something you'll have to go through.'' Before moving to Lebanon, Reed had been a teacher and school principal in New England, and he earned a reputation as an adventurer. He founded the Admiral Byrd Polar Club in Whitefield, N.H., which sponsored polar expeditions. Reed had traveled to the North Pole, the jungles of Brazil and the Australian outback. Reed was a personable, outgoing man, who made two trips to Lebanon before leaving his post as school principal in Whitefield, N.H., to become director of elementary education at Beirut's International College in 1977. After Reed was abducted on Sept. 9, 1986, a caller to a Western news agency claimed the American was a CIA spy. Reed's family called the espionage charge ridiculous.

DOC.HEAD: Nasty Weather Slows Shuttle Maintenance Work
With AM-Hubble Telescope, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Storms will delay Discovery's return to Florida, but the orbiter was in excellent shape after its 2.1-million-mile journey to launch the Hubble Space Telescope, NASA said Monday. ``You could almost roll this thing out there and fly it again,'' shuttle processing manager Tip Talone said. Few problems were found during preliminary inspection, Talone said. The shuttle's heat-shield tiles sustained 33 ``dings,'' but only five tiles were damaged seriously enough to require replacement, he said. Discovery, equipped with new and improved brakes, landed on a concrete runway at this desert military base on Sunday after a five-day mission to deploy the $1.5 billion telescope to study mysteries of the universe. NASA engineers at the Goddard Space Flight Center in Maryland said Monday they got the orbiting telescope working again by freeing a movable antenna that had jammed after brushing against an electrical cable. Gusts up to 40 mph threatened to delay Discovery's landing, but subsided long enough. Later, high winds kicked up a huge dust storm as crews towed Discovery across the dry lakebed on which the runway is located. ``It blew like hell,'' Talone said. Winds delayed efforts Monday to lift Discovery into its 100-foot-tall steel trusswork maintenance structure. Heavy rain fell Monday, slowing shuttle maintenance work as crews had to cover thrusters and other sensitive components to prevent water from leaking inside, he added. ``It makes life more miserable for guys doing the work,'' Talone said of the rain. Discovery had been scheduled to leave Edwards on Friday, mounted piggyback atop a modified jumbo jet for a one-day trip to Kennedy Space Center in Florida. Talone said the weather will delay the trip until Saturday, and possibly make it a two-day journey with an overnight stop at Kelly Air Force Base, Texas. Contributing to the delay was the need to remove one of Discovery's many small maneuvering thrusters. It failed and leaked just as the shuttle was being inserted into orbit after its April 24 launch from Florida, he said. Just as has been the case after many previous shuttle flights, Talone insisted Discovery returned to Earth in better shape than any shuttle has previously. ``Each tie we fly these things, it appears even better,'' he said. ``We're getting a clean vehicle back.'' Talone said Discovery's new carbon brakes, similar to those used on passenger jets, ``performed as well or even better than expected.'' They were removed and shipped to their manufacturer _ B.F. Goodrich in Troy, Ohio _ for analysis. But because Columbia and Atlantis haven't yet been fitted with the improved brakes, it will be late this year or early 1991 before the carbon brakes are tested again, Talone said. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration hopes the new brakes and other modifications will allow routine landings to resume at Kennedy Space Center. Talone said other minor problems included some chafing on Discovery's tires, a protective black coating that flaked off the surface of one of the damaged tiles, and unexplained but typical haze and streaks on the shuttle's windshield. During Discovery's flight, the crew found a watch that was lost by astronaut Sonny Carter when the shuttle flew on a classified Defense Department mission last November. At Kennedy Space Center, meanwhile, engineers found a small leak in the system that feeds liquid oxygen into the Columbia's main engines, but said repairs shouldn't delay the shuttle's scheduled May 16 launch to carry the Astro observatory on a nine-day mission. Discovery's next flight is scheduled to start Oct. 5, when it will launch the NASA-European Space Agency's Ulysses spacecraft on a mission to orbit the sun's poles.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Preference Dropped for Liberia; Kept for Thailand, Indonesia
DOC.TEXT: The United States will suspend trade benefits for Liberia on July 1, but will allow Thailand and Indonesia to continue to participate despite charges they have violated workers' rights, a trade official said Monday. The Bush administration found that Liberia had not taken steps to better its record but that the two Asian countries had, according to the official, who spoke on condition of anonymity. About 130 areas in the Third World were allowed last year to ship $10 billion worth of goods to the United States duty-free, or at reduced rates of duty. The measures encourage imports from those areas because the lower duties make them cheaper and more attractive to importers than goods from competing countries. Auto equipment such as tires, brakes and storage batteries are among the major imported items. The program is being expanded and is expected to grow by at least $500 million this year. Other major importing countries have similar preference programs. U.S. labor organizations had complained that some governments violated internationally recognized workers' rights by using child labor, restricting the formation of labor unions and other measures. U.S. law requires suspending privileges for those countries. A statement issued by Trade Representative Carla Hills said another year will be taken to review the cases against Syria, Benin, the Dominican Republic, Haiti and Nepal. Romania, Nicaragua and Burma remain suspended. Panama was reinstated earlier this year and Poland and Hungary were added to the list after the end of hard-line communist rule there. Other eastern European countries are expected to follow and Nicaragua is likely to be reinstated, the official said. New products will be made eligible from Bolivia, Colombia, Ecuador and Peru as part of the Bush administration's decision to help wean them away from traffic in drugs.

DOC.HEAD: Man Tries To Set Fire to Lenin Mausoleum
DOC.TEXT: A man with two jars of flammable liquid tried to set fire over the weekend to the stone mausoleum on Red Square where the body of Soviet founder Vladimir I. Lenin has been on display for nearly 70 years, Izvestia reported. The government newspaper said the man was arrested, but refused to answer questions or make any statement except for one sentence: ``My action has said all I have to say.'' The arson attempt late Saturday came two days before May Day celebrations that traditionally include columns of marchers passing through Red Square and being greeted by leaders standing atop the mausoleum. The man, who looked about 45, got past the fence around the red-brown granite mausoleum and throw two jars of flammable liquid onto its parapet, Izvestia said Sunday night. ``The mausoleum is undamaged, the fire was quickly put out,'' it reported. Statues and monuments to Lenin have come under increasing attack in Eastern Europe and parts of the Soviet Union. However, no such gesture was reported previously against the mausoleum, which is visited by tens of thousands of respectful Soviets each year. It was erected not long after Lenin died in 1924.

DOC.HEAD: Hostage Won Repute as Educator With Bent for Adventure
With AM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Amogene in graf 19 is cq
DOC.TEXT: Newly released hostage Frank Herbert Reed was an intelligent adventurer who got caught up in Middle East turbulence just as he was trying to leave the war-torn region, friends and relatives say. But they also say he had the Yankee stoicism it takes to ride out even the storm of 3{ years of captivity in Lebanon. ``He would never give up. I hope it's a Reed trait. We certainly are self-made in what we do,'' his 70-year-old brother, Edward, said after he and other family members received news of the release. Reed, 57, had traveled to the North Pole, the jungles of Brazil and the Australian outback. He was a teacher and school principal in New England and founded the Admiral Byrd Polar Club in Whitefield, N.H., which sponsored expeditions to Antarctica. But after making two trips to Lebanon, he left his post as school principal in New Hampshire to become director of elementary education at Beirut's International College in 1977. ``It appealed to the adventurer in him,'' Maryellen Cavan, a former New Hampshire colleague, said of Reed's decision to move. Later, he converted to Islam, the religion of his wife, Fahima Dalati, 39, a Syrian national who met him in 1977 while she was in training as a teacher. When the International College was bombed out, Reed founded the private Lebanese International School. A nephew said Reed decided to stay on because he believed he could be of help, especially to young students. And one of his daughters, Marilyn Langston, has said that education was all important to him. Still, while Reed came to believe ``violence was a way of life'' around Beirut and that he could work around it, he was not inured to it, Cavan said. ``He was pretty flamboyant and wouldn't show he was afraid,'' she said. ``But it certainly unnerved him.'' Finally, even Reed decided to leave. At the time of his abduction, he was trying to make arrangements for his wife, known as Fifi, to come to the United States and ``had intentions of coming home,'' Edward Reed said. The couple has a 9-year-old son, Tarek, and Reed has two grown daughters from a previous marriage. Reed grew up in Malden, the youngest son of three sons. His father was part owner of a leather wholesale firm. ``He was the baby in the family, and whatever the baby wanted, he got,'' said Edward Reed. Reed, who attended Harvard University, the University of Maine and Northeastern University, was always outgoing and an adventurer, friends and relatives say. ``He had an impact on everybody who dealt with him in our community,'' Cavan said. ``He's a unique individual.'' His 91-year-old mother, Leota Sprague, said she believes her son can do anything, and even thought during his captivity he might ``outsmart the people who kidnapped him, and escape.'' Amogene Rolerson, who taught with Reed in the early 1960s in Islesboro, Maine, said: ``He was a person who liked a lot of action. He liked to be doing and going. He was always in the thick of everything.'' ``I can't imagine him being cooped up all the time that he's been cooped up,'' she said. Reed and his wife faced the objections of her parents because he was American and Protestant. ``We had to try to convince them we wanted to get married,'' Mrs. Reed said. ``We were just the right people for each other. This is the time I remember. We just had a great time together. I used to say, `It's too nice to be true,' and it was too nice to be true. It ended all of a sudden.'' She and her son have been living at her mother-in-law's Malden apartment for about a year. They had come on vacation and decided to stay when violence in Beirut escalated. Almost all of Reed's immediately surviving relatives were at the apartment when news of his release came. ``I'm thrilled. I'm overjoyed. I'm everything. All of the above that describe happiness,'' she said. After Reed was abducted on Sept. 9, 1986, a caller to a Western news agency claimed the American was a CIA spy.
