Reed's family called the espionage charge ridiculous, saying Reed had no interest in politics. ``I don't even think he's a registered voter,'' said nephew Ken Reed. A former Lebanese reporter, Tewfik Mishlawi, now working at the Center for Foreign Journalists in Reston, Va., said: ``He was apolitical and had friends all over the country.'' Mishlawi said Beirut's cycle of terror kept Reed's new school from flourishing. But, said Reed's older brother Edward, ``he thought it was a challenge to be there. He thought he was doing good there.''

DOC.HEAD: Task Force Criticizes Probe into Murders of Salvadoran Jesuits
DOC.TEXT: The investigation into last year's murders of six Salvadoran Jesuit priests has ground to a halt and is unlikely to bring to justice all those responsible, a House Democratic task force charged Monday. The task force, appointed by Speaker Thomas Foley soon after the Nov. 16 murders, issued a harshly critical report that appeared likely to fuel opposition to new U.S. military aid to El Salvador. ``As of mid-April, the investigation and preparations for prosecuting the case have come to a virtual standstill,'' reported the 19-member group, made up primarily of liberal Democrats opposed to Bush administration policy toward El Salvador. Nine military officials were charged following the murders _ an unusual step in El Salvador, where death squads with military involvement have been carrying out executions for the past decade with apparent legal impunity. But while the task force gave credit to President Alfredo Cristiani for pushing the investigation forward, it said key questions remain unasked and that investigators and the judge in the case appear reluctant to pursue leads that could lead to involvement of higher-ups. ``This lack of continued progress, coupled with certain aspects of Salvadoran law, make it less likely that full justice will be done,'' the report concluded, adding that the failures are symptomatic of deep institutional problems in the military and the system of justice. Task force leader Rep. Joe Moakley, D-Mass., said he expected the report to bolster opponents of U.S. military aid to El Salvador. The House Foreign Affairs Committee last week approved a provision that would cut the $85 million annual aid in half, and make the remaining aid contingent on progress toward peace at United Nations-sponsored talks by both the government and the leftist FMLN rebels. Those charged in the murders are members of the elite U.S.-trained Atlacatl batallion. Senate Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, said in an interview that he believes military aid should be limited. ``I have grave reservations about continuing military aid, especially at the current levels,'' Mitchell said. ``I favor limitation and restriction of such aid in view of the tragedy that has occurred in that country over the past several years .... There has to be some change in our current policy.'' Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who has promised to seek a new bipartisan approach to U.S. policy in El Salvador, was scheduling meetings this week with congressional leaders to open discussions. Miguel Salaverria, El Salvador's ambassador to the United States, disputed the report's conclusion that the investigation had stalled. He said Cristiani ``has a real concern that more investigation should be made'' into rumors that top military officials may be involved. But Salaverria added: ``Cutting (aid) now would be the wrong time to do it. El Salvador has never been closer to peace than we are at this moment.'' He said he believed the murders came about because ``someone in this whole thing succumbed to provocation,'' referring to rebel attacks on family members of mayors and military officers. The task force also said those charged in the crime might never have been arrested if a U.S. military officer _ an Army major assigned to the U.S. Embassy in San Salvador _ had not come forward in January with information implicating Col. Alfredo Benavides, the most senior official charged. The task force said it was ``very disappointed'' by the failure of the investigating unit to look seriously into whether superiors to Benavides may have ordered or known about plans for the murders. The judge handling the case, Ricardo Zamora, also has seemed at times uninterested in pursuing the case vigorously, the group reported. ``Even today, a series of questions about the possible involvement of higher officials in ordering the crimes remain unanswered and, as far as can be determined, unasked,'' the report stated.

DOC.HEAD: B-2 Resumes Flight Tests
DOC.TEXT: The B-2 Stealth bomber has resumed flight testing after a five-month respite, the Pentagon announced Monday. The radar-evading aircraft took off from Edwards Air Force Base, Calif., Friday morning and reached an airspeed of 325 knots and an altitude of 35,000 feet before touching down later in the afternoon, an announcement said. ``I've very pleased with the flight tests results,'' Maj. Gen. Dick Scofield, the director of the B-2 program, said in a statement. Scofield called the six-hour, five-minute flight ``an especially remarkable achievement'' in light of the five-month layup for the plane. During that time, the aircraft was virtually pulled apart to check it after its initial test flights. Changes were made in the software in the plane's nose-wheel steering, environmental control system and pilot displays, the statement said. The Pentagon said the aircraft is expected to make five to seven more flights before going into a second planned layup and preparation for the final tests of its stealth capabilities. A second B-2 is scheduled to make its first flight later this year, the statement said. Bowing to congressional budget pressure and the reduced Soviet threat, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney announced last week that the Pentagon intends to sharply reduce the proposed purchase of bombers from 132 to 75. That smaller purchase is expected to drive up the cost of the plane from $530 million to $815 million each because of higher production costs.

DOC.HEAD: Five More Companies Join Recall of Infant Pillows
DOC.TEXT: Five more manufacturers of a type of infant pillow linked to the suffocation deaths of 19 children joined a nationwide recall of the items Monday, the Consumer Product Safety Commission announced. The recalls expand the number of recalled pillows to nearly one million. They came 11 days after the agency announced voluntary recalls by eight other manufacturers and retailers involving 644,000 of the ``bean bag'' style fabric-covered cushions sold under several brand names. The cushions are filled with polystyrene pellets. The latest recall included Comfort Products of Dallas, which commission officials said had resisted the initial recall. Jacqueline Jones-Smith, CPSC chairwoman, said 19 infants 3 months old or younger had been ``found dead lying stomach-down'' on the cushions since September 1987. The latest three deaths were last January and February, she said. Ten occurred last year. The soft pillows conform to the baby's shape and could engulf a child placed face down on them, the CPSC said. On March 6, the commission issued a warning urging parents to discontinue use of the pillows, but it did not move to ban the pillows because such action can take longer than voluntary recalls, said CPSC spokesman Dan Rumelt. The commission said consumers should immediately stop using the products and contact the manufacturer for any exchange that might be available. The new batch of recalls and the manufacturers included: _``Comfort Tote,'' ``Comfy Tote'' and ``Cushie Comfort'' by Comfort Products; 133,800 have been sold. _``Baby's Cloud'' by U.S. Mom's of Las Vegas; the CPSC says these products should be destroyed because the manufacturer is out of business; about 3,500 were sold between 1985 and 1988. _``Sof-Sak'' by MFP of Hays, Kan.; 76,000 were sold nationwide from 1986 through February 1990. _``Comfort Cushion'' by Tailored Baby, Inc., San Fernando, Calif.; approximately 78,000 were sold from 1988 through April 1990. _``Baby Jacks Bean Bag'' by Jumping-Jacks Shoes, Inc., Monett, Mo., which manufactured about 45,000 sold in Jumping-Jacks Shoes and other retail stores from 1985 through February 1990. The previously announced recalls were ``Mother's Helper'' by Hollander Home Fashions of Newark, N.J., which announced its recall in January; ``Gold Bug Support Sacks'' by Gold, Inc., of Denver; ``Cozy Cushions'' by Pinky Baby Products of Houston; ``Cozy Baby'' by Cozy Baby Products, Mount Vernon, N.Y.; ``Baby Minder'' by The Fourth Little Pig of San Anselmo, Calif; ``Baby Sak'' by Baby Sak of Pembroke Pines, Fla., and cushions sold by J.C. Penney Co. and the Army and Air Force Exchange Service. The government's consumer affairs hotline, 1-800-638-2772, provides automated information on individual recalls and takes reports on incidents involving the cushions.

DOC.HEAD: Commodity Prices at Farm Edge Higher in April, Says USDA
DOC.TEXT: Prices farmers get for raw products increased 0.7 percent from March to April, raising the overall commodity index 2 percent above a year ago, the Agriculture Department said Monday. But revisions showed the department's ``prices received'' index has declined about 2 percent from the record level set in January. That included a decline in March instead of an increase shown by the preliminary figures a month ago. According to the revisions, the index rose 3.4 percent in January from its December average before dropping 1.3 percent in each of the next two months. Prices of raw agricultural products can swing widely during a single month, and for that reason and others are not considered reliable indicators by themselves of overall food price trends at the consumer level. Higher prices for oranges, corn, potatoes and cattle were mostly responsible for the overall price increase from March, the department's Agricultural Statistics Board said in its preliminary report. Lower prices reported for tomatoes, milk, eggs and broilers partly offset the gains for the other commodities. Most prices are mid-April averages which will be revised next month. New quarterly figures showed prices paid by farmers to meet expenses were up 1.1 percent from January and averaged 3.4 percent more than in April 1989. ``Since January, higher prices for feeder pigs and feeder cattle and calves were moderated by lower fuel and energy prices,'' the report said. Prices of cars and trucks, farm chemicals, tractors and self-propelled machinery were generally up from last year's surveys. Most retail seed prics were lower than a year ago. Department economists say the net cash income of farmers in 1990 may be in the range of $54 billion to $58 billion, compared with about $53 billion in 1989. The record was $57.2 billion in 1988. Net cash income is the money nationally that farmers have left from gross cash income during a calendar year after deducting cash expenses. It includes government payments and proceeds from crops grown previously but sold during the year. In another method taking into account changes in inventories, depreciation and other allowances during a calendar year shows that 1990 net farm income may be in a range of $45 billion to $49 billion, compared with $49 billion last year. Consumer food prices are forecast by USDA economists to rise 3 percent to 5 percent this year after posting an average gain of 5.7 percent in 1989, the sharpest rise since 1981. Based on the preliminary figures, the April price index for livestock and poultry dropped 1.2 percent from March but still averaged 9.7 percent more than a year ago. Milk prices dropped an additional 60 cents in April to an average of $13.10 per l00 pounds. Even so, the preliminary April price was up 70 cents from April 1989. The farm price of milk rose to a record $16 per hundredweight in December. Crop prices, overall, rose 3.1 percent from March but averaged 7 percent below the year-earlier level. Fruit prices, led by oranges and grapefruit, were up 11 percent from March and by the same margin of 11 percent from a year ago. The index for commercial vegetables dropped 13 percent from March and averaged 28 percent below the year-earlier level, reflecting abundant tomato supplies and low prices. Tomato prices were reported at $16 per 100 pounds, down from $32.80 in March and $55.80 in April 1989. Onions, however, rose to $23 per 100 pounds from $19.60 in March and $10.90 a year earlier. Prices of potatoes and dry beans, which are measured collectively, increased 14 percent from March to April and were up 13 percent from a year earlier. The report said: _Cattle averaged $75 per 100 pounds of live weight nationally, up from $74.20 in March and $70.10 in April 1989. Those are averages for all types of cattle sold as beef. _Hogs averaged $52.90 per 100 pounds, compared with $51.30 in March and $36.90 a year earlier. _Corn, at $2.52 a bushel, was up from $2.37 in March but was just short of the $2.56 year-earlier average. _Wheat prices at the farm, according to preliminary figures, averaged $3.51 per bushel, compared with $3.49 in March and $4.03 a year earlier. _Rice averaged $7.26 per 100 pounds, compared with $7.50 in March and $6.74 in April 1989. _Soybeans were $5.62 per bushel, compared with $5.65 in March and $7.29 a year earlier. _Upland cotton was reported at 64.8 cents per pound, up from 64.1 in March and 58.7 a year earlier. _Eggs were 71.4 cents per dozen, compared with 79.3 in March and 66.1 in April 1989. _Milk was $13.10 per 100 pounds, down from $13.70 in March but above the average of $12.40 a year ago. _Broilers were 33.2 cents per pound, live weight, down from 36.4 cents in March and from 39.1 cents a year earlier.

DOC.HEAD: High Court Gives States, Consumers Tool to Challenge Completed Mergers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 8th graf: ``California's attorney,'' with state reaction
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court gave state governments and consumers a potential pocketbook victory Monday, saying they may use federal antitrust law to try to break up corporate mergers. The unanimous decision empowers California officials to challenge a $2.5 billion merger of the Lucky and Alpha Beta supermarket chains. If the state wins its lawsuit and splits up the business deal, officials said California consumers could save $440 million a year in grocery bills. Justice John Paul Stevens, writing for the court, said any opponent of a merger _ not just the federal government _ has the right to sue to force divestiture of merged businesses. The ruling, however, does not give states and individuals the same sweeping power enjoyed by the federal government. Stevens said federal officials can force divestiture merely by proving an antitrust violation but said, ``A private litigant ... must prove threatened loss or damage to his own interests in order to obtain relief.'' The decision sends the supermarkets merger case back to lower courts where the state will try to prove the merger is illegal. California's attorney general, John Van de Kamp, said he was delighted with the court's ruling: ``It's a great victory for California's consumers, as well as consumers all over the country, because this case is now national in its implications.'' Justice Anthony M. Kennedy, in a separate concurring opinion, said the California attorney general's office still faces some hurdles at trial. The state knew of the impending supermarket merger in early 1988 but waited months before it sued, he said. Kennedy noted that the Federal Trade Commission permitted the merger and that the break-up will ``upset labor agreements and other matters.'' ``These considerations should bear upon the ultimate disposition of the case,'' he said. It was widely assumed before Monday's decision that states and private citizens could prevent anti-competitive business combinations but could not interfere once such deals were completed. But Stevens said the Clayton Act, passed in 1914 when Congress was preoccupied with trust-busting on a national scale, can be a weapon even against a completed merger. Lucky, California's largest supermarket chain, and Alpha Beta, the fourth largest, operate some 600 stores in the state. Alpha Beta's parent company, American Stores, acquired Lucky in June 1988 to merge the two chains under the Lucky name. American has 1,500 stores in 40 states, while Lucky's operations are in seven Western and Midwestern states. American Stores said California customers would save more than $40 million a year because of increased efficiency. But state officials said the merger would drive other competitors out of business and would lead to $440 million in higher grocery prices each year. U.S. District Judge David Kenyon in Los Angeles temporarily blocked the merger in 1988, and ordered separate operation of the two chains pending further litigation. But the 9th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals overturned the judge's ruling and lifted the break-up order. The appeals court said the state could have prevented the merger had it sued quickly enough, but could not dissolve the completed business deal. Monday's decision overturned the appeals court ruling.

DOC.HEAD: `Driving Miss Daisy' Reaches End of Road Off-Broadway
DOC.TEXT: It's the end of the road for ``Driving Miss Daisy.'' The Pulitzer prize-winning play about the relationship between an elderly white woman and her black chauffeur will close June 24 after an off-Broadway run of 1,219 performances, David Powers, a spokesman for the show, said Monday. The comedy, written by Alfred Uhry and which now stars Frances Sternhagen and Arthur French, is off-Broadway's fourth longest running play. The movie version, with Jessica Tandy and Morgan Freeman, won the Academy Award for best picture in March. Freeman was in the play's original cast, along with Dana Ivey who played Miss Daisy. Miss Tandy won a best actress Oscar for her screen performance.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Won't Step in to Quiet Bands in French Quarter's Jackson Square
DOC.TEXT: Artists and shop owners driven to distraction by loud brass bands blaring Dixieland jazz in the heart of the French Quarter lost their fight Monday to establish court-ordered quiet. State Judge Richard Ganucheau rejected a request that he order police to enforce New Orleans anti-noise ordinances in Jackson Square, an area of stone sidewalks and greenery between the quarter's St. Louis Cathedral and the Mississippi River. Novelty shops, bars and artists who set up booths on the sidewalks cater to tourists in the area, as do street musicians who collect money thrown into their hats or empty instrument cases. At a hearing Friday, a city attorney argued that city police already try to enforce the anti-noise ordinances by using decibel meters. But, he said, the offending bands play more softly when they know they are being monitored. The Association of Businessmen and Artists of Jackson Square argued that more police manpower and more discreet use of the meters would help. Police say they do the best they can with the manpower available. Ganucheau said in his written ruling Monday that it wasn't up to him to tell police how to allocate their resources. ``This court finds that it does not have the authority to direct the superintendent of police in his method of enforcing the municipal noise ordinance,'' he wrote.

DOC.HEAD: 13-Year Study Says TV Makes Viewers Moody, Unable to Concentrate
DOC.TEXT: The nation's couch potatoes say watching television is mindless, boring, addictive and takes less concentration than any activity short of sleep. Americans will spend an average of two hours per day, the equivalent of seven years over a lifetime, sitting in front of the tube, according to a 13-year study of viewers released Monday. Viewers in the study reported their hours in front of the tube made them feel worse rather than better. But like drug users struggling to kick an unwanted addiction, they have a hard time pulling the plug. ``A viscous cycle can develop wherein viewing begets more viewing,'' said the study's co-author, Robert Kubey, a Rutgers University psychologist. ``Both the realization and escape that television so readily provides also leads many viewers to become dependent on the medium.'' Kubey and Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi of the University of Chicago published their findings in a book, ``Television and the Quality of Life: How Viewing Shapes Everyday Experience.'' And while many turn to the tube to feel better, they usually wind up feeling worse after a dose of news, cop shows and sitcoms. Viewers said they become more drowsy, bored, sadder, lonelier and hostile the more they watch. The misery is a sort of family activity, the researchers found. ``While television generally increases the total time that family members spend together, it tends to reduce their interaction with one another and they spend a disproportionate amount of this time together in a passive mode,'' Kubey said. Spokesmen from ABC and NBC said they were looking at information from the study and weren't ready to comment. A CBS spokeswoman did not immediately return a telephone call seeking comment. Howard Gardner, a psychologist at Harvard University, said the project is seen as one of the most inclusive analyses on the effects of television among thousands of studies on the medium. To assess viewing patterns and the impact they have on mood, the researchers said they looked at viewers in a different way than in previous studies. Instead of asking them to recall events or take tests in a laboratory, Csikszentmihalyi and Kubey asked 1,200 people, ranging from age 10 to 82, to carry beepers and to write down how they felt every time it went off. ``Basically,'' Csikszentmihalyi said, ``we collected a series of snapshots of what people were doing and how they felt at the time. ... We were thus able to map moods and patterns of behavior that may have eluded the subjects themselves.'' The researchers discovered a perverse sort of benefit from the TV-induced trance: ``Certainly it can be argued that using television in this manner habitually is no worse, and may indeed be better, than habitually using alcohol or other mood-altering substances.''

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Deputy To Undergo Surgery
DOC.TEXT: Soviet politician Boris Yeltsin was taken to a hospital Monday with a slipped disc and was to undergo back surgery, regional television said. The outspoken Soviet Congress deputy, who has a history of heart trouble, arrived in Barcelona Sunday night and was to have appeared on a television panel show Monday. The television, TV-3, said Yeltsin would be operated on at Barcelona Hospital. TV-3 said Yeltsin had complained of back pains during the day Monday and had canceled a scheduled news conference and meeting with Catalan officials. Yeltsin, 59, a former Moscow party chief, began to gather mass support in 1987, when he spoke out for a faster pace of Soviet reforms. He was ousted from his Moscow post as a consequence. Yeltsin's autobiography, ``Against the Grain,'' was recently published in the West, and describes other periods of ill health. Yeltsin has been hospitalized frequently in the Soviet Union. Most recently, he missed part of the Soviet Congress session in early March, and friends said his heart was acting up again.

DOC.HEAD: Former Senator Agrees to Pay Abscam Fine
DOC.TEXT: Former Sen. Harrison A. Williams Jr. of New Jersey has agreed to pay off $47,000 remaining from his 1981 fine for bribery and conspiracy in the Abscam case, his attorney said Monday. ``We believe by the end of this summer, his fine will be paid in full,'' John D. Arsenault said from his office in Roseland, N.J. Dick Lavinthal, a spokesman for the U.S. attorney's office in New Jersey, declined to comment. Rep. John J. Duncan Jr., R-Tenn., said the Justice Department had told him of an agreement by which Williams would pay the rest of his $50,000 penalty. Duncan had asked the Justice Department last year to consider recovering the money from Williams' federal pension. ``Sen. Williams apparently had a change of heart after I prodded the Justice Department,'' Duncan said. But Arsenault said: ``His intention was always to pay it off. There has never been a question about that. Contrary to popular belief, he doesn't have $50,000 laying around in a closet someplace. He does not have any appreciable assets.'' However, the attorney declined to say how Williams, a volunteer at a drug crisis center in Newark, N.J., ``with no other earned income'' would find the money to repay his fine. ``I presume there may be some debt involved in paying this off,'' he said. Arsenault said that as of February, ``arrangements already had been made to satisfy the obligation'' through negotiations with the U.S. attorney's office. According to Arsenault, Williams has cooperated with the Justice Department since his release from prison in 1986. Williams was released on good behavior after serving two years of concurrent two-year and three-year sentences for bribery, conflict of interest and conspiracy in the Abscam sting. In Abscam, undercover agents posing as middlemen for Arab sheiks made a deal with Williams. He agreed to accept a hidden interest in a Virginia titanium mine in return for helping to find military contracts for the venture, according to evidence from his trial.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Selection Begins For Man Accused Of Poisoning Tree
DOC.TEXT: Jury selection began Monday for the trial of a man who faces a possible life prison sentence if convicted of poisoning a famous, centuries-old oak tree. Paul Stedman Cullen, 46, is accused of pouring the herbicide Velpar around the base of the Treaty Oak, where, according to folklore, Stephen F. Austin signed a treaty with Indians in the 1820s. Austin is regarded as the father of Texas. The poisoning was discovered Memorial Day. Half of the 60-foot tree has died, despite $100,000 in donations and herculean efforts to save it, officials have said. The act shocked residents and touched people around the country. Many sent get-well cards to the tree or stopped to write messages and leave tokens at its base. Workers have severed the most severely affected roots and have injected sugar water in hopes of diluting the poison. Cullen, of Elroy, was charged with felony criminal mischief and has been in jail without bail for more than 10 months. He could be sentenced to life in prison if convicted because he has a prior burglary conviction. Police and prosecutors have never detailed the suspected motive. When Cullen was arrested on June 29, 1989, an arrest warrant alleged the poisoning was part of a ``ritual.'' Sgt. John Jones, who investigated the case, refused to elaborate. The Austin American-Statesman reported before his arrest that a suspect in the case was trying to cast a spell in a romantic matter. Said Jones: ``The occult's really got nothing to do with it. He's charged with damaging the tree ... Normally what we have to prove is intentionally and knowingly damaging property. We don't necessarily have to prove why he did it.'' Attorneys expect the trial to last about two weeks. Cullen also could face up to 15 years in prison for federal charges of possession of a firearm by a felon and making a false statement to a firearms dealer. The charges stem from a .22-caliber rifle that police say was found in his truck when he was arrested.

DOC.HEAD: US to Help $200 Million Fund for Eastern Europe
DOC.TEXT: President Bush annnounced on Monday a $200 million ``growth fund'' _ including $50 million from the U.S. government _ to help move eastern Europe away from its communist system. The $50 million will come from the government's Overseas Private Investment Corporation (OPIC), one of its few profit-making agencies. For the year that ended last September, the corporation turned over $122 million to the Treasury. It earned the money largely by insuring Americans against hostile acts to their property in other countries. ``For democracy's sake, we've got to do all we can to help this transition take place,'' Bush told the annual meeting of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. Private U.S. investors are expected to supply the remaining $150 million. The government corporation will insurethem against having their money blocked or confiscated, and against war and violence in the countries where the fund will be active. James V. Hall, the corporation's spokesman, said the fund should be operating in about six months, beginning with help for private investors in Hungary, Poland and Yugoslavia. Later Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, Romania and East Germany are expected to become eligible. The Soviet Union is not excluded, Hall added. He said the fund probably will be managed by a U.S. institution, and will earn 10 to 15 percent a year for investors. The government corporation will not insure the earnings, only the right of the investors to take their money back home, Hall explained. Private companies in the eastern European countries will be able to borrow from the fund, and it will buy small quantities of their stock. As a result, the U.S. government will become partial, indirect owner of many private companies in countries which until last year were under communist rule.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 3 grafs to highlight toy model contribution; picks up 2nd graf pvs. SUBS 10th graf pvs: ``One engineer,'' with three grafs, now grafs 12-14, bgng: ``We were,'' with quotes from engineer.
DOC.HEAD: Engineers Fix Antenna Movement on Space Telescope
DOC.TEXT: NASA engineers got the $1.5 billion Hubble Space Telescope working Monday with the help of a model built with a piece of lamp cord and plastic sticks from a toy store. The model helped engineers visualize what was jamming one of the primary antennas on the telescope, which was put into a 381-mile high orbit last Wednesday by astronauts on the space shuttle Discovery. Analysis showed that one of the telescope's high-gain antennas was jammed when it brushed against an electrical cable that was too long by about an inch. ``We are still investigating it to understand how did this really happen, why did it happen, why didn't we catch it?'' said Jean Olivier, one of the top NASA officials on the project. ``We're not through with that investigation.'' By Tuesday evening, the telescope should be in a condition where calibration and other normal start-up work can begin, said Mike Harrington, director of the troubleshooting team. The antenna jammed on Friday when engineers were running it through its paces. Sensing something wrong and trying to prevent damage, the telescope's computer shut down the whole system. The telescope's two high-gain antennas are designed to transmit science data to two orbiting relay satellites at very high speeds _ up to the equivalent of a 30-volume encyclopedia in 42 minutes. ``For a while we were puzzled as to the data we were receiving from the spacecraft and therefore lacked a clear understanding physically of what the problem was with the high gains,'' Olivier said. ``All that has significantly changed.'' Detective work by NASA and its contractor teams led to an understanding of the problem. While studying pre-launch photographs of the telescope nestled in the cargo bay of space shuttle Discovery, an engineer noticed that an inch-thick electrical cable on the back of the antenna was slightly out of position. Olivier said the length of the cable was determined by computer simulations and turned out to be an inch or so too long. The antenna movement could not be tested on Earth because the motors are not powerful enough to move the antenna in the presence of gravity. From the photographs, engineers decided the too-long loop had shifted over to one side. With that clue, engineers looked over their telemetry data again and reasoned that counterweights began to run against the cable when the antenna was turned into certain positions. ``We were faced with a problem that involved quite intricate geometry,'' said David Skillman, an engineer at NASA's Goddard Space Flight Center. He drove to a toy store and bought two boxes of a well-known construction set. In another store he got an extension cord, knife, masking tape and glue. He and engineer John Decker assewmbled the model in 15 minutes. ``This is how we determined if it was the cable that was the problem,'' Skillman said. ``Sure enough, when we set the models to angles on our computer screen, we could see the interference in the antenna parts and cable.'' NASA has plenty of models of the telescope, but they are big, fragile and unsuitable for that kind of demonstration, said NASA spokeswoman Janet Ruff. ``We determined that there was a proper motion that we should carry this antenna through to bring it carefully away, in the right direction so it wouldn't upset the control system,'' Olivier said. ``We successfully did that and we are all relieved to know that our theories were correct.'' The antennas, shaped like a dish, are at the end of masts and the cable is coiled along the length, terminating in the loop. One motor causes them to look up and down, 90 degrees in each direction. The other _ the one that had problems _ looks left and right. The antennas send their signal to one of two Tracking and Data Relay Satellites orbiting Earth and store their information on tape recorders when they are not in communication with the satellites. Because of that, said Olivier, the slight limits on the antenna's movement to avoid contact with the cable will have only a small impact. The first test image from the telescope had been expected by Tuesday but now is delayed until the weekend, Harrington said. The telescope, named after the famed astronomer Edwin Hubble, was carried into space by space shuttle Discovery and released into a 381-mile high orbit last Wednesday. Its mission is to look back in time for some 14 billion years, when the universe was young. Meanwhile, NASA said Discovery, which landed on Sunday at Edwards Air Force Base, sustained only minimal damage to its heat-protecting tiles. It is scheduled to be returned to the Kennedy Space Center at the end of the week.

DOC.HEAD: Researchers: Early Egyptian Women Forged Fidelity From Finances
DOC.TEXT: Women loaning men money is commonplace nowadays, but in first-century Egypt that meant marriage. University of Michigan researchers recently deciphered documents suggesting women in ancient Egypt made short-term loans to their prospective mates to guarantee their fidelity before and during marriage. The 22 documents deciphered by classical studies Professor Ludwig Koenen and two assistants recorded the business and legal transactions of the Pausiris family. The family lived about 70 A.D. in Oxyrhynchos, then a major city under Roman rule. The documents include several loan receipts made out to Dioskous Pausiris by Thermouthis, his wife of one year. Thermouthis probably came from a lower-middle-class family and couldn't afford a dowry to secure a marriage contract, Koenen said. Such women instead obtained financial security by loaning their fiances small amounts of money, he said. Researchers at the Ann Arbor school deciphered evidence that Thermouthis loaned a small amount to Dioskous for two months shortly before they married. Although none of the documents described the couple's personal relationship, one _ a canceled loan receipt, dated about a year after the marriage _ indicates Dioskous repaid a second, larger loan, then got a divorce. ``Where did he get the money? Perhaps he had a good business year, but a cynic would suspect that he had found another lady who would give him a loan,'' Koenen speculated. The researchers' findings will be published this summer, the university said.

DOC.HEAD: West German Leaders Offer Assurances to Soviets on German Unification
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 5 grafs to UPDATE with statement that foriegn ministers will discuss Polish border as first item in formal talks. Pickup pvs 5th graf, `Genscher told...' Edits to Trim
DOC.TEXT: West German leaders attempted Monday to overcome Kremlin opposition to a united Germany belonging to NATO as preparations got under way for historic unification talks. Experts from the two Germanys and the four victorious World War II powers held closed-door procedural talks in East Berlin to prepare for the formal ``two-plus-four'' negotiations at the foreign ministers' level in Bonn. After six hours of talks, they issued a joint statement saying that Poland's borders would be the first item discussed when the foreign ministers from the six nations hold their first formal talks on May 5 in Bonn. Poland is demanding guarantees that a united Germany will not seek to reclaim former German lands ceded to Poland after World War II. In a meeting Monday, West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher assured Victor Karpov, the Soviet deputy foreign minister, that Bonn would not overlook Moscow's ``justified security interests.'' Genscher told the Soviet official that German unification would represent the ``solution of a serious European problem (the division of Europe), and not the creation of a new one.'' In an effort to make some headway before Saturday's ``two-plus-four'' talks, the West German government announced that Genscher would hold separate meetings Friday with Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze and U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Baker will also meet Friday with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, said West German government spokesman Dieter Vogel. Kohl indicated that West Germany was prepared to offer economic and other incentives to the Soviet Union to overcome reservations about German unification within NATO. Kohl, in a statement read by Vogel, said he is ``certain that we will come to a reasonable agreement, also with the Soviet Union'' on the matter of a united Germany's strategic allegiances. Kohl added that West Germany is ``ready for comprehensive cooperation with the Soviet Union in the areas of economy, technological exchanges, athletic meetings ... and cooperation in security questions.'' Kohl's statement did not elaborate. West Germany is the Soviet Union's largest trading partner in the West. In Bonn, East and West German negotiators tried to wrap up their own talks on merging the economies of the two countries by July 2. East Germany is pressing West Germany to sweeten its proposed terms for economic union, but the West Germans have indicated their unwillingness to make further concessions. Despite the differences, Vogel told reporters the two Germanys still intend to forge a basic economic agreement by Friday. On Saturday, foreign ministers from East and West Germany and the Soviet Union, France and Britain as well as Baker are to meet in Bonn to try to iron out the thorny strategic problems raised by German unification. Mikhail S. Gorbachev reiterated the Soviet Union's opposition to a united Germany's membership in NATO during a meeting Sunday in Moscow with East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere. The Soviet Union is concerned that a unified Germany within NATO would upset the current European balance of power to Moscow's disadvantage. Shevardnadze has signaled that Moscow was prepared to drop its demand for a neutral unified Germany. He said the Soviet Union is open to proposals for new European security structures, including a proposal that a united Germany belong to both NATO and the Warsaw Pact. West Germany and its NATO allies have insisted that a united Germany must remain in the Western alliance. De Maizere was quoted in the East German Communist Party newspaper Neues Deutschland on Monday as saying East Germany should act as a mediator between the Soviet Union and the West on German unification. East Germany has said it is willing to go along with temporary NATO membership if the alliance undergoes fundamental changes reflecting the East-West thaw by emphasizing political and economic issues over its military role.

DOC.HEAD: Protesters Scale Building to Protest Chlorine Use in Paper
With AM-Dioxin-Paper
DOC.TEXT: Two Greenpeace activists climbed 150 feet up the Georgia-Pacific building on Monday and unfurled a banner to protest the company's use of chlorine in the manufacture of paper pulp. A 30-by-12 foot banner reading ``Take the Poison out of Pulp'' was unfurled after the climbers reached the 13th floor of the 52-story building about 8:30 a.m. The building was chosen because Atlanta-based Georgia-Pacific is the largest pulp operator in the nation, a Greenpeace spokesman said. About 200 passers-by stopped to watch the five-hour protest, which coincided with the release in Washington of an Environmental Protection Agency report on dioxins found in bleached paper. The EPA said the amount of dioxin in such items as milk cartons and toilet tissue is too small to pose a health hazard, but the agency is concerned about dioxin contamination of waterways near some paper mills. ``The issue is not dioxin, but chlorine. It is an unnecessary raw material in paper production,'' said Greenpeace spokesman Brian Hunt. ``Several European nations have already made the conversion to non-chlorine bleaching processes that yield high-quality, high-whiteness paper. We're here to encourage Georgia-Pacific to take the chlorine out of pulp,'' he said. Beth Zoffmann, a Georgia-Pacific spokeswoman, said chlorine produces only a minute quantity of dioxin and added, ``We believe our products are safe.'' Pointing up at the two protesters, she said, ``This creates a far greater risk than the entire production of dioxin in pulp. They are creating an unnecessary risk to themselves and the people on the ground. There is no need for that showmanship type activity.'' Police arrested the pair, identified by Greenpeace as D.J. LaChappelle, 24 of Washington, D.C., and Laurel Greenberg, 31, of Boston, after they descended. Police said they would be charged with criminal trespass and reckless conduct, but no charges were filed immediately.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 4: ``Vice President,'' and 18-19: ``Rep. Les,'' with Quayle, Aspin comments
DOC.HEAD: Baker Challenges Shamir Anew
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III on Monday accused Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir of missing an important opportunity to move peace forward and scuttling Shamir's own plan for talks with Palestinian Arabs. Baker leveled the criticism through his spokeswoman, Margaret D. Tutwiler, as U.S.-Israeli differences over the failure to set up Mideast negotiations deepened. Even so, the department spokeswoman said she assumed ``we will pick up where we left off'' after Israel forms a new government under Shamir or another Israeli leader. Vice President Dan Quayle also pledged U.S. perseverance. ``We must and we will continue the Arab-Israeli peace process,'' he said at a seminar on the superpowers' role in the Mideast. The Baker-Shamir rift broke into the open after the Israeli government collapsed last month in disagreement over a U.S. formula for holding talks with Palestinians. Shamir had proposed last May to hold elections among Palestinians on the West Bank and in Gaza. The formula the prime minister refused to endorse had been worked out by Baker over months of negotiations with Israel, Egypt and, indirectly, the Palestine Liberation Organization. Specifically, Shamir objected to having Palestinians who were ousted from the West Bank or who resided in East Jerusalem in the delegation. He is determined to have Israel retain the territory that Jordan held from 1948 until its defeat in the 1967 Six-Day war. On Sunday, the prime minister said ``no one can expect us to accept every proposal and every idea of the American secretary, be what they may be.'' Shamir also vowed to continue settling Jews on the West Bank and in Gaza, which Egypt occupied until 1967. The Bush administration has objected, saying the settlements are an obstacle to peace. ``We're perplexed by the prime minister's statement,'' Baker's spokeswoman said. ``We've been working so closely with the government of Israel on the peace process,'' Ms. Tutwiler said, reading from a prepared statement. She said the Israeli government had asked the Bush administration ``to find a Palestinian partner from the territories'' to help implement Shamir's elections initiative. ``We were on the verge of accomplishing that objective,'' Ms. Tutwiler said. ``In fact, we felt we were close to producing Palestinians from the territories who were prepared to talk to Israel about the elections in the territories.'' Baker's formula ``would have enabled us to do this,'' the spokeswoman said. ``So saying yes ... meant saying yes to the government of Israel's plan, yes to Israeli-Palestinian dialogue and yes to peace.'' On the other hand, Ms. Tutwiler added: ``Continuing to say no will give us very little to work with and will probably mean losing an important opportunity to move peace forward.'' Shamir is in the midst of trying to form a new government. It is likely to be as hard-line as the fallen coalition with the dovish Labor party. Still, Ms. Tutwiler said, ``We hope once the political situation in Israel clarifies we can work with the government of Israel to move ahead.'' Rep. Les Aspin, D-Wis., chairman of the House Armed Services Committee, characterized the rift as one between the Shamir and Bush administration rather than a conflict between Israel and the United States. The Bush administration has adopted a policy of ``trying to crowd'' the Likud government, he said. If Peres were to form a government, Aspin told the Mideast seminar, the U.S. ``rhetoric'' would stop. Meanwhile, Richard N. Haass, director of Middle East affairs at the National Security Council, said Israel's internal political problems ``raise a question about the government's willingness to go along'' with the Shamir election initiative. ``But leaving it alone is not the answer,'' Haass said at an academic seminar. Haass said the administration would press on with its attempt to bring Israelis and Palestinians to the negotiating table because the passage of time without any solution works against moderate forces in the region.

DOC.HEAD: Federal Judge to Determine if State Can Punish Amtrak
DOC.TEXT: Amtrak would have to suspend passenger rail service to Florida if a judge rules that it must quit dumping sewage from moving trains, Amtrak's president testified Monday. W. Graham Claytor Jr., Amtrak's president and chief operating officer, was the first witness as three days of hearings began before U.S. District Judge Howell W. Melton. Melton is to decide if the national railroad can be prosecuted for dumping waste in northern Florida waterways. Amtrak appealed to federal court after a state jury found Amtrak guilty in early December of four felony counts of commercial littering into the St. Johns River and Rice Creek. Amtrak cars now serving Florida either drop waste directly on the track or put it into a holding tank which is dumped when the train reaches a speed of 25 mph, Claytor said. With the present equipment owned by Amtrak, Claytor said it would be impossible for it to continue service into Florida if Melton rules in favor of the state. ``There is no way to comply,'' he said. He testified the railroad is studying ways to modify existing cars and plans to equip new cars so sewage won't be dumped on the tracks. But that's a long-term solution which will require Congress to appropriate money and would not address the short-term problem of cars dumping waste, Claytor said. ``In today's environment, it is better not to do it at all, and we agree and we are working on it,'' he said. Assistant State Attorney Dennis Bayer said in his opening arguments that the issue is whether federal law pre-empts state law and ``whether Amtrak can continue to indiscriminately dump raw human sewage into Florida's waterways.'' ``This court should deny Amtrak's efforts to derail the state criminal prosecution and allow Florida's courts to interpret laws designed to protect the waters of the state and the citizens who use the waters,'' Bayer said in his trial brief. Edward Booth, an attorney representing Amtrak, said Amtrak is not subject to Florida's laws prohibiting the disposal of waste from trains. He argued that allowing the state to enforce its laws would interfere with interstate commerce. Melton blocked a Jan. 18 criminal sentencing of the railroad pending the outcome of this hearing. If Melton rules that state law applies to Amtrak, the railroad could be subject to about $20,000 in fines.

DOC.HEAD: Heavy Snow in Colorado; Light Rain in East
DOC.TEXT: Heavy snow fell in Colorado and winter-like weather gripped parts of the West and northern Plains on Monday. Light rain and drizzle dampened much of the East Coast. Strong gusts of wind whipped parts of California and Arizona, and light snow fell across the Sierra Nevada. Snow also fell across parts of North Dakota and northern Minnesota. A gale warning was in effect for the northern California coastline, and high winds swept the southwest corner of the Sacramento Valley. There were wind gusts up to 49 mph at Travis Air Force Base. The National Weather Service also predicted high winds in southeastern Arizona. A flood warning remained in effect along the Red River in Texas and lowland flooding continued in eastern Arkansas after heavy rains last week. Waters were expected to fall below flood stage in northwest and western Missouri beginning Monday, and rivers were forcast to crest later in the week in Tennessee. In Colorado, a wet spring snowstorm dumped up to 18 inches at Rye and almost 17 inches at Pueblo overnight Sunday. At least one person was killed in the storm that brought much-needed precipitation to the state. The body of Pearl Sutliffe, 58, was found buried in snow early Monday in Fairplay after she disappeared while trying to round up livestock with her husband late Sunday, according to the Park County Sheriff's Department. A low-pressure system over California was responsible for heavy winds in Arizona, and was expected to spread snow into New Mexico on Tuesday. Heavy snow was possible for higher elevations, where a winter storm watch was posted. Showers and a few thunderstorms developed Monday along a warm front curving through Kentucky, Tennessee and North Carolina. Light rain and drizzle dampened the East Coast from northern Virginia into New England. Dry weather prevailed across the rest of the nation in the early afternoon, and abundant sunshine brightened the Northwest. Winter-like weather swept into the northern Plains and upper and middle Mississippi Valley, as temperatures were only in the 30s and 40s. Strong and blustery northwest winds howled across the region. Strong southerly winds prevailing just ahead of a cold front crossed the upper Great Lakes region and kept temperatures in the 60s and 70s. Cool weather prevailed across the West. Temperatures varied from the 30s in the northern Rockies to the 70s in the southwestern deserts. The low on Monday for the Lower 48 was 12 degrees at Laramie, Wyo.

DOC.HEAD: Radicals Slam Call for Direct Talks With U.S.
With AM-Hostages, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Iran's anti-Western radicals have criticized suggestions that Tehran consider opening direct talks with Washington, the official Islamic Republic News Agency reported Monday. The agency, monitored in Nicosia, quoted Tehran's Kayhan daily as saying in an editorial Sunday that any move toward dialogue with the United States deviated from the teachings of Iran's late revolutionary leader, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini, who died of cancer June 3. The comments followed the April 22 release of U.S. hostage Robert Polhill, but came before Monday's freeing of hostage Frank Herbert Reed. Both had been held by an Iranian-backed Shiite faction in Lebanon. The editorial was commenting on a suggestion Vice President Ataollah Mohajerani, in an article published in Tehren's Etelaat daily Thursday, that proposals for direct U.S.-Iranian talks should be considered by the Tehran government. President Hashemi Rafsanjani, leader of Iran's so-called pragmatists, is seeking to end Iran's isolation and improve links with the West and the media broadside underlined the opposition he faces from Tehran radicals. Rafsanjani has been seeking to secure the release of Western hostages held by pro-Iranian Shiite Moslem militants in Lebanon. Polhill's release, the first freeing of a U.S. hostage in Lebanon in more than three years, was seen as a victory for Rafsanjani and a first step toward breaking the deadlock in U.S.-Iranian relations. Veteran analyst Charles Snow wrote in Monday's edition of the respected Middle East Economic Survey: ``The release of Mr. Polhill is unmistakably a conciliatory gesture which should be rewarded both for its own sake, unless the U.S. actually wishes to play into the hands of the radicals in Tehran, and in order to encourage the Iranians to do more of the same. ``The problem is, however, that Mr. Bush has also inherited an iron-clad commitment not to trade for hostages, or at least not to appear to do so, and must therefore try somehow to differentiate between a reciprocal gesture ... and a quid pro quo. ``So far, Mr. Bush has responded with the standard litany, saying ... `I don't trade for hostages','' Snow wrote. The Tehran Times, an English-language daily associated with Rafsanjani, Sunday had quoted an unidentified Iranian official as saying there had been ``extensive talks'' between Tehran and the kidnappers. Kayhan warned any dialogue with the United States will mean ``burying'' the achievements of Khomeini's 1979 Islamic revolution that toppled the pro-Western shah and a major retreat. It said Mohajerani's suggestion amounted to urging Tehran to stop ``fighting against the arrogance,'' the word Iranians use to describe the United States and its allies, and to bow down to the Americans and the West. Re-establishing ties with the United States would signal ``accepting the rule of opponents of (Khomeini's) divine rule and destroy the revolution,'' Kayhan declared. The radical Jomhuri Islami daily also lashed out at Mohajerani's ``deviation,'' IRNA reported. The leader of Iran's radicals, former interior minister Ali AKbar Mohtashemi, wrote in a Kayhan commentary that Mohajerani's article was ``begging for mercy from the Great Satan,'' a term some Iranians use for the United States. Mohtashemi, who was elected to Parliament in December and has sought to mobilize opposition to Rafsanjani, said the vice president's article was ``irresponsible'' and advocated the ``death of the Islamic revolution.'' The former minister, who helped organize Shiite militants in Lebanon in the early 1980s, cited ``U.S. crimes ... and plots to overthrow the Islamic republic'' as proof of U.S. hostility.

DOC.HEAD: Robot Driven By Students Explores 1812-Era Wrecks
DOC.TEXT: The crew that discovered the wreck of the Titanic used a robot diver Monday to explore a War of 1812-era wreck in Lake Ontario _ and shared the expedition with children across North America. The camera-equipped robot examined the Hamilton, a merchant schooner that the British pressed into service as a warship. Students at 14 spots in the United States and Canada watched satellite TV transmissions. A few students even got to try steering the robot through a satellite link, using joysticks like those used with computer games. It transmitted pictures to students watching through satellite hookups at 14 locations in the United States and Canada. Cannons, railings and the ship's elegantly carved figurehead could be seen in the television transmission. Robert D. Ballard, the expedition's leader, said the ship's state of preservation was remarkable. ``We can see the caulking in the planks,'' he said. The Hamilton and its sister ship, the Scourge, sank during a storm on Aug. 8, 1813, killing 53 sailors. They had taken part in several battles for the British against U.S. forces that invaded southern Canada during the war. The wrecks remained undisturbed in 300 feet of water six miles off St. Catharines, about 30 miles south of Toronto and less than 10 miles west of the U.S. border at Niagara Falls, until their discovery in 1975. Since then, there have been several attempts to examine the wrecks, including one by French explorer Jacques Cousteau. But none were technologically advanced enough to reach them. The cold, fresh water helped keep the ships in much better condition than most wrecks, said Shelley Lauzon, a project spokeswoman. ``The wood on the Titanic is all gone because there are wood-boring animals in salt water,'' Lauzon said. ``They're not present here.'' Ballard, director of the Center for Marine Exploration at the Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution in Massachusetts, led the 1985 expedition that discovered the wreck of the Titanic. The ocean liner sank in the North Atlantic after ramming an iceberg in 1912. Ballard said Monday's examination of the Hamilton and the Scourge was aimed more at teaching children about archaeology and oceanography than at making startling new discoveries about the two warships. ``We've had four students actually take control and operate the vehicle beautifully,'' he said in an interview by ship-to-shore telephone. ``That was the biggest technological feat.'' The children controlled the robot with a joystick linked to the system by satellite, Lauzon said. A computer program restricted the robot's movements so the children could not damage it. Although there were no archaeological breakthroughs, the expedition did reveal a number of details not known before, Ballard said. The two-week expedition will prepare a comprehensive diagram of both ships and could provide information allowing the city of Hamilton, which has title to the wrecks, to decide whether they are worth raising. Ballard said there appeared to be little damage that would stand in the way of such an effort. ``There's no suggestion that they suffered any damage due to the sinking itself,'' he said. ``They just got flooded and went down very gently.'' The museums taking part in the program were in Boston; Chicago; Dallas; Detroit; Memphis, Tenn.; Minneapolis; Rochester, N.Y.; Salt Lake City; Sarasota, Fla.; Toronto; Victoria, British Columbia; Washington; and Woods Hole.

DOC.HEAD: Opposition Parties Threaten to Boycott Elections
LaserPhoto XBUC1
DOC.TEXT: Five major opposition parties on Monday threatened to boycott national elections and accused the dominant National Salvation Front of harassing opposition activists. A joint communique by the opposition groups was released as thousands of protesters rallied in central Bucharest for the ninth consecutive day to demand the resignation of interim President Ion Iliescu, whom they accused of monopolizing power and favoring Communism. The statement warned, ``If the government does not take measures to ensure democratic elections, our parties will be forced not to participate in such rigged elections.'' ``Our parties' activists have been violently attacked ... Our newspapers and magazines do not reach their destinations,'' the statement charged. ``The National Salvation Front, meanwhile, enjoys the administrative, financial and technical means of the old ruling structure,'' it said. The National Salvation Front took power after a December revolution that toppled Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. The Front continues to dominate an interim governing coalition and Parliament. The statement was signed by the National Peasants' Party, the National Liberal Party, the Social Democratic Party, the Free Democratic Party and the Socialist Liberal Party. On Friday, Iliescu rejected demands to postpone elections, scheduled for May 20, insisting that ``we have been living in a provisional state for long enough.'' Iliescu, a former Communist official who became a critic of Ceausescu in recent years, called the accusation that he is a neo-Communist ``an electoral maneuver.'' He said he has had to persuade his supporters not to ``go over to the square like a bulldozer, and wipe out'' the demonstration. On Monday, 4,000 protesters crowded in University Square, now filled with makeshift tents and sleeping bags, as their protest entered its ninth day. Stelian Tanase, a leader of the Group for Social Dialogue, a regular speaker at the demonstration, accused Iliescu of ``offering us Communism in a sweet box.'' ``We want sweeping changes, not perestroika,'' boomed the bearded Tanase, as the crowd roared its approval. Each night the protest has been capped with a rousing rendition of what has become the demonstrators' anti-government anthem: ``Better a tramp than traitor, Better a hooligan, than a dictator, Better a ruffian than an (Communist Party) activist, Better dead than a Communist.''

DOC.HEAD: Air Force Plane with 10 Aboard Crashes on Scottish Isle
DOC.TEXT: A Royal Air Force plane with 10 people aboard crashed into a hillside on a Scottish island Monday, the coast guard said. No survivors were reported found. An RAF spokesman said he could not confirm the number killed until all next of kin had been contacted. Rescuers said bodies were scattered over the hillside on South Harris in the Hebrides island chain off the northwest coast of Scotland. They did not report finding anyone alive. ``There was nothing we could do when we arrived,'' said Stornoway fire officer John Norman Macdonald. ``It was all over before anyone could get to the scene.'' A yellow Sea King helicopter winched bodies aboard Monday night to fly them to Stornoway, the chief town of the islands, where the initial accident inquiry is to begin Tuesday. The Shackleton aircraft took off on an exercise from Lossiemouth, on the northern Scottish mainland, said the coast guard in Stornoway, the Hebrides capital. Tony Arden, the Stornaway coast guard duty officer, said three rescue helicopters and fire engines raced to the scene at Maordal, a hill near the village of Northton. He said there was a fire in the wreckage but it burned out on its own. A witness, builder Kenny Mackay, said the wreckage was spread over about 1{ miles. ``I heard the plane going over the village very low and then there was a thundery noise ... You could feel a tremor shaking your feet but we couldn't see anything because the hill was covered in thick fog,'' he said. ``We went up to the hill and all we could see was burned heather and bits of plane all over the place.'' The Shackleton, a version of the wartime Lancaster bomber, is used for long-range maritime patrols, and is part of Britain's airborne early warning system.

DOC.HEAD: Plastics Plant Fire Forces Evacuations
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Rewrites throughout to update with fire smoldering, evacuees allowed to return, not all nursing home residents left, comment from plant manager; delete redundant material.
DOC.TEXT: Toxic smoke from a fire at a plastics plant kept firefighters at bay for several hours Monday and forced the evacuation of at least 2,000 people, including nearly 150 nursing home patients, authorities said. The fire at the Life-Like Products Inc. plant was still smoldering at late afternoon, but air samples tested by Spiltech Inc. of Little Rock found conditions were safe, said Franklin County Sheriff Gordon McCain. He said people were told they could return home at about 2 p.m. No injuries were reported. The fire was reported about 6:45 a.m. Firefighters began dousing the fire but had to pull back after about 45 minutes, when their air tanks ran out, state police spokesman Mack Hayden said. A team with air equipment from Fort Chaffee arrived later in the morning, he said. Until then, emergency officials had to watch the fire from a makeshift headquarters on a hill about a quarter mile from the blaze. The cause of the fire was not yet known, McCain said. He said damage caused by the fire, which destroyed the plant, probably will run into the millions of dollars. The entire west side of the town of about 4,000 was evacuated, said Gary Talley of the Office of Emergency Services. That included about 1,400 public school students and 350 students at the Arkansas Valley Vocational Technical School. Authorities said most of the 155 residents of the Ozark Nursing Home and more than 50 patients at Mountain View Lodge, a private center for mentally handicapped people, were taken to a school gymnasium about five miles from town. Other evacuees were taken to churches, officials said. McCain said about a dozen bed-bound nursing home residents were not moved. Plant manager Gary Key said the plant made polystyrene packaging materials. He said some of those products are made using pentane gas, the flammable material that most concerned emergency workers Monday. ``This stuff is not real toxic,'' said McCain. ``At first they thought it was,'' he said. ``What happened is, the records of what to do in case of fire were in (the plant) and they burned up. They ended up not knowing what to do.'' The Ozark Fire Department and a hazardous materials team from Fort Chaffee entered the remains of the gutted plant in the afternoon afternoon wearing air masks, said Hayden. They erected a dike to stop any toxic material from running out of the 52,000-square-foot plant and into nearby Gar Creek, officials said. Key said 33 people work at the 52,000-square-foot factory.

DOC.HEAD: Vice President to Visit Europe
DOC.TEXT: Vice President Dan Quayle will visit Italy, Great Britain and France on May 6-9 as he leads a delgation celebrating the Eisenhower Centennial in Europe, his office announced Monday. Quayle will meet with the top leaders of the three countries, address an Eisenhower tribute at the Italian Parliment and visit the European Space Agency headquarters in Paris.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Says He Will Try to Form Rightist Government
DOC.TEXT: Caretaker Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said Monday he will seek a narrow center-right coalition as he attempts to form Israel's next government and will not ask the left-leaning Labor Party to join. In the past, Shamir, head of the right-wing Likud bloc, has advocated a ``national unity government'' with Labor, mainly because such a broad coalition reduced the leverage of small ultra-rightist and religious parties. Also Monday, Israel's 42nd Independence Day, leaders of a growing electoral reform campaign met with President Chaim Herzog and presented him with 501,000 signatures of Israelis backing the drive. Israel has a population of 4.6 million. The meeting came after Herzog issued a strong call for electoral reform and said Israeli politicians have shown ``total contempt for the principles of democracy'' in their quest to rule. In parks, forests and on Mediterranean beaches, millions of Israelis celeberated Independence Day with picnics and barbecues. Police reported massive traffic jams, and Israel radio said recreation sites were filled. This year's Independence Day found the country plagued by political divisions and unable to form a strong government since the March 15 collapse of a Likud-Labor coalition. Labor leader Shimon Peres failed last week to form a governing coalition, and Herzog on Friday asked Shamir to try. ``Under the current conditions, I don't see a chance to form a government with Labor,'' Shamir told Israel radio in an interview broadcast Monday. ``I'm certain that a rightist government headed by me, even if it is a minority government, will have more success in advancing peace than a government that includes leftist factions that openly advocate the establishment of a Palestinian state,'' Shamir said. Shamir and his right-wing allies reject proposals by Secretary of State James A. Baker III that would provide the framework for preliminary Israeli-Palestinian peace talks in Cairo. Shamir says he fears the talks could lead to indirect Palestine Liberation Organization participation in negotiations. Under Baker's plan, the two sides would discuss Shamir's proposal to hold elections in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip. Those elected would negotiate the final status of the occupied lands with Israel. On Monday, State Department spokeswoman Margaret Tutwiler told reporters that the U.S. government was ``perplexed'' by Shamir's rejection of Baker's efforts. ``Continuing to say no will give us very little to work with and will probably mean losing an important opportunity to move peace forward,'' she said. Shamir currently has the backing of 61 members in the 120-member Parliament. Labor Party legislator Ephraim Gur told Israel Television on Monday night that he might move over to the Likud camp, broadening Shamir's support. Last month's defection and re-defection of several legislators lured by offers of political jobs from Labor and Likud has angered many Israelis and sparked an electoral reform campaign. Many Israelis want a change in the system of proportional representation to reduce the influence of small, religious parties. Several thousand demonstrators staged a protest rally in front of Parliament on Monday to push for a new political system. Herzog dedicated a major part of his traditional Independence Day speech Sunday night to the subject. ``How can citizens who have the democratic right to choose their representatives watch calmly the political phenomena revealing a total contempt for the principles of democracy,'' he said. ``I want to use this opportunity and appeal to the political leaders ... not to ignore the voice of the people,'' Herzog said. The president did not specify what system he favored, and warned that reform ``is not a wonder drug that will remove all the troubles from our public life.''

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING to fix numbering in header
Berlin Police in East and West Prepare for May Day Riots
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of extra police were deployed Monday in both Berlins ahead of feared May Day riots, as the city prepared for its first joint celebration of the holiday since the Berlin Wall came down. Union organizers said they expect up to 50,000 people from both sides of the city to attend the festivities Tuesday. Police forces in East Berlin and West Berlin will each have 3,000 extra officers on the job, and West Berlin police said they will be prepared with water cannons and tear gas. The main May Day event will be a celebration in front of the former Reichstag, or parliament building, in West Berlin. For the last three years, May 1, the international workers holiday, has been marked by clashes between the city police and youth gangs, foreigners and extremists. Last year some 2,000 rioters ramapged through the streets of West Berlin, smashing windows and cars and looting grocery stores and other businesses. More than 300 police officers, demonstrators and passers-by were injured. Last week, hundreds of right-wing ``skinheads'' and leftist extremists rampaged in East Berlin and police fear that troublemakers from both sides of the city will join forces Tuesday. ``We'll do our best to see that violent people don't cross the border,'' West Berlin police spokesman Gernot Piestert told The Associated Press. ``We'll search anyone who looks suspicious.'' Skinheads and youths in black leather will be special targets, Piestert said. Skinhead is a popular term for right-wing extremist youths with close-shaven heads. Piestert said the police will, however, not close any of the more than 35 border checkpoints between East and West Berlin, which Germans can cross after presenting a valid passport. ``We're too happy about the borders being open to close them now,'' Piestert said. The Berlin Wall and the rest of East Germany's western border were opened in November 1989. For the first time police in both Berlins will cooperate to ensure security for the holiday. Three officers from each side will cross the border to provide smooth communication between the two countries' forces. Klaus Schattat, a police chief in East Berlin, warned: ``Everybody can rely on the fact that police in both halves of the city will work, together when necessary, against all forms of violence, vandalism and rowdyism.''

DOC.HEAD: Lava Flow from Kilauea Continues Unabated
DOC.TEXT: A 2,000-foot-wide river of lava from Kilauea Volcano destroyed another house Monday as it threatened to bury and burn the center of this coastal community. Kilauea, the world's most active volcano, was pumping all of its daily output of 650,000 cubic yards of molten rock into the Kalapana area on Hawaii Island, and authorities had little hope the community would survive. ``This is a massive glacier of lava, at least a quarter of a mile wide, at least 10 to 40 feet high behind the front of the flow,'' said Hawaii County Civil Defense Administrator Harry Kim. Kilauea has destroyed 120 homes since its latest eruption began Jan. 3, 1983, 44 of them in April. Lava was a quarter-mile from the Kalapana Store and Drive-In and two churches in the town center, which Kim said could be overrun by Tuesday at the earliest. Walter Yamaguchi, who built the store in 1974, said he was content to leave the fate of his business in the hands of God and the volcano goddess Pele. ``In fact, Madame Pele owns the whole place. So I believe in her and I believe in God,'' the 82-year-old man said. ``I leave it up to the good Lord whether I win. I leave it up to heaven.'' Parishioners made plans to move the historic Star of the Sea Church, which sits on an oceanfront lot in the direct path of the lava. A trucking company volunteered to move the church for free. Volunteers began removing the church's stained glass windows Friday. Robert Lippi, chief financial offer for the Roman Catholic Diocese in Honolulu, said church officials would wait until lava was certain to overrun the church before moving it. ``It looks pretty inevitable,'' he said. Leaders of Kalapana Mauna Kea Congregational Church, located across the street from Star of the Sea, said the church's structure was rotten from termites and not worth saving. They said some artifacts and a church bell made in the 1800s would be the only things salvaged.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 12th graf: ``Asked whether,'' with 4 grafs bgng: ``Bush met,'' with Polhill delivering kidnapper message
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, saying ``things seem to be moving,'' hailed the release Monday of a second American hostage in Lebanon but said there could be no rest ``until all hostages are free.'' ``I hope this is a forerunner to the release of the other American hostages and the others from other countries held against their will,'' Bush said. Bush spoke as he welcomed former hostage Robert Polhill to the White House. The meeting came just hours after another hostage, Frank Reed, was turned over in Beirut to Syrian officials after 43 months of captivity. The president pointedly thanked Iran and Syria for their efforts in winning the hostages' release. But he added that no one can expect a return to normal relations ``or expect vast improvement until all Americans are free.'' ``I hope there's a realization that holding people against their will is not the way to affect political change,'' Bush said. Asked if Israel ought to release a Shiite cleric, Sheik Abdul-Karim Obeid, and others as demanded by a Tehran newspaper as a next step, Bush said he would have ``no objections'' to such an action. ``That is a matter for others to determine,'' he added. The State Department, in its annual report on terrorism released Monday, criticized both Iran and Syria. Iran still uses terrorism in pursuit of foreign policy goals, and Syria continued to support a variety of terrorist groups, the report said. Polhill, accompanied by his wife Ferial, clasped Bush with both hands in a warm handshake. Speaking in a raspy whisper, Polhill said he could not provide any clues about the other six Americans still held hostage. ``You may be surprised, but I really don't know very much about what was going on around me,'' Polhill said. ``The only thing I can suggest is that the American people continue to show, as hostages continue to be released on a regular basis, how much we are wanted back.'' Bush met with Polhill for an hour in the executive mansion, accompanied by senior White House aides and the president's wife, Barbara. ``He described his life in captivity and gave his impressions of his captors, of the confusing situation in Beirut and of the hardship he suffered during 3{ years,'' said White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater. The president took Polhill aside at one point to receive a private message from his former kidnappers. Fitzwater said Bush refused to reveal the contents of the message publicly. ``Apparently Polhill told his captors he would deliver a message privately and personally to President Bush only,'' Fitzwater said. ``And that's what he did.'' Bush and Polhill also talked by telephone briefly with Reed in Damascus. Bush wished him well, and Polhill and Reed exchanged warm greetings, Fitzwater reported. Bush said the meeting with Polhill came ``at a very special moment'' because Reed had just been freed. The president said he expected to talk soon with Reed by telephone in Damascus, Syria, where he was taken. ``I do want to take this opportunity to thank Syria for its role in not only bringing Mr. Polhill home but its role in the Reed release, and similarly to Iran for its role,'' Bush said. Expressing hopes for release soon of the other hostages _ six Americans and 10 other Westerners _ Bush said, ``Things seem to be moving on this.'' ``I can't explain the rationale but I can express a certain gratitude that things seem to be moving. And what I feel in my heart about the return of now these two Americans is, in a sense, overwhelming.'' ``But I don't think any American can totally rejoice until the rest are free, and indeed we can't limit our concern and our feelings to just the Americans, in my view.'' Iran, meanwhile, said no more Americans would be released unless the United States reciprocated with a gesture in line with Bush's oft-stated promise that ``goodwill begets goodwill.'' ``Now the ball is in the court of the U.S. and the Western countries,'' said the English-language Tehran Times, considered close to President Hashemi Rafsanjani. Asked if he was ready to make a goodwill gesture in return for the hostages' release, Bush said all must be freed. ``We're not in a piecemeal basis, bidding for one human life, holding out hopes, only to have them dashed for one American family or another,'' he said. In a statement released earlier, after Reed's impending release was announced, Bush said, ``We urge all parties who either hold hostages or have any influence over the hostage takers to work for the expeditious and unconditional release of the remaining hostages.'' The White House said it had made no deals to win Reed's freedom but that Iran and Syria apparently were working to free the hostages in hopes of improving relations with Washington. ``This is a joyous day for Mr. Reed, his family, his friends and all Americans,'' Bush said in the written statement. However, in a reference to the others still held, he said, ``Their predicament weighs on our mind and tempers the joy we feel today.'' Privately, U.S. officials said a key element of Bush's statement was to applaud Iran for ``humanitarian'' action _ a description also used by Secretary of State James A. Baker III. The officials said Iran, after years of isolation from the West, was seeking recognition for positive deeds. Even before Reed was released by his captors, a State Department hostage reception team was dispatched to the U.S. hospital at Wiesbaden, West Germany, to provide care and conduct debriefings. Preparations began after a previously unknown group, the Organization of Islamic Dawn, said on Sunday it would free Reed within 48 hours.
