In Malden, Mass., an overjoyed Fifi Reed got the word from the State Department and said she would fly to Germany to be with her husband. Reed, director of the private Lebanon International School, had been seized Sept. 9, 1986. While asserting there had been ``no deals'' with the kidnappers, spokesman Fitzwater said, ``we've had a number of discussions ... with Syrian officials, with third countries who have relations or have contacts with Iran and people in Lebanon. ``We've had a lot of third party intermediary kinds of messages back and forth with Iran, but there's nothing we can point to in terms of any specific reasons for this release,'' Fitzwater said. The Americans still hostage in the Middle East include Terry Anderson, the chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press. The longest held, he has been captive for more than five years.

DOC.HEAD: Chamaorro Appeals For Support For Shaky Coalition
DOC.TEXT: President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro said Monday that Gen. Humberto Ortega will remain only temporarily as chief of the armed forces and that she would hold talks with Contra rebels who refuse to disarm. Many Contras balked at disarming after Mrs. Chamorro named Gen. Ortega, brother of former Sandinista president Daniel Ortega, as the armed forces chief. The move also drew criticism from many within the new president's 14-party coalition. The president's remarks, at her first news conference since taking office five days ago, were a clear attempt to ease tensions within the coalition. The transition of power from the leftist Sandinistas to Mrs. Chamorro's UNO coalition followed nine years of a U.S.-backed insurgency by the Contras, in which 30,000 people died. The inauguration of Mrs. Chamorro, a conservative elected in February, brought immediate resumption of U.S. aid and trade assistance. At her news conference, the president commented for the first time on austerity measures aimed at patching up the battered economy. Mrs. Chamorro said the Sandinistas had left only $3 million in the treasury and an $11 billion foreign debt. ``That is why it is urgent that we apply severe measures that will allow us in the short term to stabilize the currency and prices, to guarantee investment and the productive effort now that this year's agricultural cycle is starting,'' she said. Last week the cordoba, Nicaragua's currency, was devalued by half, sharply increasing prices and causing more hardship in an already poor country. At the news conference, Mrs. Chamorro said the powerful secret police force, which was run by the Sandinista Interior Ministry, would be abolished. But she did not elaborate. She also said a requirement that both Nicaraguans and foreigners obtain exit visas to leave the country would be ended. Mrs. Chamorro also referred to differences with her vice president, Virgilio Godoy, who is out of the country on an unexplained trip. He is engaged in bitter rivalry for influence and power with some of Mrs. Chamorro's close advisers. ``I trust that the vice president ... will accompany and support me with the total loyalty in the taking of the great decisions and in the fulfillment of the complex tasks with which the people of Nicaragua have entrusted us,'' she said. Mrs. Chamorro faces two May Day protest marches, one by a Sandinista labor union demanding 100 percent pay raises and the demobilization of Contras, and another by a bloc of four independent trade unions demanding Gen. Ortega be removed. ``I understand that in the case of the army, the people and the political sectors that helped me and support me would like a drastic and immediate change,'' she said. ``But we need to do things well, even if it means resuming temporary sacrifices to guarantee the tranquility and stability of the country.'' Contra military chief Israel Galeano is meeting with Mrs. Chamorro on Wednesday to discuss the rebels' position. The rebels had agreed to demobilize by June 10, but many have put off laying down their arms. Galeano has said he wants the Sandinista People's Army dismantled _ or, at the very least, the departure of Gen. Ortega and the top Sandinista military officers. The president said she had met several times with Gen. Ortega and had told him the job was temporary. He was being retained ``to ensure the unity and discipline of the army'' while the Contras disarm, she said. The Sandinistas say the army is protected by the Constitution and any attempt to radically change it could result in violence. While Mrs. Chamorro's United National Opposition coalition has a majority in the National Assembly, it does not have enough votes there to change the constitution.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Opens Higher in Tokyo
DOC.TEXT: The dollar opened at 159.09 yen on the Tokyo foreign exchange market Tuesday, up from Friday's close of 159.08 yen. The Tokyo market was closed Monday because of a national holiday.

DOC.HEAD: Third Day of Prison Disturbances in France
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with Nice, Douai disturbances. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: Protests broke out at French prisons Monday for the third day in a row, and the authorities said steps would be taken to reduce overcrowding and other problems. In the northern city of Douai, about 50 disgruntled inmates scaled a jailhouse roof Monday and brandished a skull-and-crossbones flag. Police fired tear gas, and the prisoners returned to their cells. A similar rooftop protest had occurred at the prison Sunday. In Nice, on the French Riviera, about 150 inmates protested overcrowding at their prison by refusing to return to their cells following an afternoon exercise period Monday. They ended the two-hour protest after presenting a list of demands to authorities. The protests followed two days of rioting by 500 inmates at the Loos-Les-Lille prison in this northern industrial city. Inmates burned a workshop and garage, sacked 175 cells and hurled roof tiles at police, causing an estimated $1.7 million in damage. No serious injuries were reported. Prison investigators questioned inmates Monday to determine who led the rioting. They promised to uphold negotiators' pledges that no general reprisals would be carried out. Pierre Arpaillange, the country's top prison official, blamed the riot on overcrowding at Loos-Les-Lilles, which was built for 550 prisoners but holds 1,000. The prison at Nice reportedly holds 900 inmates in a facility built for 280. Arpaillange told the RTL radio that new prisons for 13,000 inmates are to open by July. The rebellions were the first in French prisons this year, but there were at least 10 such revolts in 1989. A series of prison revolts in 1987 during an intense heat spell started at the Loos-Les-Lille and Douai facilities. Loos-Les-Lille is about 125 miles north of Paris and 25 miles from Douai. Officials said there is no overcrowding at Douai, where 540 inmates are housed in a facility with a capacity for 575. The demands of the Loos-Les-Lille inmates were never made clear, but officials said they centered on the slowness of the justice system and the parliamentary amnesty recently granted to a number of politicians in a fund-raising scandal. The Douai prisoners were demanding better recreational facilities.

DOC.HEAD: Former Colombian Guerrilla Replaces Slain Presidential Candidate
DOC.TEXT: A former guerrilla, left with one leg and slurred speech after an assassination attempt six years ago, gained the support of a leftist coalition Monday as replacement for a slain presidential candidate. Former field commander Antonio Navarro replaces Carlos Pizarro, his onetime guerrilla boss, on the May 27 ballot. Pizarro was assassinated last Thursday. The government is printing 16 million new ballots to replace those carrying Pizarro's name and photograph. Photos help illiterates identify candidates. The Democratic Alliance, a coalition of many of Colombia's leftists that claims to have the support of the nation's labor unions, will support Navarro. He is the new leader of the M-19 movement. Last month M-19 disbanded as a guerrilla organization and became a political party. Colombia's Communist Party refused to support Pizarro and does not support Navarro. The party is divided as a result of Communist loss of prestige and power througout the world. The secret police meanwhile said they could not verify the authenticity of a letter purported to be from Pablo Escobar, chief of the Medellin drug cartel, claiming that Escobar did not murder Pizarro, as suggested by national police. The letter said Escobar sheltered M-19 guerrillas in the past. The movement took its name from the date of the April 19, 1970 presidential elections that rebels said were rigged. Former president Misael Pastrana of the opposition Conservative Party urged President Virgilio Barco on Monday to resign before his four-year term ends Aug. 7. His remarks came in an interview published by the Bogota daily La Prensa and in a live broadcast interview with the radio chain RCN. Citing Pizarro's assassination, the third of a presidential candidate since last August, Pastrana said Barco ``has lost all authority.'' He said violence had overwhelmed state security forces and that Colombia could not afford to be led by a lame duck president for too long. Pastrana, president from 1974 to 1978, confirmed the pilot of an Avianca jet asked him to to leave the plane on Saturday because passengers were afraid to travel with a political leader, a potential target for assassins. Pastrana said he was out campaigning for Conservative presidential candidate Rodrigo Lloreda, but agreed to get off the jetliner with his bodyguards because he understood passengers' fears. On Friday, 100 passengers refused to board an Avianca plane in Barranquilla when it was learned that a leftist congressmen was going to be aboard with 25 bodyguards. Pizarro's shooting occurred on an Avianca airliner in flight.

DOC.HEAD: Iranian Resistance Leader Buried in Iraq
DOC.TEXT: Slain Iranian opposition leader Kazem Rajavi was buried in Iraq on Monday, and comrades who blamed Iran for his assassination called for revenge. ``Kazem's blood will not rest until the regime of the mullahs (clerics) is overthrown,'' Massoud Rajavi, Kazem's brother and leader of the Mujahedeen Khalq opposition group chanted in unison with scores of mourners. Kazem, 56, was killed by a burst of machine gun fire last week near his home in a suburb of Geneva, Switzerland. Police have made no arrests in connection with the slaying, but evidence has suggested a link with the Teheran government. Iranian officials have denied any connection with the murder. Kazem Rajavi was the chief lobbyist for the Baghdad-based Mujahedeen with the Council of Europe in Strasbourg and the numerous Geneva-based international organisations. His body was flown from Geneva to Baghdad on Sunday and brought to this holy city for burial the following day. Kazem's French-born wife, Michelle, and his two sons, Kayhan and Kamal, accompanied the body. Moslem Shiites, who form the vast majority of Iran's population, consider Karbala their holiest shrine after Mecca because the founder of their sect, Hussein is buried there. Hussein was one of the grandsons of Islam's Prophet Mohammed. Shiites believe anyone buried in Karbala is guaranteed a place in heaven. Speaking in French with tears in her eyes, Kazem's wife, Michelle, told mourners that her husband's mission ``is now completed and he has crossed the river of freedom for the sake of your country.'' She said Kazem must be happy that he was buried in Karbala, which she described as ``the land of revolution and paradise.'' The Mujadeen Khalq are the largest Iranian resistance group. The Mujahedeen were first allied with Iranian spiritual leader Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini in the struggle to topple the late Shah. But in 1980-81, a year after Khomeini took power, he turned on the group and other leftist factions, killing and imprisoning tens of thousands of people. The Mujahedeen and their military wing, the National Liberation Army, receive training and support from Iraq. The group is estimated to have 20,000 fighters.

DOC.HEAD: B.B. King Released from Las Vegas Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Blues legend B.B. King left a Las Vegas hospital Monday in good spirits and ``asking for his guitar'' after being hospitalized over the weekend because of a bout with high blood sugar. King, who had to cancel performances at the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival over the weekend, returned to his Las Vegas home for two weeks of recuperation, his manager said. Manager Sid Seidenberg said King, 64, was admitted Friday to Valley Hospital, where doctors were concerned about King's blood sugar level and suggested the hospitalization for further tests. He said the level is being monitered. Seidenberg said King had a ``diabetic attack,'' but his assistant, Tina Brincat, said he wasn't diagnosed as having diabetes. Hosptial officials refused to discuss the case. Diabetes is a condition in which the body is unable to properly process the sugar it needs to function. It results in high blood sugar. Seidenberg, speaking from his office in New York, said the bluesman was on the way to the airport Friday when he began to feel faint and dizzy. ``Something like this can happen to anybody,'' Seidenberg said. ``It's not anticipated it will hurt his career. ``He said he felt great on Saturday and by Sunday he was asking for his guitar,'' Seidenberg said. He said King would appear as scheduled May 13 to receive an honorary doctor's degree at Rhodes College in Memphis, where he began his career in the late 1940s. He also said King would return to his tour schedule May 18, and begin a monthlong European of 13 countries on June 21. King tours 270 days out of the year. King burst upon the music scene in 1948. His hits include ``You Don't Know Me'' in 1952 and ``The Thrill is Gone'' in 1970. He has won four Grammy awards.

DOC.HEAD: GOP Backs Away from Bush 1991 Budget
DOC.TEXT: House Republicans backed away from President Bush's 1991 budget on Monday, deciding to not force a House vote on what they now say is an outdated $1.2 trillion spending plan. Rep. Bill Frenzel, ranking Republican on the House Budget Committee, said he changed his mind about offering Bush's package after talking with GOP leaders. Republicans had planned to force the House to vote on the president's proposal during debate scheduled for Tuesday on a Democratic alternative, as they frequently have done in past years. The reversal seems to indicate that many Republicans would prefer to not have to vote for Bush's plan. ``There's a feeling among Republicans that the budget has been passed by by economic and political events,'' said Frenzel, R-Minn. ``To debate it is a waste of time. We have to do a real job based on the realities of the day.'' Since Bush offered his budget in January, the Warsaw Pact has deteriorated even further and the U.S. economy has seemed to hesitate. Bush's $303.7 billion defense proposal has been criticized by Democrats _ and some Republicans _ as unneccessarily high. The Democrats want to spend $295.4 billion. And even Bush's plan understates the amount of deficit reduction that will be needed to satisfy the Gramm-Rudman balanced-budget law. To meet that law's target of a maximum $64 billion shortfall next year, Darman has said that at least $45 billion in savings will be needed, rather than the $37 billion Bush has proposed. The Democratic plan also proposes $37 billion in spending cuts and new revenues. Republicans had always expected that the president's proposal would be a loser in the House, where Democrats prevail 258-176. But they had until now planned to offer it anyway. They saw it as a rallying point and as a GOP bargaining position in what they hope will be negotiations between the White House and congressional leaders. ``It is embarrassing,'' said Frenzel of the change of plans. But he added, ``I didn't want to go ahead against large numbers of people in our caucus,'' referring to House Republicans. White House spokesman Stephen Hart said he would not comment on the House GOP decision. Senate Republicans decided weeks ago to not offer Bush's plan as that chamber's budget panel tries to work out a 1991 spending package.

DOC.HEAD: Connecticut Enacts Abortion Bill
DOC.TEXT: Connecticut on Monday became the first state to give women the legal right to abortion in a law intended to stand even if the Supreme Court reverses its 1973 decision legalizing abortion. The Roe vs. Wade decision said states cannot ban abortions, but if the ruling were struck down, states would then be able to make abortion illegal. Without ceremony, Democratic Gov. William A. O'Neill, a Roman Catholic who personally opposes abortion, signed the bill into law Monday afternoon. It takes effect Oct. 1. The bill cleared the state Senate on Friday, 32-3, and the House the week before, 136-12. It repeals the state's unenforced criminal anti-abortion statutes, requires women under 16 to be counseled before getting an abortion and encourages them to tell their parents. In a variation on the Supreme Court's Roe vs. Wade ruling, the new law allows abortions late in pregnancy, when the fetus is capable of living outside the womb, only when the life or health of the mother is in danger. ``I believe this measure strikes a balance between a person's right to privacy and state interests,'' the governor said in a news release. ``It recognizes a right to choice by women. The law also recognizes the state has an interest in fetus viability and properly recognizes that minors should be counseled before making the very difficult decision to abort a pregnancy,'' O'Neill said. When the bill passed the House, Betty Gallo, a lobbyist for the Connecticut Coalition for Choice, called it ``the most aggressive, pro-choice piece of legislation since Webster.'' She referred to the Supreme Court's decision last summer in Webster vs. Reproductive Health Services, that gave states greater power to restrict abortions. Connecticut's anti-abortion laws were rendered unenforceable by Roe vs. Wade. They carried penalties of up to five years in prison and a $1,000 fine for anyone performing an abortion, and two years in prison and a $500 fine for women getting abortions, except to protect the life of the mother. State Rep. Nancy Wyman, one of several Democrats who crafted the bill, said O'Neill, with his personal opposition to abortion, made a difficult decision. ``I know that it's not truly with his conscience,'' said Wyman. ``He's doing something that is good for the women of Connecticut.'' Kate Michelman of the National Abortion Rights League said she could ``count on one hand'' the number of other states where similar legislation could pass. ``You have to have a pro-choice legislature and you have to have a governor who is pro-choice, who understands that women, not politicians, should make this decision,'' she said in a telephone interview from Washington. ``Today Gov. O'Neill has shown his utmost respect for the women of his state. He's shown that he trusts the women of his state to make their own personal and private decisions about abortion.'' New Hampshire Gov. Judd Gregg vetoed a similar bill earlier this year, describing it as too liberal. Meanwhile, the state's leading anti-abortion group, the Pro-Life Council of Connecticut, continued to describe the bill as a success because of its provisions on counseling and fetus viability. At a news conference, the group announced the formation of a team of pro-life lawyers that will work to ensure portions of the law are enforced, particularly the counseling of minor girls on options other than abortion. ``This whole thing for us has been a major breakthrough, because before, we had nothing,'' said Regina Smith, the executive director of the council. More strident anti-abortion activists were more critical of the bill. ``Pro-life not only didn't get anything, we are in a far worse position than we were before,'' said state Rep. Anthony Nania, a conservative who voted against the bill and has called for Smith's ouster. ``To say that there are new restrictions on abortion flies in the face of the facts.'' When the bill passed the House, Betty Gallo, a lobbyist for the Connecticut Coalition for Choice, called it ``the most aggressive, pro-choice piece of legislation since Webster.''

DOC.HEAD: Governor to Veto Court-Ordered School Reform Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: DELETES extraneous 15th and 19th grafs pvs.; SUBS 18th graf to tighten, minor editoring.
DOC.TEXT: Gov. Bill Clements said Monday he would veto a bill that would increase the state sales tax by half a cent and pay for a court-ordered school finance reform plan. That set off picketing by teachers at the governor's mansion. ``I think teachers are very angry and very upset and very frustrated,'' said John Cole, president of the Texas Federation of Teachers, whose group organized the march that drew about 300. The reform bill has loomed over the state's education system since the state Supreme Court ruled last year that financing of the $13.5 billion school system must change. The state comptroller threatened Monday to freeze state education spending at midnight. The Legislature is expected to send Clements the bill on Tuesday, the deadline set by the high court ruling. The measure would put a $555 million finance plan into effect. But Clements, who is retiring, is against increasing taxes and wants to re-allocate funds to pay for a less-expensive reform plan. A combination of state and federal aid and local property taxes now pay for state education. ``I am going to veto the bill just like I said I would,'' Clements said in Dallas. He said he would summon legislators Wednesday into a third special session on education to find a solution. The Republican governor was out of town when teachers gathered at his residence to protest the failure by him and the Democratic-controlled Legislature to reach agreement on how to pay for the reform. Clyde Hemminger, a sixth-grade social studies teacher from Fort Worth, shook the locked iron gates and said of Clements: ``He's obviously locked the doors to the mansion; we'd like to keep the doors to the schoolhouse open.'' Many of the signs brandished by the protesting teachers attacked Clements' veto promise. ``Hey Bill! Exercise your mind, not your pen,'' said one sign, a reference to the governor's remark earlier in the day that by marching the teachers ``will get a lot of good exercise.'' On Oct. 2, the court ruled the state's finance system was unfair to property-poor school districts and ordered the Legislature to overhaul the system. State officials will appear Tuesday before state District Judge Scott McCown, who is overseeing the case, to explain why no reforms were approved before the deadline. The expected veto has raised the ire of teachers, Cole said. ``They have been observing officials of the state of Texas treating education _ something that teachers feel very fervently about _ as though it were a political game and using the students and the school employees as pawns in that game. ... ``If students acted like this, we would be giving them Fs and sending notes home to their parents,'' he said. The high court has threatened to stop state aid if a reform plan does not go into effect by Tuesday. Comptroller Bob Bullock said he would freeze state education expenses, including nearly $2.7 million in salaries for more than 1,000 Texas Education Agency employees, unless the judge intercedes. ``At the stroke of midnight ... state funding for public education stops unless the governor has signed the bills passed by the Legislature,'' he said. But Clements, citing $400 million sent to schools last Wednesday in April state aid payments, said there was enough money to pay teachers. ``We don't really have a problem,'' Clements said. ``We have ample funds, and the funds are in hand to pay the teachers until, I believe, it's the last two days of the school year.'' The Texas Federation of Teachers and the Texas Classroom Teachers Association said they want McCown to allow the state to send school districts enough money to pay teachers. Failing that, they want teachers to be released from employment contracts in districts lacking enough local money to pay them. ``It wouldn't be a strike ... It would be like a lockout. We are not advocating a walkout at this point,'' Cole said. ``Strikes, walkouts, all those things damage children. They don't damage governors and legislators,'' said Jeri Stone, executive director of the union.

DOC.HEAD: 13 Moslem Extremists Killed, 6 Injured in Clashes with Police
DOC.TEXT: Thirteen Moslem extremists were killed and six injured Monday in clashes with police in a province that has been the scene of frequent unrest involving Islamic fundamentalists, security sources said. The sources said the clashes occurred at Kahk village in the southern province of Fayoum, 60 miles southwest of Cairo. The trouble apparently began when militants tried to block the arrests of three brothers suspected of killing their father. The security sources said the 60-year-old father, Aly Dakheil, was killed Sunday during an argument in which he was trying to persuade his sons to give up themselves to police. The brothers were already being sought in connection with unspecified unlawful activities, the sources said. Monday's casualties bring to 15 the number of Moslem fundamentalists shot dead in the area by police in the last week. Two were killed last week in a shootout with police, who were combing the area for suspects in a bomb attack on a Christian Coptic church in the village of Sanhour. That attack resulted in the death of a policeman and the injury of two other guards, and was the latest ina series of attacks on Coptic property. Fayoum is the home of Sheik Omar Abdel-Rahman, a blind preacher widely acknowledged as leader of the Moslem group Al-Gamaa Al-Islamiya. The group demands immediate implementation of Sharia, the 1,400-year-old Islamic rfeligious and ethical code. The militants have been active in recent weeks through a wide area of south Egypt in the provinces of Faryoum, Assiut and el-Minya. The unrest has included riots, clashes with police and arson attacks.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Reverses Himself; Las Vegas Data to be Confidential
DOC.TEXT: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh has reversed himself and will keep confidential financial data of a newspaper seeking approval of joint operations with a competitor in Nevada, a spokesman said Monday night. The attorney general signed an order reversing his decision of Feb. 16 requiring the Las Vegas Review-Journal to disclose circulation and advertising revenue, said spokesman David Runkel. The publisher of the newspaper, Donrey of Nevada Inc., an arm of closely held Donrey Media Group, had sought reconsideration of the February decision in a March 2 petition. Donrey argued that disclosure would damage relations with customers, suppliers and unions not only in Las Vegas but in the 73 other markets in 21 states in which Donrey operates. In a June agreement, the Review-Journal and the Las Vegas Sun said they planned to merge their business, circulation and production operations, keeping separate editorial departments, along the lines of joint operating agreements in force in 19 other cities. Such agreements are permitted if the attorney general finds that one newspaper is in danger of failing. In Las Vegas, both newspapers have said the Sun is in ``probable danger of financial failure.'' The data in question already have been submitted to the Justice Department.

DOC.HEAD: Turkish Experts Clear Tubes as No Part of Giant Iraqi Gun
DOC.TEXT: Arms experts in this province near the Bulgarian border determined Monday that steel tubes seized by customs officials were not part of a giant Iraqi weapon launcher, Turkish news agencies reported. Hurriyet news agency quoted Gov. Unal Erkan as saying three trucks carrying the tubes were allowed Monday to go to Iraq after being examined. Hurriyet quoted Erkan as saying experts from Trakya University in Edirne and Istanbul Tehcnical University concluded the cargo consisted of normal pipes. Three trailer trucks _ two Bulgarian and one Yugoslav _ were seized at Kapikule border gate last week. A fourth truck _ Hungarian _ carrying a steel tube 39 feet long was seized at Haydarpasa customs station in Istanbul after arriving aboard a ship from Romania on April 19, a customs official there confirmed. Turkish newspapers quoted authorities as saying that particular cargo resembled pipes seized in Britain on April 12. Anatolia news agency quoted Prime Minister Yildirim Akbulut as saying the steel tubes issue may come up during his official visit to Bagdad this week Customs officials in Britain seized eight steel tubes en route to Iraq. Trade Secretary Nicholas Ridley said Britain was convinced the tubes were part of a giant gun. Weapons experts say such a gun might be able to fire nuclear or chemical weapons long distances or boost rockets into orbit. Iraq says the tubes were meant for a petrochemical plant.

DOC.HEAD: Rebel Leader Stoned to Death Along with his Mother and Sister
DOC.TEXT: Peasants in an Andean mountain village stoned to death a local leader of a Shining Path guerrilla group along with his mother and sister, police said Monday. Police said almost 200 peasants attacked Similiano Chavez Yanac and his sister, Vitaliana, as they were visiting their 65-year-old mother, Alberta, in the town of Huamarin, 180 miles north of Lima. Chavez, 43, and his 35-year-old sister were members of the Maoist-inspired Shinning Path group and were armed with automatic weapons, police said. The mob beat the three with sticks and then stoned them to death, police said. They said Chavez has led a local guerrilla force for a number of years. He was wanted by police on suspicion of killing a number of peasants. Officials say more than 18,000 people have been killed since the Shining Path began its armed insurgency 10 years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Gold Opens Lower in Hong Kong
DOC.TEXT: Gold dropped $2.39 an ounce on Hong Kong markets Tuesday, opening at $369.87. It closed at $372.26 Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Test Missile Launch Successful From Submarine
DOC.TEXT: A Poseidon C-3 ballistic missile was successfully launched from a nuclear submarine Monday as part of the vessel's final testing program before deployment, an Air Force spokeswoman said. The USS Kamehameha launched the two-stage missile at 1:50 a.m. EDT off the coast near Cape Canaveral, said Sgt. Ivy Paige of Patrick Air Force Base. The launch was part of an exercise to assess the submarine's readiness for deployment and efficiency with the weapons system. The Poseidon is designed to carry nuclear warheads to targets on land. It was the 86th successful launch of a C-3 from Cape Canaveral since August 1968 and the 65th firing from a submarine. No date has been set for the deployment of the submarine, based in Charleston, S.C.

DOC.HEAD: PMs Preliminary News Advisory
DOC.TEXT: Following is a list of stories to give PMs editors an idea of how the report is shaping up. This is not a complete digest. The first PMs digest will move at 11:30 p.m. EDT.
DOC.HEAD: HOSTAGE:
DOC.TEXT: WIESBADEN, West Germany _ ``A little skinny'' after 43 months as a hostage in Lebanon, but Daddy is headed home, U.S. educator Frank Reed tells his young son on TV after his Moslem captors let him go. PM-Hostage.
DOC.HEAD: US-HOSTAGES:
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON _ President Bush, meeting with freed hostage Robert Polhill, says Iran cannot expect ``vast improvement'' in its relations with the United States until all hostages are released. PM-US-Hostages.
DOC.HEAD: HOSTAGES-FAMILY:
DOC.TEXT: MALDEN, Mass. _ Fifi Reed always said she wouldn't believe her husband was free until she saw a picture. On Monday, pictures from Syrian television gave life to the joyous news from the State Department: Frank Reed was coming home at last. PM-Hostages-Family.
DOC.HEAD: TERRORISM:
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON _ Syria and Iran, which won praise from President Bush in the release of American hostage Frank H. Reed, are criticized again in the State Department's annual report to Congress on terrorism. PM-Terrorism.
DOC.HEAD: GERMANY:
DOC.TEXT: EAST BERLIN _ America, the Soviet Union, France and Britain _ the World War II allies that carved up Nazi Germany _ meet this week to discuss Poland's fear a unified Germany may try to take back some of its old lands. PM-Germany.
DOC.HEAD: HUBBLE TELESCOPE:
DOC.TEXT: GODDARD SPACE FLIGHT CENTER, Md. _ The Hubble Space Telescope, all $1.5 billion of it, is back in working order today because a NASA engineer used a Tinkertoy, a lamp cord, masking tape and glue to help solve a major problem. PM-Hubble Telescope.
DOC.HEAD: NEBRASKA GOVERNOR:
DOC.TEXT: LINCOLN, Neb. _ Kay Orr made history in 1986 when she became the nation's first Republican woman to be elected a governor, but Democrats eyeing her low job approval ratings hope her tenure itself soon will be history. PM-Nebraska Governor.
DOC.HEAD: LAWYERS-HUMAN RIGHTS:
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON _ More than 270 lawyers, judges and other legal professionals worldwide were killed or persecuted last year, in part because of their association with unpopular causes or because they championed human rights, a legal watchdog group said today. PM-Lawyers-Human Rights. Eds: Embargoed until 12:01 a.m. EDT.
DOC.HEAD: AIDS RESEARCHER:
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON _ A government AIDS researcher is under suspension while a grand jury considers whether he hid a financial interest in a company that contracted with the laboratory where he worked. PM-AIDS Researcher.
DOC.HEAD: WEAPONS PLANTS:
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON _ The government is moving toward resumption of nuclear weapons production after months of safety-related shutdowns, despite growing criticism from citizen groups. PM-Weapons Plants.
DOC.HEAD: EISENHOWER-HISTORIANS:
DOC.TEXT: WASHINGTON _ First they liked Ike, then they didn't like Ike, then they liked Ike again: that's the pattern of historians' appraisal of Dwight D. Eisenhower, whose place in history is still to be fixed. PM-Eisenhower-Historians.
DOC.HEAD: MORMON RITUAL:
DOC.TEXT: SALT LAKE CITY _ A Mormon ritual has been revised to require women to vow to obey God rather than their husbands and to no longer portray clergy of other religions as agents of Satan. PM-Mormon Ritual.
DOC.HEAD: BOGUS BOX OFFICE:
DOC.TEXT: HOLLYWOOD _ The weekly box-office figures supplied by the studios are supposed to be gospel. But every so often they're about as accurate as an old-fashioned Chicago vote count, insiders say. PM-Bogus Box Office.
DOC.HEAD: CENTENARIAN-CONGRESS:
DOC.TEXT: GOLDSBORO, N.C. _ Centenarian Henry Stenhouse is running for Congress after watching the country ``disintegrate'' during his lifetime. ``God has saved me for something. I feel like it's an obligation.'' PM-Centenarian-Congress.

DOC.HEAD: Antoine Vitez, French Actor, Director, Dead at 59
DOC.TEXT: Antoine Vitez, chief administrator of the famed French theater company Comedie Francaise, died Monday of a brain hemorrhage, Culture Minister Jack Lang announced. He was 59. ``A master of the theater has left us,'' Lang said. Vitez was named to the Comedie Francaise post in 1988 after seven years as director of another another Paris-based company, the National Theater of Chaillot. Born in Paris on Dec. 20, 1930, Vitez became an actor at 19. He performed, directed or taught in Marseille, Caen and Nanterre, and was a colleague of Lang's at the Chaillot theater in 1972-74. He was a member if the Communist Party until 1980, when he quit to protest the incursion of Soviet troops in Afghanistan. Vitez' predecessor at the Comedie Francaise, Jean Le Poulain, died of a heart attack in March 1988, also after having served in the post just two years. Funeral arrangements were pending.

DOC.HEAD: Trial Begins for Alleged Bomb Factory Workers
DOC.TEXT: Two men whom the authorities say are members of the Irish Republican Army went on trial Monday in connection with the operation of a bomb factory that London police stumbled upon by accident. Authorities said they headed off a Christmastime bombing campaign with the arrest of the two men _ Nicholas Mullen, 42, and Eamon Wadley, 36 _ and the discovery of the arms and explosives cache in December 1988. At the Old Bailey Central Criminal Court, Mullen denied charges of conspiring to cause explosions and Wadley denied charges of making documents for use in terrorism. The trial is expected to last up to six weeks. Police accidentally discovered the stockpile in an apartment complex after a shooting nearby. They pursued a gunman into the complex and, while searching the area, found an apartment filled with Semtex plastic explosive, machine guns, firearms, rifles, handguns, and bomb-making equipment. Prosecutor John Nutting described it as one of the biggest stockpiles of terrorist equipment ever found in Britain. He said the two accused were members of an IRA unit that was about to embark on a pre-Christmas bombing campaign that he said ``certainly would have led to the death or injury of many people.'' The IRA is waging a bloody fight to drive the British out of the predominantly Protestant province of Northern Ireland and unite it with the Roman Catholic Irish Republic. In Belfast, Shauneen Baker, 17, appeared in court on charges of possessing a Semtex bomb with intention to endanger life and damage property. She was arrested Saturday by security forces who stopped and searched a bus taking people to Aldergrove International Airport, 15 miles from Belfast.

DOC.HEAD: Former Houston Police Officer Receives Seven-Year Sentence
DOC.TEXT: A former Houston police officer was sentenced Monday to seven years in prison for killing a black woman in a shootout on a Houston freeway after a night of drinking among off-duty officers. Alex Gonzales, 25, was convicted Friday of voluntary manslaughter in the case, which became a cause for groups that maintain Houston police are hostile to blacks. Blacks and other community leaders said they did not think an all-white jury would convict the Gonzales. Trial in the death of Ida Lee Delaney, a janitor at The Houston Post, was moved to Dallas because of heavy news coverage in Houston. Attorneys for Gonzales planned an appeal. A community activist who has monitored the case said she believed most observers would consider the verdict fair. ``Obviously, there was enough information and evidence to bring some form of justice and that was critical in my opinion,'' said activist Charlotte Ragsdale. ``The family was looking for hope in the system in they were able to find it.'' Tests after the shooting showed Gonzales had a blood-alcohol level of .19, nearly twice the amount to be considered legally drunk in Texas. Gonzales testified that Ms. Delaney shot at him and two other off-duty officers before they chased her on a Houston freeway for 12 miles early on Oct. 31, 1989. During the pre-dawn chase, the 50-year-old woman pulled her truck over to the side of the road, apparently seeking help. Ms. Delaney fired at Gonzales after he ran to her truck, gun in hand, and punched her in the face, witnesses testified. Though wounded, he returned fire, killing her. The jury spent most of the day Monday determining the sentence. Gonzales could have been sentenced to up to 20 years in prison. Gonzales and the two other officers, Alexander Romero and Robert Gonzales, who is unrelated, were fired by former Houston Police Chief Lee Brown. All three have appealed their firings.

DOC.HEAD: Kaifu Calls for Greater Japanese Role in Asia
DOC.TEXT: Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said Monday that Japan intends to play an increasing role in Asia through its economic and technological power. Kaifu, who arrived in India on Sunday to start a weeklong tour of five South Asian nations, said Japan had ``learned the lessons of history'' after its defeat in World War II and would never again aspire to power through military means. ``But times have changed dramatically,'' Kaifu said in an address to the Indian Parliament. ``Now that the building of a new world through dialogue and cooperation is being called for, Japan can and must play a positive role by putting to effective use its economic and technological capabilities,'' he told the Indian Parliament. Following Kaifu's 40-minute address, Prime Minister V.P. Singh said: ``We i India see a growing role of Japan in Asia. Japan resents more than a triumph of technology, financial intrepidity of managerial excellence.'' ``The time has come, I am convinced, for this Japanese initiative to bear its effectiveness even further,'' Singh said. Japan has promised $50 billion for its five-year worldwide aid program that started in 1988. The bulk of that money is contributed to Asian nations. Earlier in the day, Kaifu met Singh and said Japan would extend a loan of about $633 million to India next year, Kaifu's spokesman said. The exact amount of the Japanese loan will be decided at the June meeting of the Aid India Consortium, the spokesman, Shigeo Takenaka, told reporters. Kaifu heads to Bangladesh on Wednesday and then to Pakistan, Sri Lanka and Indonesia.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Tells Panamanian President US `Will Stand With You'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf pvs, But saying, with 3 grafs to UPDATE with late Senate action.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush announced his nomination of the first-ever Panamanian to manage the Panama Canal as he told that nation's new president on Monday that the United States ``will stand with you in peace.'' Bush, in his first meeting with President Guillermo Endara since the U.S. invasion of Panama last December, also voiced support for Endara's proposal to speed up a study on the feasibility of widening the 86-year-old waterway. But saying ``the struggle is not over in Panama,'' Bush chastised Congress for not moving quicker on his $800 million aid package for Panama and Nicaragua. The measure has been delayed in the Senate behind a long list of unrelated amendments. One snag, a dispute over abortion and the death penalty in the District of Columbia, was cleared away late Monday when senators agreed on a voice vote to include both provisions in the bill and work out the issues in a House-Senate conference committee later. The accepted language would allow use of D.C. funds to pay for abortions for poor women and permit the death penalty for drug-related murders in the district. But if the abortion provision remains in the bill, Bush has said he would veto it, which would lead to further delay. ``I've asked and asked again that our aid package to the newly liberated people of Panama be passed and passed swiftly. And still it waits, and with it the future of the fledgling democracy,'' said Bush, Endara at his side, after the two leaders met for 2{ hours. Endara was installed as president last Dec. 20 by U.S. invasion forces who toppled the government of strongman Manuel Antonio Noriega. Endara, speaking in Spanish, said his people had suffered ``under 21 long years'' but that ``tyrannies of any kind, of any sort, must be relegated to the past.'' Then, addressing Bush directly in English, Endara thanked him for filling ``our spirits with enthusiasm and optimism.'' He invited Bush to visit Panama as soon as possible. ``Be careful, I might just show up,'' Bush said. In a departure ceremony, Bush praised Endara as ``a consensus builder'' who ``won the confidence of Panamanians and all Americans.'' The president used the occasion to announce he was sending to the Senate, under terms of the 1978 Panama Canal Treaties, the nomination of Gilberto Guardia Fabrega to be Panama Canal Commission administrator. The treaties called for a Panamanian _ selected by Panama, nominated by the U.S. president and confirmed by the U.S. Senate _ to be put in charge of the canal in the final decade of U.S. jurisdiction. The canal will be turned over to Panama in the year 2000. Last year, Bush balked at a Noriega choice for canal administrator and refused to send a name to the Senate. The present administrator, Dennis P. McAuliffe, is an American. Guardia, 60, is the president of an architectural and engineering company in Panama City. Educated at Santa Clara University in California, Guardia was a civil engineer with the Panama Canal Company in the 1950s. Endara praised Bush's endorsement of Guardia as canal administrator as ``an act of justice.'' Bush and Endara also signed four agreements: three on drug-war cooperation and the other to allow Peace Corps volunteers back into the isthmus nation. ``Panama, a nation newly reborn in liberty, can count on the support of the United States of America. We were with you in times of conflict, and we will stand with you in peace,'' Bush said. Both in his comments with Endara, and in remarks earlier Monday to the annual convention of the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, Bush accused Congress of dragging its feet on his Central American aid package. Bush complained that his package of aid to Panama and Nicaragua had become weighed down _ by adding another $800 million in unrelated spending in the House and with ``a contentious abortion provision'' in the Senate. Bush asked Congress last March 13 for the $800 million package _ $500 million for Panama and $300 for Nicaragua. The Senate trimmed the Panama part of the package to $420 million. ``It is embarrassing'' that the aid still hasn't won passage, Bush told the Chamber of Commerce audience. ``Nicaragua and Panama quite simply need this aid and we've got to deliver.'' ``No wonder the American people get so frustrated with the way the Congress operates,'' he added. Assistant Secretary of State Bernard Aronson told a news conference that Bush endorsed Endara's proposal that a U.S.-Panama-Japan study on widening the Panama Canal _ halted under Noriega's regime _ go forward and produce its recommendations within five years. Of the three new drug agreements: one would allow the U.S. military to board Panamanian-flag vessels suspected of carrying narcotics; another seeks to regulate chemical substances used for illicit drugs; and the third would permit the U.S. Coast Guard to enter Panamanian territorial waters under specified circumstances.

DOC.HEAD: China Lifts Martial Law in Tibet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with martial law ending. Picks up 8th graf, `Altogether, Tibetans ...'
DOC.TEXT: Chinese authorities lifted martial law on Tuesday in the Tibetan capital of Lhasa, nearly 14 months after the restrictions were imposed to quell bloody nationalist rioting. China said social order had been restored. The official Xinhua News Agency said martial law, imposed March 8, 1989 after three days of anti-Chinese rioting, officially ended on orders of Premier Li Peng. ``In view of the fact that the situation in ... Lhasa has become stable and social order has returned to normal, the task of enforcing martial law in the city has been successfully fulfilled,'' said a Cabinet order signed by Li. Xinhua said People's Liberation Army troops were ordered to leave their posts around the Jokhang Temple, Buddhist Tibet's holiest shrine and a flashpoint for anti-government demonstrations, at midnight Monday. Troops have manned checkpoints on main roads leading into the temple and maintained sentries around the Barkhor Square that encompasses the temple. It is likely that the army and the paramilitary People's Armed Police will continue to be deployed in large numbers around the city. Anti-Chinese, pro-independence sentiments remain high in Lhasa. Xinhua warned Monday that ``separatists on both sides of the border ... are still plotting to continue their separatist and destructive activities. We absolutely cannot relax our vigilance.'' The government said 16 people were killed and more than 100 wounded in last year's riots. Tibetan and foreign sources said about 30 died. Altogether, Tibetans say about 70 people have died in clashes with police and soldiers in the past three years. The rioting was the bloodiest in Tibet since a failed 1959 uprising and marked the first time martial law was announced in China since the 1966-76 Cultural Revolution, when radical leftists tried to purge China of bourgeois influence. The riots began March 5 when Tibetans carrying banners marched around Jokhang Temple. Chinese police opened fire. Angry crowds began stoning police and went on a three-day rampage, burning Chinese shops and attacking Chinese passers-by. Police responded with more gunfire and tear gas. Tibetans spoke of hundreds of arrests after the March riots, but China's official media reported only 20 people being sentenced, some receiving life prison terms and others a few years. During martial law, the military presence in Lhasa _ normally high _ was stepped up further, with soldiers or paramilitary officers stationed at intersections. Most reporters were barred from the city. Tourism was tightly restricted. Nonetheless, reports of several small nationalist protests have filtered out, to be routinely denied by the Chinese. Most recently, a monitoring group in London, the Tibet Information Network, said Chinese authorities expelled several Buddhist monks and nuns from religious institutions and hundreds of monks left their monasteries in protest. Most monks and nuns remain loyal to the Dalai Lama, their exiled religious leader and once Tibet's secular ruler. They have been at the forefront of most independence demonstrations in recent years and were forced to undergo political education during martial law. China has said the Dalai Lama, who won the 1989 Nobel Peace Prize for his peaceful resistance to Chinese rule, can return only if he gives up his proposal for Tibetan autonomy. He fled to India in 1959. China says its sovereignty over Tibet dates back to the 13th century, when a Chinese princess married a Tibetan ruler. However, many Tibetans say Chinese rule was sporadic and that for many years Tibetans had their own theocratic government, flag and currency. Tibetans speak a different language, and they are culturally distinct from Chinese.

DOC.HEAD: Kohl Challenger Recovering Well from Stabbing
DOC.TEXT: Oskar Lafontaine, Chancellor Helmut Kohl's main rival in Dec. 2 elections, will be released from the hospital less than a week after being stabbed at a campaign rally, officials said Monday. They said he will check out of University Clinic in Cologne on Tuesday. ``We have only good things to say about the course of his recovery,'' his spokeswoman, Maria Zimmermann, said. ``No further hospital stay is necessary for his continuing treatment and convalescence.'' A mentally disturbed woman stabbed Lafontaine in the neck on Wednesday night with a butcher knife she hid in a bouquet of flowers she pretended she wanted to give him. Lafontaine is the Social Democratic governor of Saarland state.

DOC.HEAD: Anti-Smuggling Balloon Damaged in Winds
DOC.TEXT: A radar-equipped helium balloon designed to spot drug smugglers was torn apart by high wind and its sophisticated equipment was damaged, officials said. The $12 million balloon, one of 16 intended to be deployed along the Mexican border by the U.S. Customs Service, tore into three pieces during 57 mph winds Saturday afternoon said Customs spokeswoman Kathy Hamor. The balloon was moored near the ground when the wind struck. The craft, one of three to deployed from a West Texas base, has been grounded since a sister craft was damaged by lightning in Decmeber. The balloon's radar was damaged, but a complete assessment hadn't been made, said Danny Morris, an engineer with General Electric Co., which made the balloon. GE still owns the balloon and is paying the operating costs during a test period. The balloons are intended to float at 10,000 to 15,000 feet, and information from their radar is transmitted to the ground along a tether. The government plans a defensive line of 16 of the balloons, or aerostats, from the Pacific Coast to the Grand Bahamas. Presently five are in operation in Deming, N.M., Yuma and Fort Huachuca, Ariz., Grand Bahama Island and Cudjoe Key, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Cancel Future Poly Royal Festivals
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to CORRECT that 64 injured sted arrested.
DOC.TEXT: A 58-year-old college festival wrecked by a weekend of rowdy rock throwing was abolished Monday. California Polytechnic State University President Warren Baker called off future celebrations of the annual Poly Royal festival for an indefinite period after a morning meeting with Mayor Ron Dunin. On Friday and Saturday nights, party-goers hurled rocks and bottles at police officers, who used tear gas and fire hoses to disperse crowds. Sixty-four people were injured, including 14 police officers, and there were 110 arrests. The Poly Royal festival originally showcased student achievements, but crowds had become increasingly lawless over the past few years as parties and entertainment were added to the activities. The celebration drew 100,000 people to the campus next to this city of 40,000 on California's central coast.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers
Editors
Managing Editors
DOC.TEXT: A summary of developments in the news industry for the week of April 23-30:
DOC.HEAD: AP President Says Electronic Darkroom Testing on Schedule
DOC.TEXT: An electronic darkroom system designed by The Associated Press to replace its current network of photo receivers is on schedule and meeting pre-production testing goals, AP President and General Manager Louis D. Boccardi told the annual meeting of the news cooperative. Boccardi told publishers and editors representing the AP's 1,486 newspaper members on April 23 that full-scale installation of the AP Leaf darkroom is to begin in September after summer field-testing. An installation schedule is to be announced in June. Because installation of the darkroom will mean conversion to satellite delivery, the schedule will be driven by where AP can achieve the biggest savings in land-line costs to help pay for the project, Boccardi said. He said a joint committee of member photo editors and production executives would be announced within two weeks to advise the AP on the rollout of the darkroom program. Bill Rinehart, the just-retired ANPA vice president for technical matters, will serve on the panel. Boccardi compared the new technology for electronic handling of photos to the computer terminal revolution in handling words. He said it will mark a major step forward for newspapers. ``We will train your staff, and AP's service reliability will stand behind the AP Leaf darkroom. It is the right step at the right time,'' Boccardi said. He noted that darkrooms from sources other than AP could be used with the AP Leaf, which will fully conform to ANPA standards. Other technological advancements are imminent, Boccardi added. By July 1, the AP expects to complete the conversion of its entire highspeed system to deliver copy to members at 9,000 words a minute. A customized stocks service that allows members to localize market table pages is in print in a dozen member newspapers, and the installation schedule for SelectStocks will be accelerated through the rest of the year. Boccardi also touched on the plight of Terry Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent, who was taken hostage in Lebanon five years ago last month. ``We continue to search for an end to his ordeal and pray that recent optimistic comments will lead to his release,'' Boccardi said.
DOC.HEAD: Keating Re-ElectedAP Board Chairman; Daniels Elected Chairman-Elect
DOC.TEXT: William J. Keating was re-elected chairman of the board of directors of The Associated Press and Frank A. Daniels Jr. was elected vice chairman and chairman-elect. Keating is chairman and publisher of The Cincinnati Enquirer. His term as a director will expire in 1992. Daniels is president and publisher of The News & Observer of Raleigh, N.C. Louis D. Boccardi was re-elected president and general manager. The AP board's reorganization meeting on April 24 also included the seating of one new director and five incumbents and the election of two new vice presidents. The AP management officers newly elected to one-year terms as vice president were William E. Ahearn, executive editor, and James R. Williams, director of AP Broadcast Services. In addition to Boccardi, AP management officers re-elected for one-year terms were James F. Tomlinson, vice president and secretary; Patrick T. O'Brien, vice president and treasurer, and vice presidents Claude E. Erbsen, Walter R. Mears, John W. Reid and Wick Temple. Also re-elected from the AP were assistant secretaries Lilo Jedelhauser and Lee Perryman, and assistant treasurers Frederick R. Barberi, Paul H. Jenssen and Roger P. Sturm. The board of directors also reappointed Robert Morse of WMAQ-TV, Chicago, as a representative of the broadcasting industry. He will serve a two-year term.
DOC.HEAD: Whichard and Five Incumbents Elected to AP Board
DOC.TEXT: David J. Whichard II of The Daily Reflector of Greenville, N.C., was elected to the board of directors of The Associated Press, and five incumbents were re-elected. James K. Batten, J. Stewart Bryan III, Ruth S. Holmberg, Tom Johnson and Joe D. Smith Jr. were elected to new three-year terms. Directors were elected from among 12 nominees at the AP's annual meeting on Monday. Whichard was elected to the board to represent a city of under 50,000 population. He succeeds retiring director John O. Emmerich Jr. of The Greenwood (Miss.) Commonwealth, who was not eligible for re-election because he has served the maximum three consecutive three-year terms. Batten is chairman and chief executive officer of Knight-Ridder Inc., based in Miami. Bryan is chairman and publisher of the Richmond (Va.) Times-Dispatch and The Richmond News Leader. Holmberg is publisher of The Chattanooga (Tenn.) Times. Johnson is chairman of the Los Angeles Times. Smith is president of the Alexandria (La.) Daily Town Talk. The voting for directors was based on membership bonds held by the newspapers that make up the cooperative news agency. The results: Batten, 18,495 bond votes. Johnson, 14,846. Smith, 14,814. Bryan, 11,599. Holmberg, 11,291. Robert H. Hartmann of The Evansville (Ind.) Press, 8,945. George W. Wilson of the Concord (N.H.) Monitor, 8,563. Walter E. Bartlett of The Greenville (S.C.) News, 7,329. Beverly Kees of The Fresno (Calif.) Bee, 5,297. Richard L. Conner of the Fort Worth (Texas) Star-Telegram, 2,701. In the separate contest for election to the board to represent a city of under 50,000 population, Whichard received 11,791 votes. Ted M. Natt of The Daily News of Longview, Wash., received 8,739 votes.
DOC.HEAD: Mexican President Protests Doctor's Arrest in Camarena Case
DOC.TEXT:
Mexican President Carlos Salinas de Gortari, speaking at the annual luncheon of The Associated Press on April 23, denounced the alleged U.S. kidnapping of a Mexican doctor to face charges in the slaying of a narcotics agent. Salinas pointed to Mexican arrests and convictions of 28 defendants in the 1985 slaying of U.S. drug agent Enrique Camarena as proof that Mexico needs no help in apprehending the guilty. Dr. Humberto Alvarez Machain, who was brought to El Paso, Texas, on April 3 from Guadalajara, Mexico, is one of 18 people under indictment in the Camarena murder.
A federal judge in Los Angeles has demanded an explanation of how Alvarez came to the United States. If the doctor was kidnapped, Salinas said, the incident could undermine the international drug-fighting effort. ``This runs the risk of creating illegal habits among those who have the obligation of defending the law and could create a problem much larger than the one we are trying to combat,'' Salinas said.
The Mexican government has complained about the arrest of the gynecologist, alleging the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration offered money for the kidnapping and may have been in on the actual plot. Alvarez is alleged to have been present when Camarena was tortured and murdered at a Guadalajara house. Prosecutors allege that the doctor gave Camarena drugs to revive him for additional torturing before he was killed.

DOC.HEAD: Readership, Technology, Recycling Topics at ANPA
DOC.TEXT: An advertising consultant told the American Newspaper Publishers Association on April 24 that papers should adopt a more local focus because issues such as the push for independence in Lithuania won't sell ads. At the association's 104th annual convention, the nation's newspaper publishers also discussed declining readership, telecommunications developments affecting papers and recycling of newsprint. ``The only specialized thing about a newspaper is its locality,'' said Laurel Cutler, vice chairman of FCB-Leber Katz partners and vice president of consumer affairs for the Chrysler Corp. Frank A. Daniels Jr., president and publisher of The News & Observer of Raleigh, N.C., said, ``A newspaper traditionally has been a smorgasbord. You have something in there for everybody.'' But Ms. Cutler warned against newspapers trying to be ``all things to all people'' and suggested specialization was more appealing to advertisers. ``The more generalized, the more all things to all people, the less we care about you,'' she said. The comments came during a panel discussion called ``Ozzie and Harriet Are Gone _ Who Do You Think You're Writing For?'' Virginia Dodge Fielder, vice president of research for Knight-Ridder Inc., expressed industry frustration in trying to pinpoint the cause of declining readership. ``I wish people hated us more,'' she said. ``I wish they expressed more dissatisfaction because if they did we'd know how to tackle it. ... What the public is saying is not `I hate you' but `I don't need you. You're a great electric company, but I live in an all-gas house.''' One publisher said the industry may be close to winning a 6-year-old fight with the Bell companies over who can transmit electronic information in the future. Robert M. Johnson, publisher, president andchief executive officer of Newsday Inc. of Melville, N.Y., reported that Congress is likely to pass a bill soon setting a telecommunications public policy. He said the Bell companies have set aside a $25 million ``war chest'' to fight for the right to publish information on its electronic circuits. He said Bell seeks to launch an ``electronic Yellow Pages'' that would compete directly with newspaper advertising. Such actions would violate a 1984 federal court decision that set out the principle of diversity in dividing AT&T into separate companies, he said. Citing antitrust laws, U.S. District Judge Harold Greene held that those who control telecommunication lines should not also control the information that goes over those lines, Johnson said. Johnson said that in the past year a task force of the ANPA has worked with Congress on legislation addressing the issue. A draft bill was produced but has not yet been passed. An appeal of the original federal order has sent that back to Greene for reconsideration. The chairman of the ANPA's Newsprint Resource Task Force said publishers should move quickly to recycle newsprint to keep the government from imposing regulations. Frank A. Bennack Jr., president and chief executive officer of the Hearst Corp., New York, said publishers have resolved to double the amount of recycled newsprint used in the coming year, reaching a total of 4.6 million tons. ``We believe efforts to control newsprint can mean efforts to control the press,'' he said. ``The prospect of dealing with a regulated newsprint industry calls up an array of terrifying unknowns.'' Bennack said that at least two states have already mandated that newspapers use recycled newsprint, but he insisted such official orders will be unnecessary if publishers act on the recycling issue voluntarily.
DOC.HEAD: St. Louis Sun Closes Abruptly
DOC.TEXT: The St. Louis Sun folded April 25, ending a seven-month struggle to become the country's first big-city newspaper to make a profitable launch since World War II. ``It is clear that we could not achieve sufficient circulation to make this enterprise viable and so, we have concluded that there is no longer room in St. Louis'' for the Sun, said Ralph Ingersoll II, editor in chief. With a circulation of about 100,000, the seven-day morning tabloid never threatened the St. Louis Post-Dispatch's circulation of 375,000 daily and 565,000 on Sunday. But it did manage to generate a fair share of controversy. The Sun was accused of sensationalism for its coverage of a politician involved in a sexual assault and of the five-year anniversary of an accident in which a man was nearly sawed in two. The newspaper also was chided for running photos of revealing women's swimsuits and lingerie. Some critics derided its flood of promotions, fluorescent green billboards and contests. But the Sun was praised for its coverage of the effort to build a new domed stadium downtown and of the troubles facing St. Louis' major air carrier, Trans World Airlines. Ingersoll is chairman and chief executive of Ingersoll Publications Co. and has an interest in four other newspaper holding companies. He said his new tabloid needed to sell most of its copies from vending boxes and newsracks. Instead, it ended up with home-delivery sales outnumbering single-copy sales 2-to-1. That cost the paper, which spent more than $25 million to start up, an unexpected $5 million. Home delivery costs are higher because of the expenses of billing customers and hiring delivery people. The sudden death did not surprise everyone. ``They read the handwriting on the wall. ... The weather was good, the Cardinals were playing, the Blues were playing and people still weren't buying the paper. You don't have to be a brain surgeon to figure it out,'' said Kevin Horrigan, a columnist who jumped ship from the St. Louis Post-Dispatch to join the Sun. In Horrigan's old newsroom, Post-Dispatch Editor William Woo said he was sorry about the demise of the Sun. ``The Sun undertook a difficult mission and made a valiant effort, which fell short,'' Woo said. Ingersoll said he didn't know how much money overall he had lost on the Sun. He said the decision to close had nothing to do with debt problems at another of his newspaper companies. ``I emphasize the sole reason the St. Louis Sun did not succeed was the inability to generate adequate single-copy sales,'' he said. On April 20, an offer by Ingersoll to buy back much of the $240 million of junk bonds issued by his Community Newspapers Inc. failed to attract a single bondholder. If the company can't agree with bondholders on a buyback, it could be forced to more than double the interest rate on some of the bonds to more than 26 percent. The St. Louis Sun was owned by Ingersoll Newspapers Inc., which also owns 77 other newspapers in seven states. When he launched the Sun in September, Ingersoll said he wanted to prove that new newspapers, if properly designed and promoted, could be introduced in the United States just as they had been in other countries. He said he was planning to move to St. Louis and would personally direct the paper's launch. He spent many late nights in its high-tech newsroom learning about sophisticated equipment and refining the paper's look. ``I'm disappointed. I feel that we gave it our very best shot,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Industry in Recession, Gannett Chairman Says
DOC.TEXT: Like the entire newspaper industry, Gannett Co. Inc. is mired in a recession that began in the second half of 1989, Chairman John J. Curley told shareholders April 26. Gannett, whose profits grew along with its increasing size for 22 consecutive years since it became a publicly traded company, ``managed to report an up quarter, but barely'' in its first-quarter earnings report, Curley said. Curley's comments were made after the American Newspaper Publishers Association meeting, at which news executives discussed the general drop in advertising revenues and an accompanying decline in readership. Gannett has suffered from the downturn in advertising that started in the Northeast, spread to the South and has not yet reached the West Coast, company officials said. They were cautious about prospects for their papers, including USA Today. Still, they said they expect USA Today to turn profitable for the first time in 1990. They also said USA Weekend is approaching profitability and now carries more ads than its main competitor, Parade magazine. But Curley cautioned, ``We won't really know about the retail climate until we find out what happens in May and June.'' He noted that Gannett's stock price rose along with the fortunes of the company in the first half of 1989, then fell when the newspaper business turned down in mid-1989. Trustees of the Gannett Foundation, whose sole asset is 10 percent of the company's stock, said April 25 they would put the block up for sale because Internal Revenue Service rules forced them to consider diversifying their holdings. The charitable trust is headed by former Gannett Chairman Allen H. Neuharth. The foundation's 15,940,185 shares of stock were worth about $566 million last week. The foundation said that at times the shares have been worth as much as $900 million. Through a spokesman, Neuharth declined to comment on a Washington Post story that said the proposed sale may indicate a rift between Neuharth and executives who have run the company since he left as chairman in March 1989. Curley gave up using limousines and the corporate suites Neuharth had rented in New York and Washington, and the Post said Neuharth was upset by comments of Gannett executives criticizing his lifestyle while chairman as excessive and wasteful. Curley also declined to comment through his spokeswoman, Sheila Gibbons, although she said of the Post story, ``I think that's overreaching.'' Much of the shareholders meeting was devoted to descriptions of how Gannett is trying to develop new products as Americans find less time to read and show less inclination to do so. Such strategies include buying the city magazine in Rockford, Ill., where Gannett publishes the Register Star newspaper, ``to increase our already strong information and ad picture,'' said Gary L. Watson, president of Gannett's community newspaper division. He said Gannett might buy other such magazines. Watson and other Gannett officials also described how the company had: _published a ``talking phone book'' in Florida with access to news, weather, sports and other information at a toll-free number. _put out advertising guides to luxury real estate, also in Florida. _started upscale lifestyle supplements to attract advertisers in New Jersey and Florida. _published a guide with Pacific Northwest tourist information to be distributed on ferries that sail from Washington state to Alaska. _run specials on its television stations built around special sections in USA Today.
DOC.HEAD: First-Quarter Profit Down 33 Percent at Times Mirror
DOC.TEXT: Times Mirror Corp. said April 25 its first-quarter profit fell 33 percent, largely because of an advertising slowdown that hit its Northeastern newspapers, consumer magazines and broadcast TV operations. For the quarter ending April 1, Times Mirror's earnings fell to $46 million, or 36 cents per share, down from $68.8 million, or 53 cents per share, a year earlier. Revenues rose 3.3 percent to $875.2 million from $846.9 million. But Times Mirror said its slide in earnings was partly attributable to higher promotional costs and higher circulation that pushed up operating costs at the Los Angeles Times. ``Although our professional publishing and cable television operations achieved solid earnings growth during the quarter, their performance only partially offset the marked deterioration in our newspaper publishing segment,'' said Robert F. Erburu, Times Mirror's chairman and chief executive. Ad volume was slow at the Northeastern newspapers, with Newsday and New York Newsday suffering from a depressed New York economy, Times Mirror said. The 1990 first quarter also had one less Sunday than the year-earlier period, which reduced revenues. Despite increased revenues at the Los Angeles Times, a surge in circulation increased operating costs, contributing to a 38 percent decline in operating profit from newspapers. Times Mirror said its companywide circulation, as reported to the Audit Bureau of Circulations but not yet verified, rose 4.1 percent for the daily papers and 3.2 percent on Sunday over the past six months. At the Los Angeles Times, daily circulation during the same period rose by 8.1 percent to 1,210,077, with Sunday circulation up 5.7 percent to 1,504,540, the company said. Publisher and Chief Executive Officer David Laventhol estimated half the increase was from former readers of the now-closed Herald Examiner. New York Newsday grew by 11.6 percent to 217,514 daily circulation during the six months, and The Hartford (Conn.) Courant reported a 2.2 percent rise to 230,358, the company said. Although consumer magazines also were affected by the advertising slowdown, the book, magazine and other publishing segment still had a 13.6 percent increase in quarterly revenues and 21.7 percent growth in operating profit as a result of gains by the legal publishing, flight information and training businesses.
DOC.HEAD: Times-Mirror, Knight-Ridder Merge National Ad Sales Operations
DOC.TEXT: Times Mirror Corp. and Knight-Ridder Inc. on April 25 announced a merger of their national advertising sales operations into a single company called Newspapers First. The new company will represent 37 newspapers, including large independents not affiliated with Times Mirror or Knight-Ridder, reaching about 20 percent of the U.S. adult newspaper readers. ``Newspapers First will represent papers from coast to coast and in many of the largest metropolitan areas in the country,'' said Baltimore Sun Publisher Reg Murphy, chairman of Million Market Newspapers-Times Mirror National Marketing. Murphy and Jerome Tilis, the chairman of Knight-Ridder Newspaper Sales and vice president of marketing for Knight-Ridder Inc., announced the merger at the annual convention of the American Newspaper Publishers Association. MMN-TMNM, based in New York, sells space in more than a dozen newspapers to national advertisers. Knight-Ridder Newspaper Sales, also based in New York City, serves 26 newspaper markets. The merger takes effect on June 4. Newspapers First will have its headquarters in New York. Additional offices will be located in Chicago, Detroit, Miami, Dallas, Los Angeles, San Francisco, Minneapolis and Atlanta. The independent newspapers that will be represented include The Boston Globe, The Denver Post, The Indianapolis Star and The Indianapolis News, and The Milwaukee Journal and the Milwaukee Sentinel.

DOC.HEAD: Publishers Troubled by Advertising and Readership Declines
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Story originally for Use Sunday, April 29
DOC.TEXT: Dave Lyons remembers the glory days in Odessa, Texas, when the oil boom brought roustabouts and rig workers to west Texas and the circulation of his newspaper, The Odessa American, shot skyward. ``They were blue-collar workers. But they were sophisticated,'' he said. ``They were world traveled. Some of them had served overseas in Saudi Arabia or Libya.'' They were people who read newspapers. Now, many of the oil people are gone, and, like other Texas papers, The Odessa American is struggling back from a precipitous tumble in readership and advertising. Texas papers are not alone. Odessa's story was typical of tales of woe told last week at the American Newspaper Publishers Association's 104th convention, a gathering that annually takes the pulse of the U.S. newspaper industry. This year, the pulse was slower than ever and the prognosis for the patient's future was anybody's guess. Was the problem a recurring depression or something more life-threatening? A transfusion of advertising would help, all agreed. A healthier readership was advised. The Odessa American, a member of the Freedom Newspapers group with a circulation of 38,000, is bouncing back, Lyons said, due to aggressive changes. Those include conversion from an afternoon to a morning paper and a heavy focus on local sports to attract notoriously indifferent younger readers. ``Since 1986, we've lost about 20 percent (of circulation),'' Lyons said. ``But that was because we lost population. Our home county had a population of 144,000 before the oil bust. Now the population is 116,000. ... ``These days, every time I see an obituary for a person over 50, I think, oh, no, there goes another subscriber,'' Lyons said. Advertising, the lifeblood of newspapers, has been draining away at an alarming rate all over the country. In the worst slump since the 1970s, advertising was down 2.8 percent in 1989 from a year earlier, according to Leading National Advertisers, a firm that tracks newspaper ad revenue. In the first quarter of 1990, even the normally robust Times Mirror Co. reported a 33 percent fall in net income. The drop was blamed on a soft ad market, particularly for the company's East Coast newspapers. Times Mirror's flagship paper, the Los Angeles Times, announced a dramatic circulation climb of 9.5 percent to an all-time high of 1,225,189 daily, buoyed by readers from the Los Angeles Herald Examiner, which folded in November. But the Times' advertising revenue was down about 2 percent. Ironically, the financial news that fills newspaper business pages has had a boomerang effect, striking the messengers in the pocketbook. Acquisitions, mergers, store closures and a falling real estate market mean decreased advertising. Classified pages, the newspaper's financial backbone, shrank as ads for automobiles, real estate and help-wanted declined. ``The question is whether it's cyclical or not,'' said John J. Curley, chairman of Gannett Co., which owns more dailies than any other group. ``We honestly don't know.'' In its first-quarter report, issued last week, Gannett profits rose by only the narrowest of margins, from $74.9 million a year ago to $75 million this year. Curley sees the newspaper recession as regional rather than nationwide. He linked it to last winter's bankruptcy protection filing by the Campeau Corp., the Toronto-based conglomerate that controlled some of this country's best-known retail stores, including Bloomingdale's, Jordan Marsh, Lazarus and Abraham & Straus. ``West is best,'' Curley said, noting that the Southwest, recovering from the oil crisis, is doing well. ``Northwest is second-best. Midwest is more down than out. Southeast is mostly down _ that's retail related. Northeast is worst, with automotive ads a big factor.'' Craig Standen, president of the Newspaper Advertising Bureau, an arm of ANPA, stressed that newspapers aren't the only media-related companies suffering. ``The whole media market, the advertising business, is not going as fast as it has in the past,'' he said. ``Yes, it's a problem for newspapers. But I don't think it means something is structurally wrong with newspapers.'' Declining readership was the other major problem troubling publishers. It was the topic of panel discussions, speeches and workshops. Poor education was denounced. More literacy was demanded. A note of hope was sounded by Steven L. Isenberg, associate publisher of Newsday, who said that in spite of a general economic downturn, New York remains a bastion of newspaper readers. ``In New York City, the number of people who read two or more papers a day is remarkable,'' he said, adding, ``Opinion is the mother's milk of New York life. We give them columnists with different opinions and views, and they come back with a real signature of daily life.''
