DOC.TEXT: For more than a year, S. Epatha Merkerson built her life and career around ``The Piano Lesson.'' Her loyalty has paid off. The actress turned down work that interfered with the play's off-and-on travels from Chicago to San Diego to Washington to Los Angeles and now New York. She accepted short-term job assignments to fill in the employment gaps. A small movie role here. A guest spot on television there. ``It's been that important,'' Merkerson says now. ``It always was a dream of mine to act, but I don't think I could ever have dreamed of this. If any kid ever wants to do anything I am living proof that you can dream of something and have it come true.'' Three days before ``The Piano Lesson'' opened on Broadway last month, it won the Pulitzer Prize for playwright August Wilson. Reviewers not only cheered the play, but singled out Merkerson for her portrayal of Berniece, a strong woman determined to keep a family heirloom, an old upright piano, from being sold. The play, part of Wilson's decade-by-decade chronicle of the black experience in America, focuses on a battle between brother and sister. The brother, played by Charles S. Dutton, is determined to sell the piano to buy the land their ancestors worked on as slaves. The sister wants to keep it as a reminder of their painful past. ``I know Berniece,'' says the exuberant Merkerson, the opposite of the reserved, uptight woman she plays. ``What we have in common is that I am a collector, too, but on a small scale, of black history. I like to keep things and so does Berniece. I collect golliwogs, black memorabilia.'' Merkerson was hired for ``The Piano Lesson'' without an audition, solely on the strength of a recommendation from casting directors Meg Simon and Fran Kumin. But she had a rapport with both Wilson and director Lloyd Richards. ``Lloyd lets the actor create and as long as you are within the concept of the play that we have all been discussing and reading, you are fine,'' she says. ``He trusts the people that he hires.'' During the long tour, Wilson refined the play, even changing the ending to have more of a resolution in the fight over that piano. ``In the year and three months that I've been on the road with the play, certain things changed every time we did it. And even changed up until the rehearsal here for Broadway,'' Merkerson says. ``So it's been an ongoing process. And we're still finding new things, which is marvelous. It's still very fresh for us. Even though some people in the cast have been doing it for two years.'' Merkerson's family, from Michigan, wasn't in show business, although they were very theatrical. Everybody played an instrument, sang or danced. ``But I'm the only one who actually pursued it,'' says Merkerson, born in Saginaw but raised in Detroit. ``And they sort of live vicariously through me.'' She studied first at Eastern Michigan University in Ypsilanti and later at Wayne State in Detroit where she focused on theater. Merkerson left Wayne State for a yearlong job with a children's theater in Albany, N.Y. When it was over, the only logical thing to do was come to New York. She arrived in 1978. ``There was lots of work then,'' Merkerson recalls. ``People were really supporting small theaters. I literally was able to support myself doing showcase work. In all my years in New York, there has been only one month when I had to take a job outside the theater.'' Merkerson's first break was more than a decade ago in the Chicago company of ``For Colored Girls Who Considered Suicide When the Rainbow is Enuf.'' ``The women I worked with in the `For Colored Girls' company gave me the most valuable advice,'' she says. ``They knew I was green and they said, `Look, no one knows you but us and your mother. You make sure you do as much good work as you can. Get your name out there because then people will know you do good work and are reliable.''' Merkerson's other work in New York includes replacing Lonette McKee in ``Lady Day at Emerson's Bar and Grill,'' ``Three Ways Home'' and ``Moms,'' the story of Moms Mabley starring Clarice Taylor. ``I recall going into an audition for a big name director of a film and he asked me who I studied with,'' Merkerson says. ``I started naming the people I had worked with like Adolph Caesar, Barbara Montgomery and Mary Alice. ``My most valuable lessons have come from those actors I have worked with. I really are the people who have helped me. They have taught me by watching me work and my being able to work alongside them. They are truly my teachers.'' One constant throughout her career has been the actress' refusal to change her name ffeel like those or the stage. ``Epatha was the name given me at birth,'' says Merkerson. ``I was named for a woman who was very influential in keeping my dad in school.'' The ``S'' stands for Sharon. ``But no one in my family calls me that,'' she adds. ``People have told me that my name was very difficult and that I should change it,'' she says. ``But I figure once you learn it, you won't forget it. Only recently did I learn there was some meaning to the name. A woman camay welcomed the release of hostage Frank H. Reed, thanked both Syria and Iran but said again, ``We cannot rest ... until all hostages are free.'' He called the news of Reed's release by kidnappers in Lebanon cause for joy, but expressed concern about the plight of six other Americans and 10 other Westerners who remain hostage. ``This is a joyous day for Mr. Reed, his family, his friends and all Americans,'' Bush said in a written statement just hours before his scheduled afternoon meeting with Robert Polhill, the American hostage freed last week after 39 mopnths in captivity. ``With Mr. Reed's release, we have six innocent Americans that are still being held hostage in Lebanon,'' as well as the other foreign hostages, he said. ``Their predicament weighs on our mind and tempers the joy we feel today.'' The six Americans still hostage in the Middle East include Terry Anderson of The Associated Press. He is the longest held, and has been captive for more than five years. As he did eight days ago when Polhill was let go, Bush thanked Syria and Iran _ two states the United States has accused in the past of sponsoring terrorism. ``Once again, we wish to express our gratitude to all those who through their efforts helped in Mr. Reed's release,'' said Bush. ``In particular we would like to thank the government of Syria for facilitating this release. We would also like to thank the government of Iran for using its influence to help bring about this humanitarian step.'' Bush said, ``We cannot rest, however, until all hostages are free. We urge all parties who either hold hostages or have any influence over the hostage takers to work for the expeditious and unconditional release of the remaining hostages.'' Earlier, the Bush administration today dispatched a special recovery team to West Germany to greet Reed. There was no immediate word from State Department officials on Reed's condition after 43 months in captivity. In Malden, Mass., Reed's wife, Fahima, said she was ready to travel overseas ``as soon as I see the picture of my husband.'' Earlier in the day, as optimism rose over the prospect of a release, the White House said it was ``very hopeful'' that a hostage would be freed. But it it reiterated its policy of no deals with the kidnappers. Reed, a hostage in Lebanon for 43 months, was liberated by Islamic militants and turned over to Syria, which played a middle-man role for the Bush administration, the State Department said in the first word of his release. ``We've got confirmation that he's been released and is in Syrian hands in Lebanon,'' said Kim Hoggard, a State Department spokeswoman, after receiving word from the U.S. Embassy in Damascus. The State Department had kept an open telephone line to the Embassy in the expectation that Reed, former director of the Lebanon International School in Beirut, would be liberated. Reed was seized in the Lebanese capital Sept. 9, 1986. White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said the State Department hostage reception team was being dispatched to Wiesbaden, West Germany, where hostage Reed will be taken for treatment. Amid reports in Iran that the planned release follows ``extensive talks'' between the Iranian government and the hostage-holders, Fitzwater said, ``We've had a lot of third party intermediary kinds of messages back and forth with Iran. But there's nothing we can point to in terms of any specific reasons for this release.'' ``It is virtually impossible for us to know exactly the contributions of Iran in these kinds of matter,'' the spokesman added. He reiterated that there will be ``no deals'' with the kidnappers. ``We know very little'' about the Islamic Revolutionary Dawn, the group saying it would release Reed, Fitzwater said. At the State Department, Ms. Tutwiler said the Islamic Dawn group ``was unknown to us before yesterday's announcement.'' Ms. Tutwiler said it is probably associated with the Islamic Jihad, but added: ``We know next to nothing about this group.'' ``No one knows precisely what motivates the hostage-takers in any of their activities, either in the taking of hostages or holding them or releasing them,'' Fitzwater said. ``There is considerable speculation that Iran and Syria and others in that part of the world would like to have better relations with the United States. The president has said goodwill begets goodwill. And we are hopeful that indeed that is the case, that they do want better relations.'' Reed, 57, was director of the Lebanese International School when he was seized from his chauffeur-driven car near the Beirut airport on Sept. 12, 1986, as he was driven to play golf. The Massachusetts native had lived in Beirut for eight years. He is a convert to Islam married to a Syrian Moslem.

DOC.HEAD: At the Movies: ``The Gods Must Be Crazy II''
DOC.TEXT: ``The Gods Must Be Crazy'' entranced world audiences with its simple, comedic tale of an African nomad who finds a Coca-Cola bottle and transforms it into an icon. There was a slapstick romantic subplot as well, but the film's great appeal stemmed from the character of the smiling, open-faced actor with the impossible name of N!xau. Those who embraced the film will naturally approach ``The Gods Must Be Crazy II'' with misgivings. Sequels never equal the original, they say. ``The Godfather II'' was a rare exception. ``The Gods II'' can't possibly approach the joy of discovering the delightful N!xau. But the new film is a creditable attempt, combining another amusing male-female subplot with the central story about N!xau's search for his lost children. Jamie Uys, a veteran South African filmmaker, composes his films like silent comedies. Jammed with sight gags, they are almost playable without dialogue. Uys even uses the silent-movie technique of speeding up the action (by undercranking the camera) to punctuate the comedy. His script presents three parallel and sometimes intersecting plots: _ 1. Two young children of N!xau accidentally land in the truck of some poachers racing across the desert with a cargo of elephant tusks. The distraught father finds the trail and races after them, day and night. _ 2. A New York lawyer (Lena Farugia) attends a conference in southern Africa. She takes a sight-seeing flight in a tiny plane, which crashes in the wildernesses. A research zoologist (Hans Strydom) agrees to lead her back to civilization, their journey encountering a series of mishaps. _ 3. A Unita scout (Treasure Tshabalala) and a Cuban soldier (Erick Bowen) encounter each other in the wild and wage comical, one-on-one warfare. The stories don't always mesh neatly, and some of the comedy bits prove tedious, such as the heroine's climbing up and down a tower to pump water. But there are a few bellylaughs, and N!xau remains a captivating figure. The two youngsters, Eiros and Nadies, are absolute wonders. Some will argue that Uys could have extracted lessons in the senselessness of war, the corruption of ``civilization,'' the dangers to wildlife. But he is an entertainer not a preacher, and for that we can be grateful. Produced by Boet Troskie and released by Columbia Pictures, ``The Gods Must Be Crazy II'' is rated PG but it seems acceptable for all audiences. Running time: 97 minutes.

Motion Picture Association of America rating definitions: G _ General audiences. All ages admitted. PG _ Parental guidance suggested. Some material may not be suitable for children. PG-13 _ Special parental guidance strongly suggested for children under 13. Some material may be inappropriate for young children. R _ Restricted. Under 17 requires accompanying parent or adult guardian. X _ No one under 17 admitted. Some states may have higher age restrictions.

DOC.TEXT: Within the space of a week, the film world lost two of its luminaries: Greta Garbo and Paulette Goddard. Garbo, who made only 27 movies, died April 16. Goddard, whose career spanned five decades, died April 23. Both were 84 years old. Goddard appeared in about 46 movies, many in bit parts or cameos. Most of Garbo's best work is available for the home video viewer, including her classic 1932 Oscar-winner ``Grand Hotel.'' Only a few of Goddard's movies have made it to video, including Charlie Chaplin's satire of industrial society, ``Modern Times,'' in which Goddard appeared in 1936. Here is a partial list of what's available on video of Garbo and Goddard films:
DOC.HEAD: GRETA GARBO:
DOC.TEXT: _ ``Flesh and the Devil'' (1927): Menage a tois plus one, with sexy John Gilbert. _ ``Wild Orchids'' (1928): Love in the tropics _ Java style. _ ``Anna Christie'' (1930): Garbo speaks. _ ``Grand Hotel'' (1932): Crossroads of 1,000 lives; inspiration for almost as many stories, movies, songs, plays, set in Berlin before World War II. _ ``Anna Karenina'' (1935): Tragic Garbo. Remake of her 1927 flick with John Gilbert, ``Love.'' _ ``Camille'' (1936): A weeper from George Cukor about a dying woman and her affair with a younger man. _ ``Ninotchka'' (1939): Garbo laughs. A comic jewel from Ernst Lubitsch.
DOC.HEAD: PAULETTE GODDARD:
DOC.TEXT: _ ``Kid Millions'' (1934): You can see her part in a blink in this Eddie Cantor musical. _ ``Modern Times'' (1936): Up the industry. The Little Tramp confronts dehumanizing inventions. _ ``The Women'' (1939): Movie version of Claire Booth's dishy play. _ ``The Great Dictator'' (1940): Charlie Chaplin as Adenoid Hynkel, ruler of Tomania. _ ``Second Chorus'' (1941): Two trumpet players (Fred Astaire and Burgess Meredith) vie for the fair Paulette. _ ``Pot O' Gold'' (1941): James Stewart was in this slice of life look at oldtime radio. _ ``Reap the Wild Wind'' (1942): Cecil B. De Mille goes underwater off the Georgia coast.

DOC.TEXT: The story of a tragic love set against the moody backdrop of the Louisiana Territory is told by the artist Anne-Louis Girodet-Triosen in ``The Funeral of Atala.'' The haunting oil, painted around 1811, has been acquired by the High Museum of Art in Atlanta. This particular canvas _ there are three known versions _ was commissioned by the Empress Josephine, wife of Napoleon I, for the Chateau de Malmaison. The artist, who was known as Girodet, based his work on ``Atala,'' a popular novel of the day written by Francois Rene de Chateaubriand, published in 1801. It told the story of Chactas, a Natchez Indian who was captured by an enemy tribe and condemned to death. Atala, the captive wife of the tribe's chie, falls in love with Chactas and helps him escape. They wander the wilderness together, not giving in to physical passions because Atala had taken a vow of chastity. Rather than risk temptation, she poisons herself and dies. Girodet's neoclassical oil depicts her burial. She is lowered, half clothed with folded hands across her belly, into a grave, while a tortured Chactas hugs her knees. When the painting was first shown at the Salon of 1808, it was enormously popular. Josephine liked it so much that she immediately commissioned a copy. The original hangs in the Louvre. DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
The Artists: Preserving Traditional Culture in Cambodia
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The sensuous, 1,000-year-old body language of Cambodia's classical ballet will soon reach Western audiences, as the country embarks on some ``dance diplomacy.'' Beginning next month, members of the national dance company will spend seven weeks performing in Britain and the Netherlands. The group also has been invited to an arts festival in Los Angeles in September. However, it is uncertain whether entry will be granted since the United States has no ties with Phnom Penh. The cultural journey is part of an effort to help Cambodia out of international isolation, and to show the world that its culture has not been ``Vietnamized.'' ``The truth is as you see it,'' said dance director Proeung Chhieng. ``One cannot change one's soul. The Vietnamese have their culture and we have ours.'' As he spoke young dancers went through a rigorous practice session at the University of Fine Arts, weaving hands, swaying hips and gliding across the floor to tell stories of bygone loves and wars. Graduates of such training are to make their first trip to the West since the early 1970s when the U.S.-sanctioned Lon Nol government held power. The Khmer Rouge reign of terror all but eradicated the classical dance. The foreign tours are seen by knowledgeable observers as small steps toward international recognition by a government that most of the world shuns in favor of a guerrilla coalition led by Prince Norodom Sihanouk. Domestically, the general revival of traditional arts has probably helped the communist, Vietnam-installed regime to gain some popularity and buttress its claim of fostering Cambodian nationalism. Vietnam, which invaded Cambodia and ousted the Khmer Rouge in early 1979, unquestionably has had a significant effect on the country's political course. But Cambodians stridently maintain its powerful neighbor has not debased, or even influenced, their culture. At the university, for example, the only discernible Vietnamese influence are a few teachers of Western instruments such as the accordion and violin. There are reportedly as yet no qualified Cambodians for these instruments. The Sihanouk-led coalition, which includes the Khmer Rouge, and others have claimed Cambodia is the target of Vietnamese ``cultural imperialism.'' While independent observers, including Western aid agency officials based in Phnom Penh, discount such charges, they note the state and communist party make use of culture and put limits on artistic expression. Minister of Culture Chheng Phon stressed it was the duty of artists and intellectuals to support ``good leaders'' and help fight against the Khmer Rouge. Despite censorship of the media the former actor and music scholar claimed more artistic freedom existed under the current government than those of Lon Nol or Sihanouk, who ruled Cambodia first as king and then head of state. He said satires mocking official corruption and lust for power currently being performed would certainly have been banned in Sihanouk's time. In an interview, the minister said the past decade had seen the rebirth of traditional culture from the Khmer Rouge era. The next phase, he said, would emphasize ``unleashing the gray matter, creating something, not just preserving.'' How far this can go in a country at war and under one-party control remains to be seen. William Labban, an Australian ethnomusicologist helping the ministry, said there was nothing in Phnom Penh that could be described as an intellectual community. There are no literary magazines and little printing of any material. ``It's a vacuum and it can't be filled while there is a war going on. You need money and leisure before it can happen,'' he said. But Labban and others say the revival of traditional culture has been impressive given the meager resources and the physical depredations and slaughter of artists, teachers and other intellectuals by the ultra-radical Khmer Rouge. Today, the country has three archaeologists, two architects, three veteran teachers of the classical dance and not a single skilled librarian. The National Library is still reeling from the wholesale destruction of books by the Khmer Rouge and the National Museum, home of priceless statuary, is beset by swarms of bats and electrical fixtures from the early 1920s. Despite Cambodia's political isolation, some foreign assistance has trickled in from the Belgian government, U.N. Children's Fund, private Australian agencies and Cornell University in Ithaca, N.Y. Judy Ledgerwood, a Cambodia scholar from Cornell, is literally stopping Cambodian culture from being eaten up by purging palm leaf manuscripts of destructive insects. The literary and religious texts, inscribed on palm leaves, are also being microfilmed and stored in special containers. Angkor Wat, one of the world's architectural masterpieces, is being restored by Indian experts but most other structures from Cambodia's Golden Age between the 9th and 13th centuries are in urgent need of care. Music, the dance and other arts were traditionally passed down from teacher to student rather than recorded for posterity. But the violence and chaos of recent decades has severed these fragile links. To assist in some sort of preservation, Labban is training students to record old music, and the fine arts university is videotaping classical dances that have been reconstructed from the fading memories of the few surviving authorities.

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Music Makers: A Simon Sense of Achievement
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Carly Simon has been working hard these days, doing everything from singing standards dressed in glamorous gowns to writing songs to recording two albums, scoring a film and writing children's books. She has a sense of achievement. And she's looking forward to summer like a kid let out of school. Her newest album, ``My Romance,'' has 11 standards, plus a new song co-written by Simon, ``What Has She Got?'' Arista Records intends to release it with a record of her own songs that will come out next fall. Some of those, written around her birthday, will be about the passing of time. It will include ``Fisherman's Song,'' which sounds like a folk song and has Judy Collins and Lucy Simon singing backup, and ``Have You Seen Me Lately?'' _ a tune Simon wrote for Meryl Streep to sing in Mike Nichols' upcoming film ``Postcards From the Edge.'' Simon did a Home Box Office special in April, with Harry Connick Jr. as her guest. He played piano on some songs, and performed some duets. ``We only went through them once and it sounds as if we've been singing together our whole lives,'' Simon said. ``It was magical. He's one of the most talented people I've ever met. He sings like (Frank) Sinatra and plays piano like (Thelonius) Monk.'' On May 6 she sang a few songs with Connick in his show at the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival. Simon recently watched a video of the one-hour special for the first time because she had been afraid to watch it. She thought their duet, ``I Don't Know Why I Love You Like I Do,'' was ``very sexy.'' But she was winging it with her on-stage patter. ``I hate hearing myself; I feel embarrassed. They left them in; they felt it lends a sort of down-to-earth quality.'' For the album, she and pianist Michael Kosarin went through ``piles and piles of songs deciding which were best for my voice,'' winding up with six by Richard Rodgers. Then Marty Paich arranged for orchestra and conducted. ``I can't imagine anybody treating those songs more sensitively and romantically,'' Simon said. The record was made in three days, four songs a day. She spent one week before the HBO special was shown in scoring ``Postcards From the Edge.'' ``Fortunately, I was able to mobilize everything in my head and work with a sense of urgency, panic and drama. It was very much like studying for the exam when you haven't done the work all semester. ``I think I wrote a great song for Meryl to sing opening the picture. She sings two other songs, `You Don't Know Me,' the old Ray Charles song, and one Shel Silverstein wrote.'' The same week she and Doubleday editor Jacqueline Onassis finished work on her children's book for next Christmas, ``The Boy of the Bells.'' Her first children's book was ``Amy the Dancing Bear,'' out for Christmas 1989. ``I'm going to put out one a year probably for the rest of my life.'' Her husband, Jim Hart, who can be seen in the audience at the special, is finishing a novel. Sipping a big mug of tea during an interview, Simon talked about Jackie O. ``She had great suggestions; she helped me enormously,'' she said. ``The thing I love about her is that she didn't want to `tighten it up' or take any of my personality out of it. The other thing I feel is that her work thrills her. She doesn't do it dryly or coldly. She is perfect for an artistic type of person. If I feel like I'm just taking up somebody's time, I just feel awful. ``She didn't do this editing on `Amy.' That landed on her desk almost perfect. I must have told that 1,000 times to Sarah and Ben. This I started from scratch on a day in the sun when I felt like thinking up a new story. It wasn't honed the way `Amy' was.'' When her children Sarah, called Sally, 15, and Ben, 13, were young, Simon made up stories for them. ``I loved doing it. I very rarely read to them because they seemed to go to sleep better if all the lights were out,'' she said. ``Amy is a budding aritst. That was a story that Sally particularly loved. Ben was quite angry that I didn't dedicate it to him as well.'' She dedicated ``The Boy of the Bells,'' a Christmas story, to him. The reason she wrote down Amy and some of her other bedtime stories wasn't to publish but so she wouldn't forget them. ``I knew when I had grandchidren the kids would say, `Remember the one you used to tell about Amy.' My memory would be completely gone by that time.'' In her musical future, Simon wants to sing both her own songs and standards. She wrote ``Fisherman's Song'' in 20 minutes after coming home late from recording and finding Ben asleep. ``I smelled his neck and kissed his eyelids, things he doesn't let me do because he's 13. I translated that to an unrequited love situation. A girl sneaks into a loved one's house and lies beside him. It sounds like an old English folk song. It shows another style of mine I feel equally at home in.'' Simon made one previous album of standards, ``Torch,'' in 1981. ``Everybody gives Linda Ronstadt credit for having gone back and done the standards. I always felt jealous she got all the credit for it.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Books and Authors: Words and Riffs
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Patricia Volk writes fiction and nonfiction _ often at the same time. She calls her short stories ``riffs,'' narratives proudly made up as she goes along. But even Volk knows you can't avoid injecting a little truth in fiction. That's why she tears out pages from the newspapers and circles articles of interest, just in case. One day, for instance, she read about ``syzygy,'' which means the Earth, sun and moon are in rare alignment. Months later ``Syzygy'' became the title of a story included in her collection, ``All It Takes'' ($17.95, Atheneum). ``I was writing this story and I had a character press up against her ex-lover for the last time and I thought, `Oh my God, this is like syzygy. Every part connects,''' explained Volk. ``And I thought, where is that article? I wondered whether people could line up like planets and I started rewriting it from that. Most of my characters are struggling for some kind of alignment, but they can't find a syzygy. It's very rare that you can.'' Volk, whose essays appear frequently in The New York Times, wrote the novel ``White Light.'' She can turn anything into a story. That's how the Manhattan resident became a writer. Ten years ago, there was an incident at the playground with one of her two children, and she couldn't stop describing it to friends. Before long, the story was so polished Volk decided to put it into writing. ``I tell people all the time that the only difference between those who sell and those who don't sell are those who don't send it out,'' she said. ``Some of the best writers don't send their work out. They're afraid of rejection, it's too much trouble. They're not sure they like it.'' Volk can't resist applying a little ``creativity'' to real life. The stain from a spilled cup of coffee gets a little bigger, that delay on the subway becomes a little longer, encounters with strangers keep getting more interesting. ``Your memory plays tricks on you,'' Volk said. ``Any incident is like `Rashomon.' Play that coffee spill back and it's entirely different. I think I bring a lot of fiction writing to the essay in terms of taking leaps and nuance. I think of something that might distort it, but it gives it a personal feel.'' Volk's characters are often in danger of losing their lives in thought, trying to impose order on events as logical as the daily horoscope. In ``Reckless Dreamer,'' a woman reflects on the personality of her former lover: ``He was an editor and lived the most censurious life she knew. He criticized things other people never thought about, labels on cans, the wording on menus, how people sat. He even criticized her syntax and her dreams. If she'd stayed with him, he would have criticized her into the ground.'' In ``Which Is Better?,'' Del analyzes everything from sex to lemonade. ``Thinks Too Much But Can't for the Life of Her Stop'' is included in a list of things she doesn't like about herself. In the title story of ``All It Takes,'' Lucy is so unhappy that she writes letters to the artist Georgia O'Keeffe, seeking advice from an ``expert'' on the meaning of life. ``I think my characters are straddling a fence,'' Volk said. ``On one side they're powerless and on the other side they're rationalists. They're trying to make sense of things. ``Lucy is really quite on the edge. She's trying to maintain her equilibrium with those letters to Georgia O'Keeffe. But when you're needy and you're feeling terribly, you look for answers in everything. If it's a painter, and you move yourself to bounce ideas off a dead person, fine.'' Volk, who grew up in Manhattan and Long Island, had plenty time to think as a child. When her older sister was born, her grandfather quit his job to spend time with the baby. Fortunately, Volk says, her birth was less eventful. ``Second-born children are different. Less is expected of them and less time is devoted to them. It's a very nurturing thing for a writer because there's less time physically for you. You don't have that intensity beamed on you.'' She worked full time, with writing squeezed in during lunch hours. But Volk made the best of it, managing to compose 11 drafts of ``White Light'' with the help of daily trips to a nearby coffee shop. ``I'd get the coffee, I'd get the egg salad and the cheese and I'd go to the library, and it was so wonderful,'' she recalled. ``The whole process was like Anne Tyler sharpening her pencils before she crosses the threshhold into the room where she writes.'' Having quit her job and with the kids in school, Volk can write all the time now. The routine is simple: Just grab a cup of coffee, sit down, and get to work. But writing remains mysterious, what Volk might call a ``yellow banana'' _ something that doesn't turn out the way it's expected. ``Writing the essay I kind of know what I think up front and I can ask questions of my reader, but I don't know what I think up front at all writing fiction. ``It's a real kind of discovery process for me. I do it with the unsensitive part of my brain. The sensitive part of my brain comes later, when I try to make sense of things.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Nashville Sound: Ricky Van Shelton and the ``Voice of the Soul''
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Award-winning country star Ricky Van Shelton describes music as the ``voice of the soul.'' ``It just grabs hold of me,'' the 38-year-old singer says. ``A beautiful melody just picks me up and carries me away.'' Shelton, the reigning Country Music Association male vocalist of the year, has had six No. 1 country music singles in the past three years. His ``RVS III'' has been a No. 1 album on the country music charts this spring. Singing has always been a part of life for Shelton, who spent 10 years as a pipe fitter and plumber before launching a full-time music career. And it always will be. ``If it ends today, I'll be playing at my friends' house Friday night and having a ball,'' he said. ``I've always done it. I couldn't live without it. I play all the time _ early in the morning and late at night.'' Shelton, a star on the Grand Ole Opry, left his home in Grit, Va., two days after Christmas in 1984 and moved to Nashville. In 1987 he burst onto the national country music scene with the album ``Wild-Eyed Dream.'' Both it and his second LP, ``Loving Proof,'' were million sellers. His hit singles include ``I'll Leave This World Loving You,'' ``Somebody Lied,'' ``Life Turned Her That Way,'' ``Living Proof,'' ``Statue of a Fool,'' ``Don't We All Have the Right'' and ``From a Jack to a King.'' He's one of Nashville's most active singers, hitting the road for more than 200 shows a year. ``I don't count 'em,'' he said in an interview on a rare day off the bus that carries him throughout the country. ``We stay gone all the time.'' Still, playing his guitar on stage and performing with his six-piece band is the supreme satisfaction of his profession, he says. ``When I'm on stage for an hour a night, I'm the happiest man in the world. That hour makes up for the other 23. I live for that hour on stage. When you get home, you can't wait to get back out again. It gets in your blood.'' For the past three years, Shelton has been living out his dream: singing hit records, selling millions of albums, performing twice on ``The Tonight Show Starring Johnny Carson'' and receiving some of the top awards in country music. It's been the fulfillment of his vision that began when he sang gospel music in church by age 3. But there's also been a down side. ``It's been a wonderful, wonderful experience and I'm still happy, but when you have big success, you have big problems,'' he said. ``I never have time for myself any more or my friends or my family. I don't have any privacy any more. There are all kinds of decisions to make. I don't get to go fishing any more. ``It (success) has brought me happiness but you don't have time to enjoy it. It's kind of a paradox.'' Sometimes, he misses his days in south-central Virginia where he worked at one time or another as a car salesman, appliance store manager, grocery store clerk and house painter. His main jobs, however, were as a plumber and pipe fitter making $5 to $10 an hour. ``It's a real highly skilled craft to make that stuff work and fit. I miss the challenge of that and the camaraderie of the guys you work with all day long. Them guys work hard. ``It was a very satisfying job when you got through and it was nice to see it operate. I enjoyed welding and cutting things with the cutting torch and getting dirty. And I got dirty.'' Shelton is often compared to Randy Travis, who also broke into country music about the same time singing a similar style of traditional country music. ``Being compared to Randy, that's flattery. He's been super successful.'' Don't expect to find a lot of lyrics in Shelton's songs. ``I don't like a song with a lot of words in it. Too many words kills the thought.''

DOC.HEAD: AP WEEKEND ENTERTAINMENT AND ARTS
Entertainment Briefs
DOC.TEXT: Forty American dancers will go to Korea this summer to teach and perform modern dance. The Dayton Contemporary Dance Company from Ohio, the Doug Varone Dance Company of New York City and seven teachers from the American Dance Festival in Durham, N.C., will be in Seoul from July 30-Aug. 12. ADF was formed in the 1930s as the umbrella organization for preserving choreography. It has many overseas programs including China, Argentina, Venezuela, South Africa and the Soviet Union. This is the second time ADF has brought both teachers and dance companies to a nation for an intensive two-week period. ADF took dancers to Japan in 1984 and 1986 and will go to India next winter. Courses to be taught include one on body knowledge so dancers can understand how their body relates and moves as an instrument, and one on African dance.

Jimmy Smits, JoBeth Williams and Lorraine Bracco have joined star Ellen Barkin in the cast of Blake Edwards' new comedy, ``Switch.'' Shooting began in Los Angeles on April 18. ``Switch'' is a contemporary fantasy about a misogynist who dies and is reincarnated as a beautiful woman. As a female, he has to undergo all the highhanded, selfish treatment that he inflicted upon women in his earlier life. The play is a Blake Edwards Company Production presented by Home Box Office in association with Cinema Plus L.P. Warner Bros. will distribute theatrically in the U.S. and Canada.

Remember Irene Dunne and Cary Grant swapping snipes in an elegant nightclub in ``The Awlful Truth'' while Ralph Bellamy looked on? Or Constance Bennett and Grant kicking up their heels all night long in ``Topper''? The 1930s was a time when night life meant dressing up. And nightclubs were lavish places where you could dine, wine and dance everything from the two-step to the samba. Samiha D'Aiuto is trying to bring back those sylish platinum days with the Blue Angel, a new club with a Follies Bergere-type revue and a harpist to dine by. There's also a cabaret for quiet jazz. The '90s might just be the '30s redux.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, May 3, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Author Sees Need to Limit Medicine's Battle Against Aging, Death
DOC.TEXT: Medical ethicist Daniel Callahan was criticized for picking on old people in his 1987 book about setting limits on medical treatment for the elderly. This time, he may get criticism from more quarters. In his new book, ``What Kind of Life? The Limits of Medical Progress,'' Callahan deals on a broader scale with the same problem: how to rein in the demand for unending efforts to defeat illness and death, and the unending costs involved. Callahan argues that Americans will have to accept limits on medical treatment if there is to be any hope of holding down costs. This could mean denying expensive, high-technology treatments to those beyond a certain age, as well as to other patients on the ``ragged edge'' of medical progress. There should be ``a great reluctance to use curative, life-extending technology in the care of the critically ill, likely terminal, or irreversibly declining patient'' unless there is a strong probability of a good long-term outcome, Callahan writes. ``A society would ... be well justified in the future to set an age limit on the public provision of expensive, life-extending, curative healthcare,'' according to the book. ``We will probably have to set limits of one kind or another for all age groups,'' he said in a recent interview. The suggestion of an age cut-off is perhaps his most controversial. ``It'll never happen, it shouldn't happen, it's a mistaken idea,'' said one critic, Harry R. Moody of the Brookdale Center on Aging at Hunter College in New York. Callahan, 59, is co-founder and director of the Hastings Center, a research and educational organization that studies ethics in medicine and biology. Currently, he said, decisions on allocating health care resources are made ``on a case-by-case basis, and I'm arguing that we'll probably have to do it by categorical standards _ that is to say we might have to use age as a way of setting a limit.'' One way to accomplish this would be to set age cut-offs for Medicare reimbursement: for example, deny payment for heart bypass surgery, chemotherapy or other expensive drug treatments to patients over a certain age, perhaps 80 or 85. This, said Callahan, would not mean abandoning the sick. He advocates increased emphasis on ``caring medicine'' rather than ``curative medicine,'' on good-quality long-term care at home and in institutions, on relieving pain and suffering rather than merely prolonging life. ``What I'm looking for is a kind of trade-off. We need to improve long-term and home care ... and one of the prices we may have to pay is to put some limits on that expensive high-tech curative medicine. ``In effect what we have to do is say, `Look folks, you can't have it all.''' Moody argues that an age cut-off is neither desirable nor politically possible. ``When (Callahan) gets into specifics like cutting off care for people beyond age 85 I say no, because it isn't going to happen and it's distracting from the real issues,'' Moody said in an interview. Limits on treatment for terminal or critically ill patients already exist, in the regulations governing Medicare reimbursements and in the standards and protocols followed by doctors, and can be tightened, Moody said. ``It could very well be that the medical community would develop a practice, for example, of not giving dialysis to people in the end stage of Alzheimer's disease. But that's different from saying it's against the law to do so,'' Moody said. ``With a standard practice, someone who wants to deviate from the practice can always do so,'' he said. ``As the system gets squeezed for money, doctors will routinely try to discourage families from having so-called heroic treatments. But they might not succeed, and the family might say, `No, give him one more year of life.''' That tendency to cling to life, whatever the cost, is part of the problem, Callahan said. Advances in technology have made it harder for patients, families and doctors to accept death. In looking at the problem of escalating health care costs in the United States, Callahan focused first on the elderly because ``the future of health care in this country belongs to the elderly, in the sense that most people will die beyond the age of 65. ``We've done awfully well in eliminating the things that kill people earlier in life.'' The government in March reported that life expectancy in the United States had reached a record 75 years, up from 62.9 years in 1940. This has led to increased emphasis, in research and in treatment, on battling diseases of old age and extending lives still longer. And the costs keep growing. Medicare alone is expected to cost $104 billion this year _ about one-twelfth of the federal budget _ and grow to $183 billion by 1995. The Medicare trust fund could be bankrupt by the turn of the century unless costs are curbed, its trustees reported last month. Callahan sees the pursuit of longer and longer lifespans as ``an open, endless frontier. Given the fact that the body ultimately ages and dies there's no end to the amount of money that can be spent to continue caring for the elderly.'' But there is a limit to the amount of money that can _ or should _ be made available for this battle, Callahan argued. Society and government must weigh this commitment against its other priorities. Otherwise, he said, the endless pursuit of better health and longer lives can use resources needed for other worthwhile goals, from education and child care to building roads and fighting crime. ``It is ... reasonable for us as patients to ask our neighbor as a taxpayer to care for us if we cannot care for ourselves,'' Callahan wrote. ``We cannot ask that neighbor for an ultimate cure of disease, or to relieve us of the burden of having bodies that age and die; and we cannot ask the medical profession or the political order for that kind of benefit, either.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, May 3, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Soviets Begin Exchange with U.S. on Aging Research
DOC.TEXT: The graying of America will be mirrored in other countries, including the Soviet Union, which has sent three scientists to Northwestern University to collaborate on research into aging. ``The pressing issues are how best to deal with the medical needs of the elderly ... without bankrupting the country, and how to maintain their dignity and humanity while we provide them with what they need,'' said Dr. James R. Webster Jr., director of the Center on Aging at Northwestern's McGaw Medical Center. The Soviets will stay in Chicago for collaboration on projects lasting one to three months, and researchers from Northwestern, which initiated the idea for the program, will travel to Kiev later this year for like endeavors. The visits are part of an agreement between Northwestern's Center on Aging and the Soviets' Institute of Gerontology of the Academy of Medical Sciences, the equivalent of the U.S. National Institute on Aging. ``Chicago is one of the birthplaces of gerontology, and Kiev is the most important city in the Soviet Union for that study,'' said Celia Berdes, associate director of the Center on Aging. As an exchange participant, she will look at the Soviets' system of elderly care. According to Webster, one major difference between U.S. and Soviet elderly care is that the United States generally emphasizes high-tech medical approaches. U.S. stroke victims, for example, typically undergo computer-enhanced X-rays and studies of electrical impulses in the brain, while the Soviets tend to direct resources to rehabilitiation, he said. ``They would probably have more intensive and prolonged therapy for the restoration of function _ more emphasis on getting them back into their homes,'' Webster said. Not surprisingly, the Soviet researchers who have come to Chicago will be trying to learn some of America's high-tech methods, he said. Nataliya Bachinskaya, a neurologist, will work for three months with John D.E. Gabrieli, assistant professor of psychology, on how thinking processes change in people who have had strokes and related ailments. ``We're also interested in how we can improve the functional activity of the brains of old persons,'' Ms. Bachinskaya said. Yuri Jaroshenko, an internist, will work for one month with Arthur Atkinson, director of pharmacology, and Richard Davison, chief of cardiology, on a study of how heart drugs work in the elderly. Yuri Rushkevich, a physiologist, will work for one month with John Disterhoft, associate professor of cell biology and anatomy, in a study of learning in aged animals.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, May 3, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Report: Retirees Could See Loss of Health Benefits
DOC.TEXT: Few retirees have access to company-sponsored health insurance and many of those who do are seeing their benefits shrink as businesses try to control skyrocketing costs, a government report says. ``Although seen as a low-cost employee benefit decades ago, retiree health coverage has now become a major concern for companies because retiree health costs have risen and are expected to continue to increase dramatically in the future,'' the General Accounting Office reported. More than 5 million retired Americans are covered by such health plans, of whom 2 million are under 65, the GAO said. Private health coverage is particularly important for younger retirees because people do not become eligible for Medicare health benefits until age 65. The GAO study was conducted at the request of Rep. Edward R. Roybal, D-Calif., who chairs the House Select Committee on Aging. The mission was to find out what was happening to health coverage for retirees, said Gary Christopherson, the committee's director of health legislation. Now that the study has been completed, it's ``not as clear that we know what we want to do,'' he said. ``At this point, Congress is not clear uired contributions from retirees under 65 and 53 percent passed on part of the cost to retirees 65 and over, the GAO added. Christopherson said the few options Congress has available could have negative side effects. For instance, he said, if employers were required to provide health coverage for retirees or Congress tried to make it easier for them to do so, the quality of existing plans could suffer. ``No matter what you gain you're going to lose as much in return,'' he said. ``There's a risk involved.'' The GAO said some companies providing retiree health care coverage might drop the plans if the Financial Accounting Standards Board follows though with a plan to require corporations to show future costs on their balance sheets. The FASB is an independent agency that sets accounting standards for private companies.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, May 3, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Merck Publishes New Elderly Health Care Manual
DOC.TEXT: A graying America requires professionals better equipped to deal with health care problems of the elderly, say publishers of a new reference manual geared toward just that. The Merck Manual of Geriatrics is ``oriented toward medicine, disease and even health of the aged,'' said Dr. P. Roy Vagelos, president and chief executive officer of Merck & Co., the Rahway, N.J.-based pharmaceuticals company that published the book in April. It follows in the tradition of The Merck Manual, first published in 1899, a standard reference on symptoms and diseases. The 1,300-page manual on geriatric medicine describes symptoms and suggests treatments for older patients. Merck sells the handbook at cost, $20, company officials said. Topics include malnutrition, sleep disorders, falls, fractures, incontinence, acute confusion and geriatric emergencies. Despite the aging of the population, medical schools offer little training in specialized treatments for older patients, Dr. William B. Abrams, co-editor of the manual. ``Recent statistics for people completing their internships show that only about 4 percent were able to say that in their medical training they had what was quoted as an extensive experience in geriatrics, meaning a two-week exposure,'' he said. Abrams said physicians must adjust their approach when treating elderly patients. ``The fact of the matter is that yes, many physicians, internists, have taken care of older people. But one definition of experience is making the same mistake over and over,'' he said. People over 65 make up 12 percent of the nation's population, but use 30 percent of health care services, Vagelos said. By the year 2000, the over-65 population will grow to 20 percent and will use about 50 percent of health care services.
Eds: The manual may be obtained from bookstores or from Merck & Co. Inc., Professional Handbooks Department, P.O. Box 2000, Rahway, N.J. 07065.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, May 3, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Indiana Lawyer Lives a Life of the Mind
DOC.TEXT: John Morton-Finney has a dozen academic degrees, is fluent in seven languages and lectures and studies. That, and the fact that he's 100, makes him ``America's most-seasoned scholar,'' according to President Bush. Morton-Finney went to Washington recently to meet Bush, who said he has lived ``the life of the mind better and longer than anyone else.'' ``Try to praise him though, and he'll bawl you out, saying, `There's nothing extraordinary about me,' '' said Bush, who noted Morton-Finney's accomplishments when he honored teacher-of-the year Janis T. Gabay of San Diego. Bush wasn't the first president Morton-Finney had met. The first was Franklin D. Roosevelt. He went to Washington this time because he was invited, but said, ``I've been voting the Democrat ticket since Roosevelt.'' Morton-Finney was honored April 25 at Harvard University with a citation from the Harvard Foundation for Intercultural and Race Relations for his ``lifelong devotion to higher education and public service.'' At a lecture he gave there, he asked students and professors to examine whether the United States had lived up to the ideals in the motto ``e pluribus unum,'' Out of many, one. ``All the people of the nation should be of one mind when it comes to the matter of civil rights,'' he said. ``But even today, some people don't believe in integration, which tells me they are not good Americans. And a good American believes that one man is as good as another.'' Son of a former slave, Morton-Finney became interested in the law because he wanted to know what he could do to protect himself. ``You know, when a person is deprived of doing what he wants to do in life it becomes very burdensome,'' Morton-Finney said. Slaves, he said, ``were not by law or by custom allowed to read or even have a pencil. The law was very strict and was strictly enforced.'' When his father was freed by the Emancipation Proclamation he learned to read and write, Morton-Finney said. His mother, born free, also knew the value of an education. ``My father and my mother both always urged the children to go to school. I learned to like to know about things.'' Morton-Finney was 14 when he spent all his savings, 30 cents, to buy his first book, a dictionary. And he has spent his life learning. He reads three books at a time, and the television in his book-filled home always is tuned to a news channel. It's surprising he has not written a book of his own. ``They say every man can write a book but I haven't written mine yet. It's a big job.'' Morton-Finney was born along the Ohio River in western Kentucky. Of his six siblings, one survives, 95-year-old Viola, who lives in Pennsylvania. When his mother died, Morton-Finney went to live with his grandfather in Jefferson City, Mo., where he attended segregated schools until he joined the Army in 1911. He completed his first academic degree and became a teacher in a one-room schoolhouse. He taught until World War II, when he again joined the military. When he returned home from war, Morton-Finney married Pauline A. Ray, who taught French at Lincoln College in Missouri. They traveled to Indianapolis, where they both taught in public schools. He became a lawyer, graduating from Indiana University's law school. Mrs. Morton-Finney died in 1975 after 54 years of marriage. Their daughter, Gloria, who shares a home with her father, is a public school instructional coordinator. There's one thing America's most-seasoned scholar never got around to learning _ how to drive. ``I've never driven a car in my life, Morton-Finney said. ``I sit in the back seat.''

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, May 3, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Massachusetts Report Shows Abuse Cases Up
DOC.TEXT: Reported cases of elder abuse rose 12 percent in Massachusetts last year, reflecting a steady increase over five years, a state official said. According to the study, reports of elder abuse and neglect increased to 3,094 for the year ended June 30, 1989, compared to 2,769 cases the previous year. Reported cases in the 1984 fiscal year totaled only 1,529, so the latest statistics represent an increase of 102 percent within six years. ``For every report of abuse or neglect we receive, we know that there are many others who suffer in silence,'' said Elder Affairs Secretary Paul J. Lanzikos. But Lanzikos, Donna M. Reulbach, program director for elder protective services, and Craig R. Fox, western regional supervisor, all said it was unclear whether the increase meant more elders were being abused. Reulbach said the increase may have resulted in part from a greater awareness among health care professionals, police and others covered by the state's mandatory reporting law. Hospitals, doctors and others often were more willing to accept families' stories that an injury to an older person resulted from an accident, not abuse, than they were for children, Reulbach said. That is changing, she said. Fox said he has also noticed that drugs are playing a role, sometimes involving grandchildren seeking to extort money for drugs from a grandparent. Joan Hatem, a protective service worker and supervisor at Elder Services of the Merrimack Valley, said alcohol also plays a role, frequently in cases of spousal abuse. That abuse, she said, may have gone unnoticed for years until the abused person reached age 60 and fell under the requirements of the reporting law. Hatem and Lanzikos said sometimes the abuse is unintentional, for example, confining a confused older person to their room to keep them from wandering off. In those cases, Hatem said, a social worker can resolve the situation. Reulbach said serious abuse cases are reported to district attorneys for possible action. Lanzikos said his agency also recently set up a program to help older people threatened by self-neglect. But except in cases of mental incompetence, older people can legally reject state intervention. Fox said that happens in about 23 percent of reported cases. The report covered abuse in homes and other community settings. Reports of abuse in nursing homes are handled by the Department of Public Health.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, May 3, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Plan Now for Retirement
DOC.TEXT: Millions of Americans have benefited from the Social Security Act, approved by Congress in 1935. But the Social Security Administration says that by the year 2048 money for the future may be depleted if Congress continues to borrow against the fund. There is strong evidence that Social Security might radically change by the time today's baby boomers reach retirement age. Because of the uncertainty about the future of Social Security and the extent to which corporations will continue to contribute to retirement funds for employees, my advice to all consumers is to begin planning now for retirement. Americans are almost evenly split on the issue of whether the Social Security system will be able to pay them retirement benefits. Reponding to an Employee Benefit Research Institute and Gallup survey, 47 percent of those surveyed said they would probably not get a penny from the Social Security fund, while 49 percent expressed confidence in the system. It's interesting to note, though, that those with a positive outlook about their retirement fund tended to be 55 and older. Nevertheless, only 7 percent of this age group felt that Social Security would meet all their retirement needs, while 55 percent said the fund will provide one-third or less of their livelihood in the golden years. Despite this skepticism, consumers are not beginning to plan for retirement soon enough. While retirement planning was the key concern among clients of financial planners, most clients don't begin retirement planning until they are 35 to 44 years old, 10 years later than most planners recommend. There are many reasons why all consumers should begin planning today for retirement. Increased longevity rates mean we will have longer retirements than previous generations. Planning for long-term care and medical expenses _ which are rising annually at a rate of 20 percent to 30 percent _ should also be a key concern. Further, because most people want to maintain the same standard of living they enjoyed while working, money that's put away for retirement must account for inflation, which typically increases 4.5 percent annually. I advise all consumers to take these small steps now: _ Participate in a company-sponsored savings program, most of which earn tax-deferred interest until retirement. If you are self-employed, set up a Keogh Plan. _ Save at least 10 percent of income, preferably 15 percent to 20 percent. _ Invest in an individual retirement account, or IRA, one of the few tax-deferred saving programs remaining since the enactment of the Tax Reform Act. _ Consider tax-sheltered annuities. If you work for a religious, charitable or educational organization, or state university or public school system, you may be eligible to participate in a tax-sheltered annuity plan. _ Consider tax-exempt or tax-deferred investments such as municipal bonds or single-premium or flexible-premium deferred annuities. _ Consider diversifying your portfolio to include stocks or real estate, if you feel comfortable with these growth investments.

Janet Walsh is an expert in retirement planning for the Denver-based College for Financial Planning, a non-profit institution offering financial services education programs. She holds an MBA and is a certified financial planner.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, May 3, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: President Jefferson a Model Gardener
DOC.TEXT: Friends of broccoli, saddened by George Bush's dislike of it, can get a lift from another president. Thomas Jefferson, master gardener as well as author of the Declaration of Independence, grew numerous varieties. Broccolis _ green, purple, white _ appear repeatedly in gardening notes Jefferson kept throughout his life, showing he was planting the vegetable in his own kitchen garden at Monticello in Virginia and exchanging seeds with friends. Broccoli aside, anyone looking for a patron saint of gardening will find the perfect model in Jefferson, who said, ``No occupation is so delightful to me as the culture of the earth, and no culture comparable to that of the garden.'' Jefferson lived to age 83, statesman, inventor, architect, astronomer, founder of the University of Virgina. But despite his myriad activities, he had time for a garden diary, starting with an entry dated March 30, 1766, when he was 22: ``Purple hyacinth begins to bloom.'' The burdens of the presidency did not stop him. On April 6, 1804, for example, he wrote, ``Sowed seeds of the East India asparagus in small bed.'' Sometimes he jotted garden notes on odd sheets of paper. In 1808, his last year in the White House, Jefferson wrote to a friend, ``It is now among my most fervent longings to be on my farm, which with a garden and fruitery, will constitute my principal occupation in retirement.'' Fortunately for us, the nation's third president left a wealth of material on his gardening and farming, highlights of which are in the 704-page ``Thomas Jefferson's Garden Book.'' First published in 1944 by the American Philosophical Society in Philadelphia, the book was reprinted in 1985. It's available through bookstores and at the gift shop at Monticello. It's worth a trip to Monticello in Charlottesville, Va., just to see the gardens, restored more than 50 years ago by the Garden Club of Virginia. Vegetable growers will be fascinated by the kitchen garden stretching 1,000 feet along the sunny southern slope and containing more than 250 varieties, including English peas, Jefferson's favorite. (A Virginian of his times, Jefferson had slaves to help him, but he was deeply troubled by the question and was one of the first Americans to propose a plan of abolition.) Through correspondence and accounts of others, the Garden Book, admirably annotated by Edwin Morris Betts, a biology professor at the University of Virginia, gives us rare glimpses of Jefferson. One chronicler, Margaret Bayard Smith, tells us he kept a pet mocking bird in a cage suspended among his flowers and plants in his White House apartment. ``Whenever he was alone, he opened the cage and let the bird fly about the room. ... It would alight on his table and regale him with its sweetest notes or perch on his shoulder and take its food from his lips.'' The correspondence shows us Jefferson on expeditions in southern France and Italy while he was minister to France, always looking for varieties of such crops as rice that might do well in America. He says, for example, ``The olive tree is least known in America, and yet the most worthy of being known. Of all the gifts of heaven to man, it is next to the most precious. ... Perhaps it may claim a preference even to bread, because there is such an infinitude of vegetables which it renders a proper and comfortable nourishment.'' Intimate views of Jefferson as gardener and farmer in his old age also are contained in ``Jefferson and His Time, the Sage of Monticello'' (Little Brown and Co., 1981), the sixth and final volume of Dumas Malone's epic biography. His previous volumes won the Pulitzer Prize for history in 1975. The books tell us Jefferson collected seeds everywhere _ county neighbors, nurserymen, naturalists, from a friend in Italy, even from Gen. Lafayette's aunt. Mrs. Smith, who was the wife of the publisher of the National Intelligencer, visited him in his retirment and reported he kept his vegetable seeds in a little closet. Peas and beans were in tin canisters, she said, but all the other seeds were ``little phials, labeled and hung on little hooks,''' everything being in the ``neatest order.'' As the years went on, Jefferson suffered from rheumatism, but his spirit was not dampened. As he said, ``But though an old man, I am but a young gardener.''
EDITOR'S NOTE: George Bria retired from the AP in 1981.

DOC.NOTE: For release Thursday, May 3, and thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Bill Aims at Testing Drivers 80 and Over
DOC.TEXT: Residents 80 and older will need hearing, sight and driving skills tests every two years under a proposal in the Legislature. A law being pushed for the second year by Rep. Marian Lewis would require more than 300,000 Floridians to prove they're not hazardous drivers, beginning in 1991. While Ms. Lewis contends the measure would keep dangerous drivers off the road, critics say the bill is discriminatory. That argument helped kill her bill in committee last year. In 1986, a similar bill proposed by Sen. Jack Gordon failed when legislators were swamped by mail from constituents opposing the idea. Ms. Lewis' bill has cleared the House committee on highway safety, and she is optimistic the measure will pass the Legislature this year. ``The people of Florida favor testing elderly drivers even before they reach 80,'' Lewis said. ``The bill is such a minimal step toward getting unsafe drivers off our roads. I think we should be re-testing drivers starting at age 60 _ and I'm 60.'' Some legislators say the bill discriminates against a specific age group and makes no provision for transportation for those no longer able to drive. ``I don't know why we're singling out the elderly,'' said Rep. Art Simons. Ms. Lewis noted that most accidents involving young drivers are due to aggressive or careless driving _ not deteriorating skills. ``Older people's reflexes are just going to get worse,'' she said. ``If they aren't competent now, they'll be less so later.'' Indiana, Illinois, New Hampshire and the District of Columbia require drivers to take road tests after a certain age, generally 75. New York state is considering what, if anything, to do about older drivers.
DOC.HEAD: Geriatrics Society Honors Doctors
DOC.TEXT: Eight doctors will be honored for contributions to geriatric medicine at a joint scientific meeting next month of the American Geriatrics Society and the American Federation for Aging Research. To be given awards May 19 are: _ John R. Walsh, professor of medicine at Oregon Health Science University and chief of the gerontology section at the Portland Veterans Administration Hospital. _ Gene H. Stollerman, clinical director of the Bedford division of the Geriatric Research, Educational and Clinical Center in Bedford, Mass. _ Frederick T. Sherman, a private practitioner in Huntington Hospital on Long Island, N.Y., and clinical professor of medicine at the State University of New York at Stony Brook. _ David R. Solomon, professor of medicine at the University of California, Los Angeles, School of Medicine and editor in chief of the Journal of the American Geriatrics Society. Four of those being honored are to present papers at the meeting: John R. Mach Jr., professor of medicine at the University of Minnesota; Maria Antoinette Fiatarone, instructor in medicine at Harvard Medical School; Cary S. Buckman, assistant director at the Newark Beth Israel Medical Center; and Michael W. Rich, assistant professor of medicine at Washington University School of Medicine.

DOC.HEAD: Rig Count Drops By Five
DOC.TEXT: The number of working U.S. oil and natural gas rigs is down for the fourth straight week, slipping by five in this week's tally to total 927, Baker Hughes reported Monday. Although the rig count has declined over the past three weeks, the current total is well ahead of the 761 rigs counted at this time a year ago. Baker Hughes' rig count _ the widely watched industry index of drilling activity _ reflects the number of rotary rigs actively exploring for oil and gas as of last Friday, not the number of producing wells. Houston-based Hughes Tool Co., an oil toolmaker company that merged with Baker International Corp. of Orange, Calif., has kept track of the rig count since 1940. In December 1981, at the height of the oil boom, the rig count reached a peak of 4,500. But oil prices plunged to less than $10 per 42-gallon barrel in the summer of 1986, prompting a collapse in the rig count that bottomed out at 663 _ the lowest since Hughes began compiling figures. Among major oil-producing states, Louisiana and Pennsylvania posted the largest gain with four each, while North Dakota and California each were up three. Oklahoma, down seven, showed the sharpest decline for the week, with Texas off four, Colorado and New Mexico down three and Ohio down one. Kansas, Michigan and Wyoming were unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: Officials Fret Over Labor Unrest, Stock Plunge
DOC.TEXT: The single largest plunge in the South Korean stock market Monday and another day of labor unrest forced President Roh Tae-woo to convened an emergency meeting of his economic ministers. The composite stock index hit an 18-month low after falling 31.71 points to close at 688.66, its lowest level since Oct. 13, 1988. The index has lost 24 percent this year. Protests by investors crippled operations at stock trading offices in Seoul and at least six other cities. Newspapers said some had to close their offices to keep out angry customers. Militant shipyard workers, whose strike was broken up over the weekend, fought running battles with riot police in the southeastern port city of Ulsan and sympathy protests spread nationwide. Economic ministers met in emergency session Monday night to review the nation's growing economic crisis, news reports said. Finance Minister Chung Yung-euy was recalled from New Dehli, where he was to attend a meeting of the Asian Development Bank beginning Tuesday, a presidential aide said. Roh met during the day with Deputy Prime Minister Lee Seung-yun and economic advisors to draft new measures to curb inflation and spiraling land speculation, Presidential press secretary Lee Soo-jung told reporters. Lee said Roh ordered the formation of a special team to consider ways to stabilize the real estate market, including those that may encourage securities and insurance companies to dispose of their land holdings. News reports said investors staged sit-down protests demanding special government measures to prevent a stock market crash. In the central city of Chongju, investors roamed through nine trading offices, smashing windows and furniture, Yonhap, the South Korean news agency, reported. Some protesters demanded the stock market be closed.

DOC.HEAD: Commodity Futures Regulator to Join NY Mercantile Exchange
DOC.TEXT: Economist Robert R. Davis, a member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission since 1984, said today he will leave the federal futures regulating body for an executive position with the New York Mercantile Exchange. Davis, who was nomiated to the five-member CFTC by President Reagan, said he will join the New York exchange as senior vice president for planning and development. Davis' resignation was expected to take effect immediately, the CFTC said. Davis, who has bachelors', masters and doctoral degrees in economics from Virginia Polytechnic Institute, served as senior economist for the Joint Economic Committee of Congress before his appointment to the CFTC. He also has served as a financial economist to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and a vice president at the Harris Bank in Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Court Approves Random Drug Tests for Transportation Department Workers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today let the government force thousands of Transportation Department employees in sensitive jobs to take random drug tests. The court, over one dissenting vote, rejected an appeal by a labor union that said the tests violate the government workers' privacy rights. Today's action is further evidence the justices are willing to allow widespread random drug testing of public employees. Only Justice Thurgood Marshall voted to hear arguments in the case. Four votes are needed to grant such review. Transportation Department officials approved a drug-testing program in 1987 for some 30,000 people in jobs the agency said have a direct impact on public health, safety or national security. Nearly two-thirds of the workers who must undergo the random, periodic urinalysis tests are air traffic controllers. The rest hold a variety of jobs, including airplane inspectors and mechanics, traffic safety specialists and mail van drivers. The tests were challenged by the American Federation of Government Employees, which represents many of the workers but not the air traffic controllers. The U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals here ruled last September that the tests do not violate the employees' constitutional rights. ``The program is supported by sufficiently compelling circumstances to justify the invasions of privacy entailed,'' the appeals court said. Those who test positive once for illegal drugs such as marijuana or cocaine generally are transferred to non-senstive jobs. If they test positive a second time they are fired. The appeals court relied heavily on the Supreme Court's only drug-testing rulings. In them, the justices last year upheld drug and alcohol tests for railway workers involved in accidents and for U.S. Customs Service employees applying for certain jobs. But neither of those rulings determined the constitutionality of randomly administered drug tests. The high court subsequently, without comment, rejected appeals challenging random tests for other public employees. Drug tests of federal workers stems from a 1986 order by then-President Ronald Reagan calling for a drug-free workplace. The Bush administration has endorsed the anti-drug campaign. Neither the court's 1989 rulings nor the cases acted on today bear directly on workers in private employment. The federal employee union's appeal said more than 345,000 government workers now are subject to drug tests that violate their privacy and dignity. Millions more who work for states or cities or in private employment also must submit to such tests, the union said. The Transportation Department program means that each affected worker ``will continue to be subject to random selection for the remainder of her worklife, regardless of how often she has been tested, how uniformly innocent her prior tests or how unblemished her work and health records,'' the union said. The case is AFGE vs. Skinner, 89-1272.

DOC.HEAD: Court Asks Administration For Views On Indian Tax Question
DOC.NOTE: Eds: also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court today asked the Bush administration for its views about Oklahoma's attempt to collect a sales tax on cigarettes and other items sold at a Shawnee convenience store owned and run by an Indian tribe. The court said it wants to know what Justice Department lawyers think about a ruling that bars the imposition of such a tax. A response from the government lawyers might take months, and the justices are not expected to say whether they will review the case until getting that response. The store belongs to the Citizen Band Potawatomi Indian Tribe, and is located on land held in trust for the tribe by the federal government. Oklahoma law requires all vendors to collect from consumers sales taxes of 6 or 7 percent _ 4 percent for the state and 2 or 3 percent for local communities. The state also imposes an excise tax on the sale of cigarettes. The Potawatomis have never collected sales taxes or the cigarette excise tax on items sold in their convenience store, and in 1987 state officials assessed the tribe $2.7 million for the sale and distribution of untaxed cigarettes. The tribe challenged the assessment in court, and U.S. District Judge Lee R. West blocked enforcement of the cigarette tax pending the tribe's lawsuit. West later ruled that cigarettes sold to tribal members could not be taxed but that the tribe must collect taxes on cigarettes sold to non-members. But the 10th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals last November ruled that the tribe does not have to collect any state or local taxes on items sold at the store, even to non-members. The appeals court said Oklahoma officials wrongly relied on a 1980 Supreme Court ruling in a Washington state case to justify the taxing of sales to non-tribal members. In the 1980 case, the appeals court said ``the Indian tribe had opted to come under state jurisdiction.'' It said, ``Because no such jurisdiction exists in this case, Oklahoma's reliance on (the 1980 decision) is misplaced.'' In the appeal acted on today, Oklahoma officials said, ``The case turns on whether federal law has pre-empted state law or whether state action has infringed tribal self-government.'' The appeal added, ``The state simply suggests that the tribe may operate its government in any way that it sees fit. However, if the tribe operates a business in the state, it must obey applicable state laws.'' The case is Oklahoma Tax Commission vs. Citizen Band Potawatomi Indian Tribe, 89-1322.
