DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Open Mostly Lower; Weather Pressures Soybeans
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly lower in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade with soybeans leading the decline amid forecasts for cooler, wetter weather in the Midwest. Soybean futures surged more than 30 cents a bushel last week, partly on the belief that last week's hot, dry weather might set the tone for the growing season. The drought fears were dispelled, though, by several forecasts issued late Friday by the National Weather Service, which predicted cooler, wetter weather in the region this week and normal to above-normal rainfall in the Midwest from May through July. Last week's advance in soybean prices prompted an increase in farmer selling of soybeans over the weekend, triggering further selling of futures this morning, analysts said. The weather outlook is also bearish for corn futures. Wheat futures opened nearly unchanged. In early trading, wheat futures were { cent lower to \ cent higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.70 a bushel; corn futures were \ cent to 1\ cents lower with May at $2.79} a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1 cent higher with May at $1.62\ a bushel; soybeans were 2{ cents to 4{ cents lower with May at $6.30{ a bushel. Cattle futures were mixed while pork futures were mostly lower in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Live cattle futures were .05 cent lower to .03 cent higher with June at 73.15 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .07 cent lower to .22 cent higher with May at 82.37 cents a pound; live hogs were .08 cent to .25 cent lower with June at 62.75 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .45 cent lower to .08 cent higher with May at 64.25 cents a pound. Cattle futures settled higher on Friday. Pork futures were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Posts 24 Percent Profit Rise in 1st-Qtr
DOC.TEXT: PepsiCo Inc. said Monday its first-quarter profit rose 10.2 percent, led by markedly better returns in its domestic soft drink and worldwide restaurant operations. The Purchase, N.Y.-based company said it earned $181.9 million, or 68 cents per share in the three months ended March 24, compared with $165.1 million, or 62 cents per share, a year earlier. Revenue for the quarter rose 24.3 percent to $3.68 billion, from $2.96 billion a year ago. Operating earnings increased 26 percent for the quarter, fueled by strong volume growth in its soft drink, restaurant and snack foods operations. Operating profit in soft drinks rose 27 percent to $151.5 million as sales rose 25 percent to $1.3 billion. Excluding acquisitions, sales were up 8 percent, and operating profit jumped 24 percent. Domestic soft drink profits rose 32 percent on an 8 percent sales gain, including double-digil growth in the Diet Pepsi and Mountain Dew brands, while international profits fell in comparison with strong results a year ago. Operating profit from snack foods rose 20 percent to $186.4 million as sales rose 27 percent to $1.1 billion. Profit growth was fueled by a 50 percent increases in international results excluding the effect of acquisitions. Higher advertising and marketing expenses, costs of new product introductions and a shift in the sales mix to lower margin products led to slower growth in domestic snack food operations, although volume sales rose 6 percent. Increased sales of Ruffles and Santitas were partly offset by a decline in Doritos. Worldwide restaurant earnings rose 39 percent to $91.0 million on a 22 percent sales increase to $1.3 billion. Operating profit rose 39 percent at Pizza Hut to $51.1 million on a 23 percent sales increase to $633.5 million, and 37 percent at Kentucky Fried Chicken to $23.5 million on a 15 percent sales increase to $322.7 million. The Taco Bell chain's operating profit rose 48 percent to $16.4 million on sales growth of 27 percent to $356.3 million.

DOC.HEAD: Ames Replaces CEO Following Chapter 11 Filing
DOC.TEXT: Ames Department Stores Inc. today announced that its chief executive officer, Peter B. Hollis, has resigned and been replaced by Stephen L. Pistner. Ames, which last week filed for bankruptcy court protection from its creditors, described Pistner, 58, as ``a specialist in turnaround situations in the retailing industry.'' Pistner was chairman and chief executive officer of Montgomery Ward & Co. from 1981 until 1985, when he left to become chairman of McCrory Corp. He left McCrory in 1988 to pursue ``a variety of activities,'' Ames said. Pistner will also be chairman of the Ames board of directors. His appointment must be approved by the U.S. Bankruptcy Court in New York, where Ames filed under Chapter 11 of the Bankruptcy Act on April 25. Ames, whose troubles have been blamed on its acquisition of the Zayre discount chain in 1988, is the nation's fourth-largest discount retailer. It operates more than 600 stores in 20 states and has 55,000 employees. Ames announced earlier this month that it would post a $228 million loss for the fiscal year that ended Jan. 27.

The stock market pulled back in slow trading today, extending its decline of the past two weeks. DOC.HEAD: Digital To Unveil First Products From Alliance With Apple Computer
DOC.TEXT: Digital Computer Corp. and Apple Computer Inc. will announce products on Tuesday that allow Digital and Apple computers to connect easily, the first fruit of a 2-year-old alliance between the companies. Through the software, Apple Macintosh personal computers will be able to share computer files with Digital machines, to send messages to Digital computers and to use printers hooked up to a Digital network, among other things, said John Rose, who head's Digital's personal computer division. ``They're all done with the Macintosh friendly user interface,'' said Rose, referring to the on-screen graphics display that makes the Macintosh easy to use by replacing typed commands with pictures. Several outside suppliers provide software to connect Apple and Digital computers, but Rose said none is as comprehensive as the Digital-Apple system. Digital computers usually are connected in a network or to a mainframe computer, while the Macintosh, a desktop computer, usually is a stand-alone machine. The software will allow companies using both types of machines to link them in a network. ``There is a substantial audience out there'' for the products, Rose said. Laura Conigliaro, an analyst at Prudential-Bache Securities Inc., agreed that the market for the products could be considerable. She said there are many companies that rely on both Digital and Apple computers. She said the products are important for Apple because it needs a credible ``server,'' or a computer that acts as the central file repository in a network of computers, while Digital needs a desktop computer that has wide acceptance. ``It has some positive marketability for both companies,'' she said. Digital, based in Maynard, Mass., and Apple, based in Cupertino, Calif., announced their intention to develop the products in January 1988. In the past two years, Digital, the second-largest computer company after International Business Machines Corp., has released products that allow IBM computers to be linked with Digital machines. Ms. Conigliaro said the delay in releasing the Apple-Digital products probably is due to ``the kind of things that go on when companies are big and bureaucracy is the modus operandi.'' Linking computers from various makers is becoming increasingly popular as the computer industry moves from proprietary, or company-specific, computers and software to machines and software that adhere to industrywide standards. Companies increasingly want all their computers to be able to communicate with each other and to share files, analysts say. Rose said additional products to further link Apple and Digital computers will be announced in the future.

DOC.HEAD: Say Trade Reporting Rule Anti-Competitive
DOC.TEXT: A recent London Stock Exchange rule change that allows for a delay in reporting large trades is anti-competitive, the Office of Fair Trading said Monday. Sir Gordon Borrie, director-general of fair trading, said the 24-hour delay in reporting large deals deprives the market of information that could affect the price of stocks. It also gives trading opportunities to those market makers involved in the deals which are denied to their competitors, Borrie said. The exchange decided in early 1989 to postpone the reporting of trades of over 100,000 pounds, or $164,000 until 24 hours after completion of the transaction. Market makers had complained that instantaneous publication of large share deals on the Stock Exchange Automated Quotation system spoiled liquidity and led to volatility in share prices. Borrie said he had not uncovered any evidence that liquidity was affected or that the delay reduced volatility. The director-general sent his report to Trade Secretary Nicholas Ridley to decide what action, if any, the government should take.

DOC.HEAD: Say Sluggish Steel, Defense Industries Drag Down Profits
DOC.TEXT: LTV Corp. reported a 42 percent decrease in first quarter earnings Monday, blaming lower profits from its steel and defense industries. The Dallas-based company, which is operating under bankruptcy court protection, said earnings for the quarter ended March 31 were $44.2 million, or 29 cents per share, compared with $76.6 million, or 54 cents a share, for the same period last year. Revenues dropped to $1.49 billion from $1.61 billion. Steel profits fell from $87.1 million to $41.1 million while earnings from missile and electronics slipped from $6.6 million to $6.2 million. Energy products income grew from $1 million to $1.7 million. The aircraft products group, which makes parts of the B-2 stealth bomber, lost $4.3 million in the quarter, compared with a $25.1 million loss last year. Chairman Raymond A. Hay said the decline in steel profits was caused by higher costs, lower selling prices and lower volume. LTV filed for protection under Chapter 11 of the federal bankruptcy code in 1986 and plans to emerge as a much smaller company, although no reorganization plan has been filed. LTV already has sold off much of its steel operations. The bankruptcy filing also is the basis for a key Supreme Court case over the company's claim that it cannot afford to pay pension benefits, leaving the federal insurance fund Pensions Benefit Guaranty Corp. liable for $2.3 billion. A decision on that case is expected by the end of June, Hay said.

DOC.HEAD: Posts 6 Percent Drop in 1st-Qtr Earnings
DOC.TEXT: The Travelers Corp. on Monday reported a 6 percent drop in first-quarter net income, citing soft market conditions in the property-casualty business. The insurance giant reported first-quarter net income of $92 million, or 87 cents per share, compared to $98 million, or 96 cents per share, for the same period a year ago. Total revenues for the quarter ended March 31 were $3.2 billion, the same as a year ago. Net investment income fell $9 million to $860 million. Premiums were $2.1 billion, compared to $2 billion for the same quarter a year ago. Net income for the property-casualty commercial lines was $42 million, compared to $56 million for the first quarter a year ago. Premiums were $833 million, compared to $860 million for last year's first quarter. ``We believe the long-term outlook for property-casualty commercial lines is excellent,'' said Edward H. Budd, chairman and chief executive. ``We are managing through this cycle with steady increases in prices, and are strengthening further our relationships with producers and customers with strong loss control services.'' Property-casualty personal lines posted a net loss of $4 million, compared to net income of $7 million a year ago. Premiums rose to $409 million, compared to $398 million a year earlier, as price increases offset a decline in the number of policies written. Net income for the managed care and employee benefits nearly doubled to $22 billion, compared $12 million in the first quarter of 1989. Net income for the asset management and pension services was $29 million, compared to $14 million for the first quarter of 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Soybeans Close Lower, Wheat Futures Advance
DOC.TEXT: Soybean futures prices closed slightly lower Monday on the Chicago Board of Trade amid profit taking after last week's big gains. Wheat futures rose strongly on frost fears while corn futures ended mixed. Soybean futures surged more than 30 cents a bushel last week, partly on speculation that last week's hot, dry weather might set the tone for the growing season. The drought fears were dispelled, though, by National Weather Service Forecasts for cooler, wetter weather in the region this week and normal to above-normal rainfall in the Midwest from May through July. ``The main feature was a little profit-taking,'' said Victor Lespinasse, a grain futures trader with Dean Witter Reynolds in Chicago. Wheat futures prices rose amid concerns about the possibility of freezing temperatures in the Central Plains this week, although many do not expect temperatures to fall enough to significantly damage the Kansas winter wheat crop. The Agriculture Department's weekly export inspections report, released after the close, indicated last week's loadings of wheat and soybeans for export were above market expectations, which could prompt some buying in those markets on Tuesday. At the close, wheat futures were 2 cents to 5\ cents higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.72{ a bushel; corn was 1{ cents lower to 1\ cents higher with May at $2.81\ a bushel; oats were 1{ cents to 3 cents higher with May at $1.65\ a bushel; soybeans were 1{ cents to 3 cents lower with May at $6.33 a bushel.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Air Subsidiary Reports $21.3 Million First-Quarter Profit
DOC.TEXT: Continental Airlines on Monday reported first-quarter earnings of $21.3 million, vs. a loss of $16.5 million in the same period a year ago. Continental, a subsidiary of Houston-based Texas Air Corp., said revenues in the January-to-March period were $1.27 billion, up slightly from $1.24 billion the previous year. ``In an environment of higher fuel costs and substantially worsened results being reported by most airlines, we are very gratified with Continental's first quarter results,'' Frank Lorenzo, chairman of both Continental and the parent company, said in a statement. ``These results continue to reflect the progress made by our employees in providing our premier product, and augurs well for continued product and financial improvement in the 1990s.'' Texas Air also owns Eastern Airlines, which has been functioning under bankruptcy court protection since employees struck in March 1989. On April 18 a federal bankruptcy judge seized control of Eastern from Texas Air, partly because of what he called the parent company's mismanagement of the airline. Eastern is now run by a court-appointed trustee. Continental noted the latest results included special items totaling $69.7 million, which it described as litigation settlement proceeds. Special items in the year-ago period were $30.6 million. Continental normally reports its earnings as part of the quarterly financial statement of Texas Air. But spokesman Art Kent said Monday the Texas Air financial report was being delayed while company officials assess the effect of the bankruptcy court's decision to take control of Eastern. ``We don't know where we are in terms of the deconsolidation of Eastern,'' Kent said.

DOC.HEAD: Venture to Be Formed to Distribute U.S. Bond Prices
DOC.TEXT: A trade association of bond dealers has announced plans for a joint venture to supply prices 24 hours a day, responding to a longstanding government request for improved distribution of market information. Among those eligible to participate in the joint venture are 44 primary dealers and seven interbroker dealers, said the Public Securities Association. Within 60 days of formation the venture could begin to disseminate price information, said PSA general counsel Fran Bermanzohn. Primary dealers buy and sell government bonds and participate in Treasury auctions; interbroker dealers execute trades for securities firms but not for the general public. The move was overwhelmingly approved by the PSA's primary dealers committee last Friday at a meeting in White Sulphur Springs, Va. The jointventure would negotiate to sell the data to several electronic information systems. Currently, brokers get bond quotes from financial data services such as Telerate Inc. and Reuters Holdings PLC, among others. The government has been pressuring brokers to make price information more widely available to the public. The General Accounting Office made the recommendation several years ago. The joint venture ``is being done in large measure in response to a regulatory mandate,'' Bermanzohn said. ``Many dealers take the position that the (price) information is already out there.'' The prices available from the venture would be ``real time'' quotes, which show the last sale price as trades are executed between dealers. ``The group decided that the best prices would be from the industry as a whole as opposed to any group forming together to provide a number,'' said Thomas Pura, who chairs the PSA's goverment and federal agency division. Many providers of bond prices have exclusive arrangements with interbroker dealers. Telerate, for example, has a multiple year contract with the Cantor Fitzgerald brokerage to provide exclusive quotes on Telerate screens. The Associated Press has a similar arrangment with Bloomberg Financial Markets, which in turn is supplied by Merrill Lynch. Pura noted that while the price information currently available is ``very good,'' the new system will provide even more information. ``Will they be significantly different? No, but people feel better having broader access to price information,'' Pura said.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Negotiating for Japanese Stamping Presses in Canada
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. is negotiating with Mitsubishi International Corp. on a deal to put a stamping plant next to the U.S. automaker's assembly factory in Bramalea, Ontario, the company said Monday. If the deal is struck, it would put a highly advanced stamping facility at the plant, which is likely to make Chrysler's next generation of midsize cars, code named the LH and LX. Chrysler spokesman Alan Miller confirmed a report in the weekly journal Metalworking News that the two automakers were negotiating. But he declined to confirm or deny a report in the journal that Mitsubishi would equip the plant. ``Chrysler will operate the stamping facility and Mitsubishi will provide technical support,'' Miller said, declining to say if technical support meant stamping presses. Metalworking News quoted unidentified U.S. pressmaking company executives as saying they were disappointed that Chrysler would turn to its main Japanese partner for the plant's presses. Recently, Chrysler Chairman Lee Iacocca has been on a six-city tour touting the company's vehicles, saying they were just as good as Japanese cars. The LH-LX project is to produce a car by 1992 for the 1993 model year.

DOC.HEAD: Reports 18.6 Percent Increase in 1st-Qtr Profit
DOC.TEXT: Hershey Foods Corp. said Monday its first-quarter earnings rose 18.6 percent, buoyed by sales of chocolate and pasta products. Company officials said earnings for the quarter that ended April 1 rose to $47.1 million, or 52 cents per share, up from $39.7 million, or 44 cents a share, in the same quarter in 1989. Sales rose 19.1 percent to $681.2 million from $572.2 million a year earlier. Richard A. Zimmerman, Hershey's chairman and chief executive, said sales were spurred by the performance of Hershey Chocolate U.S.A. and the Hershey Pasta Group, along with the acquisition in February of Ronzoni Foods Corp. Lower costs also contributed to the record performance, he said. Hershey also announced plans to buy back about 1.4 million shares of common stock and to use the shares to pay future costs of employee benefits.
Stock prices were mixed today in a session marked by some scattered gains among the blue chips. Shortly before the close, the Dow Jones average of 30 industrials was up 13.96 points at 2,659.01.

DOC.HEAD: Major Software Maker Sets Policy To Standardize Products
DOC.TEXT: Computer Associates International Inc., one of the world's largest computer software makers, said Monday it will standardize its products to make it easier for companies to use any of them on any brand of computer. Computer Associates, based in Garden City, N.Y., has grown primarily by acquiring other software makers. In the process, it has acquired a hodgepodge of products. The company said it will work to standardize is products so that software made specifically for one brand of computer will be able to work on another brand computer. It gave no timetable for the changes. Computer Associates said the changes will allow a company with several brands of computers to choose an applications program, such as a spreadsheet program, that will work on all the machines. Such portability of programs is becoming increasingly important as companies link their computers in networks. As part of its new strategy, Computer Associates said it will adhere to software standards established by International Business Machines Corp. and Digital Equipment Corp., as well as other industry standards. IBM and Digital are the largest and second-largest computer makers in the world.

DOC.HEAD: No Change in Corporate Fuel Economy Regulations Soon, EPA Head Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 5-7 bgng, For instance ... to CORRECT that Ford contemplated sted moved the cars to import side. Picks up 7th graf pvs, The current ... SUBS 10th graf pvs, During the ... to CORRECT buyback prioce to $700 sted $7,000.
DOC.TEXT: The federal Environmental Protection Agency plans to let automakers keep counting big, gas-gulping cars as imports _ no matter where the car is assembled, EPA Administrator William Reilly said Monday. General Motors Corp. and Ford Motor Co. have used the provision to raise their domestic corporate average fuel economy, or CAFE, by changing the manufacturing site of some major components in large cars and counting them as part of the company's import fleet. ``I don't wish to signal any substantive change in approach (on CAFE) at this time,'' Reilly said at a news conference before addressing the Economic Club of Detroit. Domestic and import fleets are counted separately under CAFE regulations. The amount of domestically made components determines if a car is counted in the domestic or import fleet. For instance, Ford planned last year to make the 1991 models of its Ford Crown Victoria and Mercury Grand Marquis, built in St. Thomas, Ontario, count in the company's domestic CAFE fleet as their domestic content dropped below 75 percent. Such a switch would have made it easier for Ford's domestic fleet to meet CAFE regulations by increasing the percentage of more fuel-efficient cars on its domestic fleet. Ford's imported cars far surpassed CAFE requirements, leaving room for the less fuel-efficient cars. Ford spokesman Dick Judy said Monday those plans changed and for now, the cars remain in the domestic CAFE column. The current CAFE standard is 27.5 mpg for both fleets. Reilly was in town for two days of meetings with automotive industry executives, officials of the United Auto Workers union and EPA officials in Ann Arbor, where the agency operates its Motor Vehicle Emissions Laboratory. During the news conference and in a speech to the Economic Club, Reilly pitched the Bush administration's Clean Air proposals and praised an oil company's plan to buy, for $700 each, cars made before 1971 when the government began regulating tailpipe emissions. ``The faster you replace the older cars with new ones, the faster you'll clean up the air,'' he said. However, Reilly added that addition measures are needed to cut tailpipe emissions because so many new cars have been added to the highways and cars are being driven more. Automakers have balked at further cutting emissions, saying that it would be very expensive while yielding only minor pollution decreases.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Mixed, Gold Lower
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended mixed Monday against key foreign currencies in thin, abbreviated worldwide trading. Gold prices declined here and abroad. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for May delivery settled at $368.40 a troy ounce, down $2.70 from late Friday. Republic National Bank of New York quoted a late bid for gold at $368.70 an ounce, down $2.80. Currency dealers said trading was quiet, with Japanese markets closed for a national holiday. Woodland said traders were marking time in anticipation of several key economic and political events set for this week. The U.S. government, for instance, plans to release reports on March construction spending, the March index of leading economic indicators, and April unemployment _ data which traders hope would shed more light on the direction of the economy and interest rates. On Wednesday, the Treasury also announces its quarterly debt refunding. Overseas, traders are expected to pay close attention to the local government elections in Britian as a test of Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's controversial reform of local taxes. The elections could effect the British pound. In West Germany, Bundesbank officials are set to meet this week, although traders said it was unlikely they'll move to raise interest rates in that country. Higher rates tend to support a currency. Late dollar rates in Europe compared with Friday's rates: 1.6787 West German marks, up from 1.6755; 1.4512 Swiss francs, down from 1.4560; 5.6335 French francs, up from 5.6240; 1.8884 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8845; 1,230.50 Italian lire, up from 1,228.00, and 1.1649 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1632.
