DOC.HEAD: Ames Replaces CEO Following Chapter 11 Filing
DOC.TEXT: Ames Department Stores Inc., which filed for federal bankruptcy protection last week, on Monday replaced its chief executive officer with a merchandising veteran likely to trim staff and close stores to revive the ailing discounter. Stephen L. Pistner, former chairman at Montgomery Ward & Co. and president at Dayton-Hudson Corp.'s Target discount stores, was named by the board of directors to replace Peter B. Hollis, who resigned as CEO and vice chairman. Pistner also will become chairman if his appointment is approved by a New York bankruptcy court. Pistner, 58, is known as a decisive, intelligent businessman who pioneered the concept of power departments _ stores within stores that specialize in particular kinds of merchandise like clothing or major appliances, said Howard Davidowitz, chairman of a New York retail consulting firm. ``He's a hard-nosed businessman and a very well-respected retailer who will probably use an ax rather than a butter knife on Ames,'' said Alan Millstein, publisher of a monthly newsletter for retailers and manufacturers. ``It's a very courageous act on the part of the board,'' added Millstein, who said the appointment will also assuage creditors and suppliers who are nervous about the company's ability to pay its bills. In a brief interview from New York, Pistner said he would not close stores or make other major decisions until he evaluates the company. He said it would take a good 18 months to put it on more solid financial footing. Ames, based in Rocky Hill, Conn., filed for protection from creditors last Wednesday, listing $1.44 billion in liabilities and $1.66 billion in assets. It posted a $228 million loss for the fiscal year ended Jan. 27 and owes $14 million to its largest creditor. The nation's fourth-largest discounter, Ames operates more than 600 stores in 20 states and employs 55,000 people. It has annual sales of more than $4 billion. Experts trace its problems to the 392-store Zayre chain, which Ames bought in 1988 for $788 million. Some experts said Hollis must bear some of the responsibility for Ames' problems because he presided during the Zayre acquisition. ``It was time to take Hollis out of the job because Hollis was a financial man but didn't understand the merchandising that was necessary to attract customers to the stores,'' said Walter Loeb, a New York-based retail consultant. Davidowitz agreed: ``It's very important for creditors because the old management simply had no credibility. The creditors have been hurt very badly, and when people are hurt they want a pound of flesh and they also want to see new faces. ``Steve is a known quantity. He's been successful in retailing for a long time in visible major jobs.'' Pistner joined Dayton-Hudson in 1970, taking responsibility for its Target chain in 1973. He was named president and chief operating officer of Dayton-Hudson in 1977. He left in 1971 to become president and chief executive of Montgomery Ward. He left Montgomery Ward in 1985 to become chairman of McCrory Corp., the variety store business owned by Rapid-American. Pistner left McCrory in 1988 and has spent the last two years pursuing business enterprises, including a joint venture in the Soviet Union that he would not disclose.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Prices Mixed
DOC.TEXT: Energy futures finished mixed Monday and wholesale gasoline prices sagged amid skepticism that OPEC can devise a way to curb the cartel's crude production. Home heating oil prices were bid sharply higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange in trading tied to the May contract's expiration. Home heating oil for May delivery shot up 2.79 cents to 56.53 cents a gallon, adding to Friday's gain of 0.67 cent. Market analysts said traders bought to cover earlier commitments to sell the contract. This short covering of the expiring May contract spurred buying of later months. June heating oil, which becomes the near-month contract on Tuesday, rose 0.70 cent to 51.45 cents a gallon. Among other refined products traded on the exchange, the May contract for unleaded regular gasoline tumbled 0.95 cent to 60.00 cents a gallon after falling 0.39 cent on Friday. The June contract fell 0.33 cent to 59.84 cents a gallon. Subsequent months lost slightly less ground. The June contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude oil, settled at $18.54 a 42-gallon barrel, the same level as Friday when it had gained 7 cents. Contracts for later delivery posted modest gains. And natural gas for June delivery closed at $1.565 per million British thermal units, up from $1.550 on Friday. Energy analysts said the weakness in gasoline prices indicated the market isn't expecting much from the scheduled May 2 emergency OPEC meeting. James Steel, an analyst at Refco Inc., said the season of peak gasoline demand is approaching. If the market believed OPEC could bring about a significant supply reduction, prices of gasoline would have been bid higher, he said. Ministers from members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries will gather in Geneva on Wednesday to plot a strategy aimed at shoring up world oil prices. The recent price slump is believed to stem in part from overproduction by several OPEC member states. The ministers are expected to seek a voluntary cut of 1 million barrels a day in output during May and June.

DOC.HEAD: Ministers Seek to Prop up Oil Prices
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 7th graf pvs, North Sea Brent ..., with one graf to UPDATE with settlement price in New York. Picks up 8th graf pvs, Analysts estimate ...
DOC.TEXT: OPEC ministers meet in emergency session Wednesday in a strategy session to support oil prices, which have fallen sharply in recent weeks because Persian Gulf members are believed to be violating output quotas. Oil industry analysts speculate the ministers are aiming at their meeting in Geneva for a voluntary cut of 1 million barrels a day in output during May and June. The quota violators, said to be Saudi Arabia, Kuwait and the United Arab Emirates, would bear the brunt of the cut in current production, they predicted. ``I think the market needs to see something at least like that to sustain prices,'' said Lucy Mullins, an analyst with the London investment firm Barclays de Zoete Wedd Ltd. Such a cut likely would only steady prices, because the market already has strengthened somewhat on hopes the meeting will produce results, analysts said. Whether such cuts will actually take place is uncertain. ``The actual follow-through in the spot market may be quite limited,'' said Stephen Turner, an oil analyst with the London investment firm Smith New Court PLC. North Sea Brent Blend, the most widely traded international crude oil, fetched a spot price of $16.45 a barrel in London on Monday afternoon, up 5 cents from Friday. In the U.S. market, the benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude settled at $18.54 a 42-gallon barrel Monday, unchanged from Friday's close. Analysts estimate the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries currently is producing about 23.5 million barrels a day, exceeding the ceiling of 22.1 million barrels a day the cartel set for the first half of the year. The 13-nation cartel accounts for a substantial portion of the world oil market and increasingly influences prices in the United States, where imports now account for about half the nation's consumption. The OPEC meeting was called April 19 by Sadek Boussena, Algeria's oil minister and cartel president, because of concern about an unusually sharp price slide that pushed prices down to the $15-$16 barrel range, vs. more than $20 earlier in the year. The meeting is expected to last one or two days. The gathering officially is of the eight-member monitoring committee, which only reviews markets and makes recommendations. But all ministers are expected to attend, which means a full emergency conference can be called immediately. But the ministers aren't expected to grapple with their official quotas and minimum reference price of $18 a barrel until they hold their full, regular midyear conference on June 25. Boussena is spearheading intensive contacts among OPEC members to reach consensus on voluntary cuts before Wednesday, the Middle East Economic Survey, a Nicosia-based oil industry newsletter, reported Monday. A contentious gathering could have a negative impact on oil markets. The newsletter said the United Arab Emirates, one of the main overproducers, ``is regarded as the toughest nut to crack, given the UAE's track record and the easy marketability of its high quality crude.'' Kuwait's oil minister, Ali Khalifah Al-Sabah, apparently has indicated that Kuwait will trim production if other producers do so, the newsletter said. ``Saudi Arabia would probably have a similar position, of readiness to contribute to an agreed temporary cutback, but not to go below its current quota,'' it said. Analysts say the overproduction has created a glut just as demand is weakening, which usually happens in the spring prior to heavy gasoline use during the summer driving season. This has prompted the unusually sharp price slide, and sparked fears that prices will collapse as in 1986, when they fell as low as $10 a barrel in a glutted market. Analysts believe Saudi Arabia, the world's leading oil exporter, is producing about 300,000 barrels a day above its daily quota of 5.4 million barrels. The United Arab Emirates is said to producing an estimated 2 million barrels a day, nearly double its 1.095 million-barrel quota. Kuwait is believed to be producing some 300,000 barrels a day over its quota of 1.5 million barrels. OPEC's members are Algeria, Ecuador, Gabon, Indonesia, Iran, Iraq, Kuwait, Libya, Nigeria, Qatar, Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Venezuela.

DOC.HEAD: Rates Rise at Latest Auction
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf pvs, The Treasury ... to make official Treasury Department CORRECTION that six-month bill rate was 8.03, sted 8.05. Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Interest rates on short-term Treasury securities rose in Monday's auction. The Treasury Department sold $8.4 billion in three-month bills at an average discount rate of 7.91 percent, up from 7.78 percent last week. Another $8.4 billion was sold in six-month bills at an average discount rate of 8.03 percent, up from 7.91 percent last week. The rates were the highest since three-month bills sold for 7.77 percent on March 19, and six-month bills averaged 8.08 percent on last June 19. The new discount rates understate the actual return to investors _ 8.18 percent for three-month bills with a $10,000 bill selling for $9,800.10 and 8.49 percent for a six-month bill selling for $9,594.00. In a separate report, the Federal Reserve said Monday that the average yield for one-year Treasury bills, the most popular index for making changes in adjustable rate mortgages, rose to 8.57 percent last week, up from 8.41 percent the previous week.

DOC.HEAD: SEC Wins Court Order Against Penny Stock Firm
DOC.TEXT: A federal judge extended a court order Monday barring a Manhattan securities brokerage from penny stock sales activities that regulators allege are illegal. U.S. District Judge Kevin T. Duffy in New York issued an opinion that temporarily bars Wellshire Securities Inc., two of its top officers and two former employees from further alleged securities law violations. ``The record is replete with evidence that Wellshire employed misleading and misrepresentative tactics to defraud its investors,'' Duffy's opinion said in part. A lawyer for Willshire maintained there was ``no fraudulent activity.'' Duffy's decision, extended a ban he issued last month in response to a Securities and Exchange Commission request, which accused Wellshire of using high pressure and deceptive sales practices to induce investors to buy risky, over-the-counter securities. Penny stocks are low cost, high risk securities _ usually issued by new or small companies. The stocks, which sell for as little as a few cents, are prone to fraud and manipulation because information about them is hard for investors to obtain and verify. In March, the SEC filed a civil lawsuit alleging that Wellshire Securities operated as a penny stock ``boiler room'' from July 1988 to the present. Boiler rooms are high pressure sales operations that use banks of telephones, staffed by sales personnel who use questionable tactics to persuade investors to buy risky stocks. ``We feel it wasn't a boiler room operation,'' said Mitchell Lampert, attorney for Wellshire Securities. ``My client runs an honest business, within the confines of the law. He feels there was no fraudulent activity. We're unhappy that the opinion is issued.'' The SEC lawsuit charged that Wellshire made exorbitant price predictions, gave out false information about stocks, made unauthorized sales and tried to stop clients from selling their securities when the price rose. In one case mentioned in the SEC complaint, a 68-year-old retiree was persuaded to borrow money from a home equity loan to buy securities. Duffy's decision applied to Wellshire's president, Robert Cohen; Carol Martino, the firm's executive vice president; Joseph Jenkins Jr., a former Wellshire broker and Alan Diamond, a former Wellshire trader. Also barred from further alleged securities law violations was Ventura Inc., a Needham, Mass., leasing company, whose securities was one of the penny stocks sold by Wellshire. Wellshire, with six branch offices in New York, New Jersey, Florida, Georgia and Germany, has about 50,000 customer accounts and employs 100 brokers, the SEC said.

DOC.HEAD: Buffett Takes to Former Vaudeville Stage for Annual Meeting
DOC.TEXT: Multibillionaire Warren Buffett took to the stage of an ornate, renovated theater Monday to dispense his financial philosophy spiced with comic asides worthy of the vaudeville comics who once trod the boards. More than 900 people crowded into the main floor and balconies of the Orpheum Theater for Berkshire Hathaway Inc.'s annual meeting, which is more like a down-home gathering of friends than a feisty exchange between management and shareholders. A brief business session preceded two hours of friendly questions aimed at chairman Buffett and vice chairman Charles Munger. Berkshire Hathaway, valued at $4.9 billion, is an investment concern that has holdings ranging from stock in big-name companies like Coca Cola Inc. and Gillette Co. to interests in a candy maker and an Omaha furniture mart. Berkshire Hathaway's annual meeting is considered noteworthy partly because of the enormous respect commanded by Buffett, who cultivated the company from a New England textile mill a quarter-century ago into one of the most successful American enterprises. Buffet sometimes is called the ``Oracle of Omaha.'' His company is also followed closely because its stock is among the priciest. On Monday, it traded at $6,700 a share on the New York Stock Exchange, up $25 from the Friday close. Buffett and Munger sipped Cherry Coke and Diet Coke and munched on See's candies as they fielded questions ranging from the possibility of a stock split to Buffett's philosophy of investing in well-managed companies that he understands. Problems with microphones as the meeting got under way prompted audience laughter as Buffett said, ``Now you see why we don't invest in technology stocks.'' Buffett briskly concluded the official business of re-electing officers with nary a word of dissent or discussion. ``With the events of Eastern Europe, this may be the last bastion of undiluted authoritarianism left,'' said Buffett, 59. Buffett said he doubts the company's stock will be split ``in the unforeseeable future.'' The company tries to attract a specific type of investor, one with the same type of long-term investment strategy, Buffett said. ``Any way you slice it, it's the same pie,'' Buffett said. ``We think better people are sitting down to eat that piece.'' When one shareholder asked Buffett about his view on the Federal Reserve Bank and interest rates, Buffett turned to Munger. ``We don't think a lot about macro economics ... We try to do something sound,'' Munger said. ``We have no view about interest rates. We don't know and if we did, it probably wouldn't do us any good.'' Asked about the possibility of foreign investments with the integration of the European Common Market in 1992, Buffett said Berkshire has no rule against foreign investing. But he said he's not enthusiastic about it. ``We have a $3 trillion equity market in the United States. If we can't make money there...'' Buffett said. If he were asked to help change the securities laws, Buffett said, he would focus on the tax code, which he said presently encourages companies to go into debt and influences corporate behavior. ``People stretched on the edge of debt don't behave very well,'' Buffett said.

DOC.HEAD: Unocal Net Falls 11 Pct
DOC.TEXT: Unocal Corp. said Monday its first-quarter profits fell 11.5 percent compared with results a year ago that included a $46 million after-tax gain from various natural gas contract settlements. For the January-March quarter, the energy company earned $77 million, or 33 cents per share, compared with $87 million, or 37 cents per share, in first-quarter 1989. Revenue edged up to $2.64 billion from $2.63 billion. Unocal Chairman Richard Stegemeier said the latest results reflected higher worldwide crude oil prices, lower interest expense and improved shale oil operations. Those positive factors were partially offset by chemical earnings, which fell to $6 million from $16 million.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with closing prices throughout.
DOC.TEXT: Blue-chip issues showed signs of recovering from their recent swoon, but the rest of the stock market managed no better than a mixed showing in a slow session Monday. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials, which had fallen 106.75 points over the past two weeks, recovered 11.71 to 2,656.76. The average finished April with a net loss of 50.45 points. Declining issues held a narrow edge on advances in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed stocks, with 732 up, 749 down and 497 unchanged. Volume on the floor of the Big Board hit a three-week low of 122.75 million shares, against 130.65 million in the previous session. Nationwide, consolidated volume in NYSE-listed issues, including trades in those stocks on regional exchanges and in the over-the-counter market, totaled 148.20 million shares. Analysts said worries over rising interest rates and inflation continued to set the mood on Wall Street. Traders were looking ahead uneasily to the Treasury's quarterly auction of bonds and notes, details of which are to be announced this week. There has been much talk that long-term interest rates, already at their highest level in nearly a year, may rise further as a new supply of government securities comes to market. The first readings on the state of the economy in April also are due this week _ a monthly survey of corporate purchasing managers on Tuesday, and the Labor Department's employment report on Friday. Brokers expect these figures to support recent evidence that business activity has picked up a bit lately. International Business Machines ranked as one of the session's standout performers, gaining 1| to 109 in active trading. Chairman John F. Akers said IBM was looking for a substantial improvement in its results for 1990 and had begun to see the financial benefits of a restructuring it undertook at the end of 1989. Another contributor to the blue chips' strength was Boeing, up 1 at 69}. The company posted higher operating earnings for the first quarter, declared a 3-for-2 stock split and increased its dividend. Elsewhere among the big-name industrials, Philip Morris rose { to 42; Bristol-Myers Squibb 1 to 56[; American Telephone & Telegraph \ to 40[, and Exxon, up \ at 45\. Baltimore Bancorp, subject of a $17-a-share bid by First Maryland Bancorp, jumped 3\ to 15. As measured by Wilshire Associates' index of more than 5,000 actively traded stocks, the market increased $10.99 billion, or 0.35 percent, in value. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks added .75 to 181.49. Standard & Poor's industrial index rose 2.10 to 385.44, and S&P's 500-stock composite index was up 1.69 at 330.80. The NASDAQ composite index for the over-the-counter market gained 2.09 to 420.07. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index closed at 343.10, up .46.

DOC.HEAD: May Be Entitled to Tax Break on $400 Million in Civil Fund
DOC.TEXT: Michael Milken may be entitled to a tax break on at least part of $400 million the fallen junk bond king is placing in a government fund to compensate injured investors, legal experts said Monday. Such a deduction may appear startling for an admitted felon _ Milken pleaded guilty last week to six criminal securities and tax law violations _ but it could be perfectly legal under Internal Revenue Service guidelines. Under his settlement of civil and criminal charges, the former Drexel Burnham Lambert Inc. executive agreed to pay $200 million in fines and $400 million in restitution for investors who can prove they were defrauded by his activities. Presuming that Milken has reported his income faithfully and complied with federal income tax laws _ and no one says he hasn't _ he already has paid taxes on the $400 million. Milken in effect would be returning money that never belonged to him but on which he has paid Uncle Sam, tax experts said. ``That's not too shocking,'' said Marvin A. Chirelstein, a Columbia University tax law professor. ``It just reverses the tax consequences. It puts the situation where it's as if it had not happened.'' According to court papers, Milken made $1.1 billion from 1983 to 1987. His advisers claim he paid nearly one-half of the amount in taxes. Milken's net worth has been estimated by Fortune magazine at $1.2 billion. Under the IRS tax code, civil or criminal defendants are not allowed to deduct fines or penalties paid to the government for breaking the law. Milken's $200 million fine to the U.S. Treasury falls under that provision. But the code generally allows deductions for the payment of compensatory damages, as well as fees or expenses incurred in a legal defense, which can be considered part of normal business operations. However, if the government could prove that the money being returned was obtained by violating some ``sharply defined public policy,'' that would open the door to preventing a tax deduction, experts said. How big a tax break might occur? Well, assuming Milken is in the highest tax bracket, the total could amount to a third of the restitution fund _ about $133 million. No one involved in the case believes that will happen. But the public appearance that Milken was getting a good deal at taxpayers' expense might be less than flattering for government prosecutors who arranged the plea bargain. New York tax attorney Michael Saltzman said the argument against a deduction would be, ``It's supposed to be part of the punishment. Why would the government be picking up a part of that?'' No claims have been made against the money by the IRS. Milken doesn't even have to fork over the $400 million until 60 days after his scheduled Oct. 1 sentencing. How much actually gets paid out might not be resolved for years. The restitution fund settles allegations by the Securities and Exchange Commission that included insider trading and other frauds not included in the criminal plea bargain. Any investor claim is eligible for a piece of the fund. Under the terms of the settlement, any money not dished out to investors after seven years will be turned over to the Treasury _ and presumably could then be classified as a fine, which would not be deductible. ``It seems to me in Milken's interest to see that as much of that gets paid out to those who justifiably lay claim to damage,'' said tax attorney Lawrence Feld, chairman of an American Bar Association panel on civil and criminal tax penalties. An IRS spokesman said the law is not clear on what tax consequences might arise in cases where restitution is not earmarked for a particular individual. The spokesman, who asked not to be named, declined to discuss the Milken case. A spokesman for Milken also declined to comment. Barry Goldsmith, SEC desputy chief litigation counsel, said tax deductibility was not a factor in the Milken settlement. ``Our job is to get the money,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Belzbergs Claim Seat on Armstrong Board
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf pvs, `The state... to CORRECT that law governs profits seized in takeover raid; PICKS UP 7th graf, `The law...
DOC.TEXT: The Belzberg family of Canada claimed Monday to have won a seat on the board of Armstrong World Industries Inc., the company that prompted Pennsylvania's tough new anti-takeover law. The disclosure came at the Armstrong's annual shareholders meeting just three days after the state enacted the law designed to stymie corporate raiders. Armstrong Chairman William H. Adams said he was confident at least three of the four incumbent board members seeking re-election were retained. He acknowledged the possibility that the Belzbergs had landed one spot on the 13-member board, but added it would take until at least May 11 to get a final vote tally. The Belzbergs own a 10.7 percent stake in Armstrong. They have waged a proxy fight to seat four directors and change company rules to weaken the board's authority to block a hostile takeover. The state law, which took effect immediately, is intended to discourage corporate raiders by seizing profits from a takeover attempt, restricting voting rights and preserving labor contracts if corporate ownership changes hands. The law was drafted last year after the Belzbergs declared an interest in Armstrong, which makes flooring and building materials. Armstrong management has declined to meet with the Belzbergs. The family has criticized the company for supporting the anti-takeover law and accused management of working against shareholder interests. Armstrong has characterized the Belzbergs as inept managers who have driven companies virtually into the ground, compromising shareholder earnings. Addressing the meeting, Adams said the anti-takeover law would not alter the company's relationship with stockholders, but would deter raiders who ``want to line their own pockets.'' Adams said the board had adopted a policy ensuring that stockholder interests would not be supplanted by other constituents. The action apparently stems from concerns about the anti-takeover law, which allows management to put the interests of employees, suppliers or the community above shareholders in making corporate decisions, including weighing takeover bids. During the meeting, Adams was questioned by only one stockholder, who asked how much the company had spent promoting the anti-takeover bill. Adams said he did not have an exact figure, but that it would be under $500,000. When asked why the directors had not met with the Belzbergs, he said: ``The past operating practices of the Belzbergs were not encouraging us to meet with them.'' The proposed changes to the company's bylaws have been held up in a court challenge and were not on the agenda. But the company took a non-binding vote to gauge shareholder sentiment. The issue could be revisited, pending the outcome of the suit. One proposal would allow a shareholder or group owning 20 percent or more of the stock to call special shareholder meetings. The company says shareholders can ask the board to call meetings, at its discretion. Representatives of First City Diversified Inc., a Belzberg entity, said they believed the changes would pass overwhelmingly. It was not clear when, or if, the vote would be released. First City's assertion that it had seated Michael C. Jensen, a Harvard Business School professor, on the Armstrong board was based on its owning more than 10 percent of the company's stock, in addition to proxies it solicited, officials said. Other Belzberg nominees were Richard E. Bennett, chairman of Scovill Inc.; Greta E. Marshall, general partner of the Marshall Plan and a former investment manager for the California Public Employees Retirement System; and Frederick R. Warren-Boulton, a resident scholar at the American Enterprise Institute. The incumbent board members seeking re-election were Barbara Hackman Franklin of Washington, D.C.; Joseph L. Jones of Lancaster; Robert F. Patton of Pittsburgh; and Harry K. Wells of Towson, Md.

DOC.HEAD: Wholesale Antitrust Attack on Mergers Not Expected
DOC.NOTE: Eds: CORRECTS `failed' to `faltered' in next-to-last graf
DOC.TEXT: A Supreme Court decision that states and individuals have the power to challenge completed mergers on anti-competitive grounds isn't likely to arouse a storm of attacks on other done deals, experts said Monday. ``Enforcement authorities appreciate the business world just can't function if transactions can be challenged five and 10 years later,'' said Georgetown University law professor Robert Pitofsky after the nation's highest court said it would allow California officials to try to block the merger of the Alpha Beta and Lucky grocery store chains. But the 9-0 ruling Monday nonetheless was expected to inject another note of caution into the already wary takeover market. The Supreme Court said any opponent of a merger, and not just the federal government, has the right to sue to force the divestiture of merged businesses. The decision does not negate the merger of Alpha Beta and Lucky; it sends the case back to court in California, where state officials must still prove at trial that the deal should be blocked. Pitofsky said California sought to block the merger because state officials did not get the support they wanted from the federal government, which had approved the $2.5 billion acquisition of Lucky Stores Inc. by Alpha Beta's parent, American Stores Co., in 1988. California officials contend that if the companies' 600 stores in the state are combined, consumers would end up paying $440 million extra each year because of reduced competition and higher prices. Despite California's victory, Lawrence J. White, a professor at the Stern Graduate School of Business at New York University, said, ``I don't think it is going to mean a grand unlocking'' of deals. Walter Adams, an economics professor at Michigan State University, agreed there wouldn't be a flood of litigation to undo done deals. But he said it's possible that some already-completed mergers will be challenged on a case-by-case basis. In addition, antitrust experts said, future deals likely will face more scrutiny. ``What this does is make the states a major player in mergers,'' said Pitofsky. Adams said, ``The state attorneys general have been extremely active to the extent that they legally could in opposing the merger wave'' and Monday's ruling gives local officials more ammunition. But the decision could have a chilling effect on dealmakers themselves, forcing them to think twice about proposing a buyout or merger that they know could run afoul of state officials. ``This in itself may do a great deal to slow down the (merger) movement,'' Adams predicted. Adams said a more aggressive stance on antitrust enforcement by the Bush administration following the more lenient Reagan era could be behind the Supreme Court's decision. ``The cop on the beat is no longer looking the other way,'' he said. The Monday ruling by the High Court was likely to further slow the takeover business, which has been dealt a series of blows over the past year. On Friday, for example, the Pennsylvania legislature enacted the toughest anti-takeover law in the country. Perhaps more important, the collapse of the junk bond market last fall has denied takeover investors access to enormous amounts of money for acquisitions. The risky high-yield bonds, which fueled the takeover boom of the 1980s, fell out of favor when the $6.7 billion debt-financed buyout of Federated Department Stores Inc. faltered in September. Without junk bonds, takeover activity has dropped off considerably.

DOC.HEAD: Commodity Futures Regulator to Join NY Mercantile Exchange
DOC.TEXT: Robert R. Davis, a member of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission since 1984, announced he was resigning Monday to take an executive position with the New York Mercantile Exchange. An economist, Davis was nomiated to the five-member CFTC by President Reagan. He said he will join the New York exchange as senior vice president for planning and development. In his letter of resignation to President Bush, Davis called the CFTC ``a model of good government that constructively channeled the `invisible hand' of the market and avoided laying on the 'dead hand' of excessive regulation.'' The CFTC, which oversees the futures industry, has come under fire in the wake of a major fraud scandal at the nation's two largest futures exchanges in Chicago. Critics in Congress and the administration have suggested merging the agency with the rival Securities and Exchange Commission or giving the SEC control over securities-related futures currently overseen by the CFTC. Davis, who has bachelors, masters and doctoral degrees in economics from Virginia Polytechnic Institute, served as senior economist for the Joint Economic Committee of Congress before his appointment to the CFTC. He also has served as a financial economist to the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation and a vice president at the Harris Bank in Chicago.

DOC.HEAD: Lawsuit on GM Layoffs Kept Alive
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 7th graf pvs, `Requested the ... to ADD bankruptcy case; PICKS UP 8th graf pvs, `Car-giant GM...; ADDS 4 grafs with reaction on lawusit against GM; No pickup
DOC.TEXT: The Supreme Court on Monday refused to kill a lawsuit against General Motors Corp. stemming from what a lower court called ``the highly charged environment of large-scale layoffs.'' The court, without comment, let stand rulings that the fraud and misrepresentation suit by 32 former employees of a GM subsidiary in Clinton, Miss., should go to trial. Those who sued had been employed at a Packard Electric plant in Clinton before GM in 1983 began laying off hundreds of workers there in response to sluggish demand for domestic automobiles. In other action, the court: _Gave state governments and consumers a potential pocketbook victory by ruling unanimously in a California case that they may use federal antitrust law to break up corporate mergers. _Let the government force thousands of Transportation Department employees to take random drug tests. The court, without comment, rejected arguments that such tests violate privacy rights. _Requested the Bush administration's views about Oklahoma's attempt to collect a sales tax on cigarettes and other items sold at a convenience store owned and run by an Indian tribe. The court said it wants to know what Justice Department lawyers think about a ruling that bars the imposition of such a tax. _Agreed to settle a bankruptcy dispute stemming from a fraud lawsuit against a Kansas City, Mo., businessman. The court said it will hear an appeal by two men who sued the businessman and are trying to collect a $525,000 judgment. The case turns on what standard of evidence applies. Car-giant GM negotiated a separation agreement with the employees' union under which workers could opt for a severance payment instead of having their seniority and rehire rights preserved. Under the so-called voluntary termination of employment plan, the 32 Packard Electric employees received payments of between $10,000 and $22,000 when leaving their jobs. Their suit alleges that at meetings to explain the severance plan, a GM representative said they could be rehired if new jobs were created. The employees allegedly were told they would have to apply like everyone else, without any consideration of seniority, but would be eligible for rehiring. New positions opened at the plant in 1985, but the 32 ex-employees were told the severance plan they had chosen made them ineligible for rehiring. The 32 employees sued in federal court, but based their suit on Mississippi law claims of fraud and misrepresentation. Lawyers for GM sought a dismissal, arguing that the proper forum was the National Labor Relations Board. Even if a court suit were allowed, GM said, the state law claims would be pre-empted by federal labor law. A federal trial judge and the 5th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals ruled against GM. The appeals court said the NLRB had no jurisdiction in the case. It characterized the case as one ``involving alleged promises made and broken in the highly charged environment of large-scale layoffs and shifts in the labor market.'' GM then sought Supreme Court review. While the original suit named 32 plaintiffs, Jackson attorney Richard Roberts III said it has been expanded to include about 50 former employees. ``We're delighted,'' Roberts said of the Supreme Court ruling. ``We look forward to proceeding with the lawsuit.'' He said a trial date was not immediately scheduled and refused to comment on whether he was discussing a settlement with GM lawyers. John Maciarz, a GM spokesman in Detroit, ``We're obviously disappointed, but the case has never been tried on its merits.''

DOC.HEAD: Greenspan Says Inventory Control a Factor in Heading Off Recession
DOC.TEXT: Change in the way manufacturers and others stock their inventories helped head off a recession at the beginning of the year, Federal Reserve Chairman Alan Greenspan told a group purchasing managers Monday. ``The obvious question is, what went wrong with the recession forecasts or, more exactly, what went right with the economy? While analysts can never be certain of such things, there is at least presumptive evidence that a major reason, perhaps the key reason, is the marked change in inventory behavior on the part of purchasing managers in manufacturing and elsewhere,'' Greenspan said. Speaking to the 75th annual conference of the National Association of Purchasing Management, Greenspan said changes in the ``inventory cycle'' are a factor in driving industrial activity in the nation. The economy began to show pre-recession symptoms in the second quarter of 1989, Greenspan said. By autumn, the signs pointing to a recession were more abundant, he said. The weakness in industrial activity bottomed out around the turn of the year, Greenspan said, without spreading to other areas of the economy. ``Most, if not all, past American recessions have been sparked, or at least aggravated by, large inventory swings,'' he said. Modern delivery methods, the use of computers to track inventory and predict demand, and the availability of goods internationally have helped prevent the cycle of overstocking and then cutting back, Greenspan said. That cycle, which in turn forces suppliers to adjust their production schedules, has not been evident on the industrial scene in recent years, he said. Greenspan said there will be other reductions of goods that affect the business cycle. The number of cars and trucks owned by households and businesses is adequate now, he said, and sales are likely to reflect primarily replacement needs and slower growth in the driving-age population. In the housing market, the low birth rate of the 1960s and 1970s means that the building rate in the 1990s will be lower than in the 1980s, Greenspan said. Increased interest rates since the first of the year on home mortgages and difficulty in obtaining credit by segments of the construction industry have also slowed building, ``but the difficulties ... should diminish considerably over time as they secure other financing sources,' he said. The volume of imports of merchandise, excluding oil, has declined in recent months, Greenspan said. ``Overall, these indicators point to somewhere between modest and moderate growth in factory output over the coming year,'' Greenspan said.

DOC.HEAD: Western Union Files Restructuring Plan Amid Mounting Debt
DOC.TEXT: Western Union Co., which pioneered the telegram, on Monday announced a plan to restructure $530 million in debt in an effort to avoid a bankruptcy court filing. Under terms of the plan, the company would exchange up to $530 million in principal amount of outstanding debt for new debt securities and common stock. Western Union faces a June 15 deadline to make a $51 million interest payment. Robert Amman, Western Union's president and chief executive, said in a statement that the plan ``will remove the financial uncertainty clouding our future.'' Amman said the plan would allow the compant to ``move forward with continued growth of our electronic messaging and financial services in markets where Western Union is the acknowledged leader.'' The company took special charges of $603 million in the first quarter of 1988 in connection with the planned sale of the company's microwave voice-switching facilities. Western Union has gotten out of the business of providing communications facilities to focus on specialized business and consumer services, but the company has continued to struggle, reporting $32 million in losses in 1989. Western Union officials told regulators in March that the company may have to seek bankruptcy court protection if it cannot meet its debt interest payments. In the filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Western Union said that without being able to raise additional funds, it probably would default on the June 15 payment. ``This exchange offer would give the company more breathing room, time to get more focused on operations, which is still showing losses,'' said Al Casazza, an analyst who follows Western Union for Moody's Investor Service. But Casazza said that even if the plan is accepted, ``there's still a great uncertainty over whether they'll ever be successful.'' Leigh Walzer, an analyst for R.D. Smith Inc., said he was more optimistic about Western Union's chances of success if the restructuring goes through. Under the plan, Western Union also would reclassify outstanding preferred shares. The plan must first be approved by bondholders. ``If they get this under these terms, I would bet they would be out of the woods,'' he said. Western Union said in a March filing with the SEC that if the restructuring is not approved, the company may seek to raise money through a public stock offering or by selling assets.

DOC.HEAD: Over-the-Counter Group Changes Name
DOC.TEXT: The National Association of Over the Counter Companies, NAOTC, announced Monday that it was changing its name to the Association of Publicly Traded Companies. The newly named organization is a not-for-profit group of 800 companies, most of which trade their stock in the National Association of Securities Dealers Automated Quotations system. ``The name NAOTC does not fully reflect the breadth of activity in which the association is involved, nor the range of issuers it represents,'' said John F. Guion, president of the Washington-based group. The group previously was interested in state securities anti-fraud regulations known as Blue Sky laws. It has turned attention to such issues as low-cost, high-risk penny stocks and short-selling practices that bet the price of a company's stock will go down.

DOC.HEAD: GM, NBC Agree on Huge Multi-Year Advertising Pact
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. said Monday it signed a three-year agreement with the National Broadcasting Co. that NBC executives called the largest commitment any advertiser has ever made for TV commercial time. The automaker and NBC refused to disclose the value of the deal, but one executive familiar with it and speaking on condition of anonymity said it was for ``a little less than $700 million.'' The agreement involves GM advertising for its cars, trucks and automotive services on prime-time programs on the NBC TV network, which is the leader in the ratings for that time of the day, and on its National Football League games starting with the 1990-91 television season this fall. It also includes GM advertising on two cable networks in which the NBC has an interest, the Consumer News and Business Channel, also known as CNBC, and Sports Channel America. NBC is a subsidiary of the General Electric Co. ``This purchase is the largest commitment made by any advertiser in the history of television advertising sales,'' Larry Hoffner, executive vice president for network sales, said in a statement. Hoffner said GM will be the exclusive domestic automaker on NBC's NFL coverage but said no similar exclusivity was given to GM on any NBC prime-time shows, which include the highly-rated ``The Cosby Show'' and ``Cheers.'' The previous largest agreement for advertising time on television was believed to have involved NBC and American Home Products Corp., which committed $250 million over several years to advertising on the network. GM spent about $200 million on advertising in all parts of the day on the NBC network last year, an executive familiar with the latest deal said. ``This involves something close to where they have been,'' the executive said. ``But now they know where they are going to be next year and the year after that and that gives them some stability.'' According to the trade publication Advertising Age, GM was the third biggest national advertising spender in 1988 at nearly $1.3 billion and was the biggest network TV advertiser at $443 million. The company declined to say how much it spends on advertising. Phil Guarascio, GM executive director of advertising and strategic marketing, said in a statement that the agreement with NBC was ``consistent with GM's on-going effort to get the maximum value for our advertising expenditures to further the sales efforts of GM divisions, including Saturn Corp.'' The new Saturn line of automobiles is expected to go on sale this fall. Other nameplates in the GM stable are Chevrolet, Cadillac, Pontiac, Oldsmobile, Buick and GMC. ``It assures us attractive prices on the most desirable programming while being sifficiently felxible to accommodate divisions' strategies and allow for mid-course corrections should forecast spending plans change,'' Guarascio said.

DOC.HEAD: Effort to Halt IBM Sales in South Africa Fails, But Backers Still Pleased
DOC.TEXT: IBM stockholders refused to order the company Monday to halt sales and services to South Africa, but backers of the move nonetheless were claiming a victory in a prolonged battle with the leading computer company. The resolution sponsored by 368 IBM employees and 21 religious organizations in Europe, Japan and the United States was approved by 17 percent of the 382.9 million shares voted during the company's annual meeting. To pass the measure would have needed a simple majority. Still, supporters were pleased because the measure only needed 10 percent to assure its place on the ballot for the next annual shareholders meeting. This is the third year the resolution's backers have succeeded in winning its reconsideration. Tom Belz, spokesman for International Business Machines Corp., aid IBM sold its South African subsidiary, IBM-South Africa Ltd., to employees of the subsidiary in 1987. The new company, ISM Ltd. (Information Services Management) is an independent dealership that sells IBM products, as well as other computer companies products, to commercial companies in South Africa, Belz said. Jim Leas, an IBM hardware engineer and sponsor of the resolution, said the 17 percent vote was ``the highest vote ever on any stockholder resolution in IBM history.'' Responding to backers during the meeting, IBM board Chairman John F. Akers said IBM and ISM comply with United States export regulations and that discontinuation of supplies to ISM would be a ``disservice to our former customers and our former employees.'' Akers also said that while ``there is nothing in the product line that we don't sell to South Africa, the resale of IBM products is controlled by U.S. law.'' Leas contended IBM has been one of the key supporters of apartheid in South Africa. He argued sale of IBM products and services in South Africa strengthens the apartheid system and helps South Africa remain one of the world's largest arms suppliers. Computers are a strategic import for South Africa and IBM has sold more computers to South Africa than any other country, Leas argued. Belz denied that IBM still does business in South Africa. ``We don't sell equipment to the (South African) police, the military, or to apartheid-enforcing agencies. It's the law,'' Belz said. The Comprehensive Anti-Apartheid Act prohibits the sale of products to South African apartheid-enforcing agencies, and to any other companies if the product is to be directly used, or ``embedded'' in a weapon system. About 20 of the resolution's backers staged a four-block march to the assembly hall, then chanted and sang hymns outside before the meeting began. In other annual meeting business, Akers said he expected the world's largest computer company to substantially improve its financial performance this year.

DOC.HEAD: Confidence Turned Down in April, Conference Board Says
DOC.TEXT: Consumer confidence in the economy fell in April because of a deteriorating job outlook, erasing an upturn the previous month, the Conference Board said. The business-sponsored research group said Monday that its consumer confidence index fell in April as consumers were less positive about current economic conditions and the outlook for the immediate future. The index is based on a monthly survey of 5,000 U.S. households. ``Although the nation's unemployment rate has remained unchanged for some months _ at slightly more than 5 percent _ the number of new jobs in March dropped abruptly and sharply,'' said Fabian Linden, executive director of the board's consumer research center. That decline ``probably contributed to much of the uneasiness'' found by the survey, he added. About 14 percent of respondents to the survey said they expected more jobs to become available during the next six months, down from 16 percent in the March survey. The percentage of respondents who said they felt business conditions are good slipped to 23 percent in April from 25 percent in March, and those saying they expect business conditions to improve slipped to 17 percent from 19 percent. The survey also found a drop in plans by consumers to buy new cars and homes in the next six months, the board said.

DOC.HEAD: EPA: Dioxin Levels in Paper Products Pose No Significant Health Risk
DOC.NOTE: Eds: ADDs three grafs with Atlanta demonstration. Also on general news wires
DOC.TEXT: Coffee filters, food wrap and other paper products do not contain enough dioxin to warrant regulation and pose no significant health concerns, the Environmental Protection Agency said Monday. Nevertheless, the EPA said it expects the paper industry to further reduce dioxin levels in its products and announced new regulations to cut dioxin releases into waterways near paper mills because of evidence of fish contamination. The EPA said a ``very small number'' of individuals, whose diets rely heavily on fish from waters near such mills, may be exposed to significant additional cancer risk. The agency said it was working with states to post fishing advisories near some mills. A cancer risk analysis from eating fish from waters near specific paper mills was still being prepared and no breakdown as to health risks by mills was available. There are 104 paper mills, operated by 38 companies, that produce bleached paper products. Henry Habicht, EPA's deputy administrator, said EPA planned to issue new permit guidelines for states and tougher effluent limitations for mills to force industry action. The agency also said it would curb the use of dioxin-contaminated sludge as fertilizer near some paper mills. Environmentalists have raised concerns about dioxin in paper products since tests several years ago showed traces of the highly toxic chemical in bleached wood pulp. Dioxin, which is known to cause cancer and birth defects in lab animals and, in high concetrations, skin disorders in humans, is a byproduct of the chlorine-based bleaching process. The EPA is under a court directive to evaluate the dioxin danger in paper products and take protective measures. The agency lists it as a probable cause of cancer in humans The agency said Monday that an analysis of cancer risks from exposure to bleached paper items shows risks too low to require regulatory controls. The dioxin levels in paper products that come into contact with food pose at most an aggregate cancer risk of no greater than 2.4 cancers for every 1 million people exposed. For such products as milk cartons and coffee filters, the risks are less than one in 1 million, the EPA said. The agency routinely uses the one-in-1-million-risk threshold as a benchmark for possible regulatory action in cases involving cancer-causing chemicals in food products. Habicht said the risks for some paper products were somewhat greater than one in 1 million. But he said no regulatory action is needed because contamination levels still were extremely low. He said the agency intends to press the paper industry ``to reduce those levels even further.'' Jim Benson, acting administrator of the Food and Drug Administration, said the dioxin level in foods from bleached paper ``is not a major health problem'' but the FDA wants the level reduced to zero. Red Caveny, president of the American Paper Institute, said the industry has greatly reduced the dioxin levels in paper products over the last 18 months by changing the bleaching process. He said dioxin levels in milk cartons and coffee filters already are so low they cannot be distinguished from ``background'' dioxin levels already found in foods. ``We have been able to reduce the levels (of dioxins) almost 50 percent in the last two years,'' he said in an interview. He maintained the improvements have made some of the data used in the EPA analysis out of date. EPA officials said the greater dioxin concern stems from releases of the chemical from mills into waterways. The agency said tests on fish caught downstream and a few miles from some of the mills had dioxin levels great enough to pose as much as a one-in-1,000 cancer risk to people eating large amounts of such fish. Habicht said the health concerns are confined to a ``very small number of people'' whose diet consists of large amounts of locally caught fish near some of the mills. There is no indication of any problem with commercially caught fish, he said. In Atlanta, two activists affiliated with Greenpeace climbed 150 feet up the Georgia-Pacific Corp. building and unfurled a banner reading, ``Take the Poison Out of Pulp,'' calling for an end to the chlorline bleach process. Georgia-Pacific is a major paper manufacturer. Beth Zoffman, a company spokeswoman, pointed at the two climbers and said, ``This creates a far greater risk than the entire production of dioxin in pulp. They are creating an unnecessary risk to themselves and the people on the ground.'' Police said the pair would be charged with criminal trespass and reckless conduct.

DOC.HEAD: Spanish-Language Network Discloses Plans for Infotainment Show
DOC.TEXT: The Spanish-language television network Telemundo and consumer products giant Procter & Gamble are launching a half-hour program in which Procter's products will be prominently featured as solutions to a variety of common domestic problems, the companies said Monday. The show is called Hablando and will appear on the Telemundo network twice a week starting Tuesday afternoon. The Telemundo network is one of the nation's largest Spanish-language TV networks, reaching 36 major markets and an estimated 78 percent of the Hispanic housholds in the United States. Telemundo Productions, which is producing the show, described the program as ``infotainment,'' or a mixture of education, information and entertainment. The show features three actors and guest appearances that portray people in a variety of settings including the kitchen and the laundry room. Procter & Gamble brands such as Luvs diapers, Scope mouthwash and Tide laundry detergent are prominently displayed and used during various segments of the program in which topics such as caring for the baby, personal hygiene or cleaning the family wash are discussed. Procter & Gamble is also the sole national advertiser on the program, pitching many of the same products that appear within the show in the four minutes of network commercials allowed each half hour. Critics of ``infotainment'' or ``infomercials'' say shows that pitch specific products in return for a fee from the manufacturer are inappropriate because viewers may mistake them for independently produced programs. But Saul P. Steinberg, chairman, president and chief executive of Telemundo Group Inc., defended the arrangement with Procter & Gamble, saying that such associations are common on television in Spanish-speaking countries. He said the program provides useful information on local customs for people who may have only recently arrived, and that it would have been a much more expensive undertaking without Procter & Gamble's sponsorship. Viewers will be the judge of the value of the program, Steinberg said, saying it will survive for long if its ratings are poor. Nonetheless, he added that ``you can only do so much of this'' and wants a large majority of independent entertainment programming on his network. Neil M. Comber, manager of target marketing for Cincinnati-based Procter & Gamble, said his company paid a premium of about 5 percent to 10 percent over the costs of commercials alone for the right to have its products used in the program. He said the company also recently began sponsoring two-minute informative programs that are being carried on Telemundo's Spanish-language network rival, Univision. Those programs, which air several times a day on Univision, are produced in conjunction with the Spanish-language magazine La Familia de Hoy, published by Whittle Communications of Knoxville, Tenn.

DOC.HEAD: Mitsubishi Recalls 1986 Cars For Pollution Problem
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: About 102,000 Mitsubishi cars from the 1986 model year are being recalled because they exceed federal standards for carbon monoxide emissions, the Environmental Protection Agency announced Monday. The cars were equipped with 1.5-liter engines and sold as the Mitsubishi Mirage, Dodge Colt and Plymouth Colt, most of them under the Dodge and Plymouth nameplates, EPA said. Dodge and Plymouth dealers will handle repairs to those cars, and Mitsubishi dealers will handle models under than name. Cars sold in California, which has different pollution standards from the rest of the country, are not affected by the recall. EPA said dealers will modify the carburetor, recalibrate the automatic choke and check the secondary air filter for possible replacement. The work will be done without charge. The excess pollution was discovered in the agency's routine checks, EPA said.

DOC.HEAD: Commissioner Orders Torchmark to Cease Proxy Fight For American General
DOC.TEXT: Torchmark Inc. promised to challenge a state regulator's order that it halt its proxy fight for control of American General Corp. Tennessee Revenue Commissioner Joe Huddleston said Monday that Torchmark violated state law with its attempt to elect five nominees to American General's board of directors on Wednesday in Houston, where the insurer is based. The law says no insurance company or holding company can seek to control a Tennessee company without prior approval of the state Department of Commerce and Insurance. ``The change in control statutes are a vital part of the regulatory framework that has developed for the protection of policyholders' interests,'' American General Chairman and Chief Executive Harold S. Hook said in Houston. ``We are gratified that the State of Tennessee has acted to order Torchmark to comply with the law.'' Torchmark issued a statement promising to go to court to challenge the ruling. Huddleston said the proxy action required Torchmark to provide financial and other detailed information on which the state can base its approval or rejection of a takeover. American General and the state argue that the proxy move by Torchmark Inc. of Birmingham, Ala., amounts to a takeover which requires approval of Tennessee. Torchmark contended during a two-day hearing last week that its actions do not require it to meet the requirements because a successful proxy fight would simply put directors on the board willing to discuss a takeover. Torchmark officials also wrote Gov. Ned McWherter on April 13 to advise him, among other things, ``that we have no plans to move any operations out of Tennessee.'' Tennessee is one of 10 states in which American General is considered domiciled because of its operations there. Regulators in Texas and New York also have questioned the legality of Torchmark's proxy solicitation. Missouri, California and Virginia have approved the process. Torchmark turned to the proxy strategy earlier this month after American General turned down its takeover bid of $50 a share in cash and $50 worth of Torchmark stock.

DOC.HEAD: Northeast Announces New Management for PSNH
DOC.TEXT: Northeast Utilities has appointed a new team of senior managers to take over the running of bankrupt Public Service Co. of New Hampshire, operator of the long-delayed Seabrook nuclear power plant. Northeast, which has bid $2.3 billion for Public Service, also said it dismissed 15 Public Service middle management employees on Monday, spokesman Jeffrey Kotkin said. They will remain on the payroll for 60 days, he said. About 50 middle-level managers had been in limbo while Northeast decided whether to keep them. Kotkin said no other firings are expected but added, ``there could be changes after the merger is completed.'' The Connecticut utility's bid for Public Service still requires the approval of state and federal regulators. Until the takeover is completed, an interim board of directors will run Public Service, New Hampshire's largest electric utility. The board elected Leon Maglathlin Jr. president and chief executive officer. Frank Locke, a Northeast senior vice president, will be responsible for Public Service's day-to-day operations. If Northeast's bid is approved as expected, Locke will become president. John Duffet, Public Service's former president and chief executive officer, and four senior vice presidents officially left the company Monday. Locke said several task forces of Public Service and Northeast employees have begun analyzing the two utilities to determine how best to operate them once the merger is completed. Public Service sought bankruptcy protection in January 1988, largely because of delays and huge cost overruns at the troubled Seabrook plant. Northeast's offer was accepted after almost two years of talks and bidding by various New England utilities.

DOC.HEAD: Esber Out as Head of Troubled Software Maker
DOC.TEXT: Edward M. Esber Jr. quit Monday as chief of Ashton-Tate Corp., a software maker that has lost money for four quarters because of problems with the latest version of its core program, dBase IV. No one was named immediately to replace him as chairman and chief executive. Carmelo J. Santoro, chief executive of Silicon Systems Inc. and an outside director of Ashton-Tate, was named non-executive chairman of the board. The new operational head of the company will be William P. Lyons, named president and chief operating officer. Lyons, 45, had headed Ashton-Tate's applications group _ its operations other than the DBase and Rapid File data base products. The data bases make up three-quarters of its business. Esber, 37, known more as a marketer than as a technical expert or day-to-day adminstrator, will concentrate on ``customers, products and strategies'' as vice chairman, the company said. Critics blamed Esber for allowing Ashton-Tate to lose its leadership in PC software and for a series of disappointing new products and acquisitions. The dBase IV program introduced in October 1988 was marred with errors, and some customers complained it was slow and too prone to crash. Esber promised an improved version, but 18 months later it is still being tested. ``We haven't set a date (for its release) but we are very pleased with its progress,'' Ashton-Tate spokeswoman Delia Fernandez said. Ashton-Tate is based in Torrance, a Los Angeles suburb.

DOC.HEAD: Boeing Reports Strong First Quarter, Continuing Worries Over Defense
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `The 1989 ...' to CLARIFY that accounting change produced one-time gain.
DOC.TEXT: The Boeing Co., which is selling more planes and making more on them, said Monday its sales jumped 60 percent and its profits 87 percent in the first quarter of 1990. Company officials said demand should remain high for Boeing's jetliners, and hinted strongly they would go ahead with their planned new jet, the 777. But they warned shareholders at their annual meeting to expect another losing year for Boeing's troubled defense and space segments. Boeing announced a three-for-two stock split, the second year in a row it has done so. Shareholders gave directors permission to issue more stock but rejected a request that Boeing stop doing business with South Africa, despite efforts by a Baptist minister who camped in a plywood shack in front of company headquarters for three days and urged holders to ``do the right thing.'' They also turned down three ``shareholders' rights'' resolutions, including a call for a shareholder vote on the company's ``poison pill'' plan. Boeing earned $302 million or $1.31 a share on sales of $6.4 billion for the first three months of 1990, compared with profits of $161 million or 70 cents a share on sales of $4 billion in the first quarter of 1989. The 1989 figures are before a restatement to reflect a change in accounting for income taxes, which produced a one-time gain of $298 million or $1.29 a share. With the gain, earnings in the 1989 quarter were $459 million or $1.99 a share. Boeing was left with a number of nearly complete planes when production was virtually stopped by a 48-day Machinists union strike last fall. As a result, it was able to deliver 84 jets in the first quarter, compared with 67 in first-quarter 1989. Deliveries included 22 747-400 jumbo jets, Boeing's largest and most expensive plane worth about $125 million each. Just five 747s were delivered in the first quarter of 1989, when Boeing was struggling to introduce the new-model 747-400. Frank Shrontz, chairman and chief executive officer, said the higher profits resulted from increased sales and improved operating margins on commercial jets. Higher federal taxes and losses in other segments of the company partially offset that performance, he said. Last year, Boeing's military and space divisions lost $474 million. Boeing has bid aggressively on defense and space contracts in recent years and fallen behind on several programs. At the beginning of the year, it consolidated its military work into Boeing Defense and Space Group to try to make the segments more efficient. Shrontz said progress had been made but continuing technical, cost and schedule problems would result in another operating loss in 1990. Boeing didn't release figures on how large the defense loss might be. But George Shapiro, analyst with Solomon Brothers in New York, said his estimate was about $150 million to $200 million. Boeing is coming to the end of some troublesome programs, such as the long-delayed new Air Force One jets, and isn't getting any new programs that could cause further losses, Shapiro said. Last week, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney proposed cutting or delaying two key programs for Boeing, the B-2 stealth bomber and the Advanced Tactical Fighter. Boeing is a major subcontractor on the B-2, with 10,000 employees assigned to the project, and is competing for the multi-billion dollar contract for the Air Force's new-generation warplane. Dan Pinick, Defense and Space Group president, said ``watershed events'' in the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe have led Boeing to anticipate a 5 percent decline in the Defense Department budget through 1995. ``Clearly we don't know exactly what the future budget levels will be but given the recent events, we believe that we should make business decisions based on a more conservative estimate,'' Pinick said. Dean Thornton, president of Boeing Commercial Airplane Group, got to deliver a much cheerier speech. Noting that 57 customers ordered 963 Boeing planes worth $47.5 billion last year _ the fifth straight year of record orders _ Thornton remarked, ``We're getting to numbers that I can't hardly relate to.'' Boeing has cranked up its production rate from 24 planes a month in 1988 to 28 in 1989, and plans to be at 34 a month later this year, Thornton said. By mid-1991, the rate will be 38 month, he said, and Boeing is considering going to 41 a month in 1992. ``In addition to increasing production on current programs, we plan to introduce the new 777 airplane in that time frame,'' Thornton said. Boeing hasn't officially launched the 777, a two-engine widebody that would carry 350 passengers, but has been talking with airlines and firming up its design. No airlines have announced orders for it yet, but Shrontz told reporters the company hoped ``to have reached a quantity that would allow us to launch it'' by mid-year. Boeing had a firm backlog of $84.1 billion in unfilled orders as of March 31, compared with $80.6 billion at the end of 1989. All but 8 percent of that was for commercial customers.

DOC.HEAD: Wells Fargo Chairman Predicts Restructuring of Banking Industry
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of Wells Fargo Bank predicted that troubles at the nation's banks and thrifts will force a radical restructuring and consolidation of the financial services industry. ``Reform, radical structural reform ... is the only sane alternative,'' the banker, Carl Reichardt, said Monday. ``It's the only safe road.'' He predicted that reform eventually would establish a single regulatory body to oversee the industry and remove competitive barriers between banks, securities firms and insurance companies. Reichardt, who made his remarks before a gathering of the Society of American Business Editors and Writers, said the Resolution Trust Corp., established last year to oversee the bailout of the thrift industry, has a ``daunting task.'' The job will entail giving many sick savings and loans ``a decent burial'' while trying to preserve as much value as possible in selling off what Reichardt called a ``motley collection of assets.'' Complicating the effort are the RTC's ``Byzantine'' organizational chart and the 371-page law that governs its work, Reichardt said. He called potential buyers ``bottom fishers ... who are the shrewdest buyers in the country.'' He urged banks to improve credit quality and chastised big banks for failing to have credit training programs. He said that was akin to ``trying to run an engineering company with poets.'' ``As in so many industries, the opportunities lie in executing the basics well,'' he concluded. Earlier, John F. McDonnell, chairman of McDonnell Douglas Corp., said booming orders for commercial aircraft and new markets in space will help the aerospace industry weather cuts in defense spending. ``The U.S. defense budget does not represent a vein of gold to be mined for social programs,'' McDonnell conceded. Rather, developments in Eastern Europe and elsewhere represent enormous potential for increased commercial aviation as tourism and business opportunities grow, he said. Defense cuts have renewed enthusiasm for space exploration and transportation, McDonnell said, adding that ``prospects in this part of our business are looking better than at any time since the 1960s.'' The recent layoff of 3,000 workers by the Douglas Aircraft unit in Long Beach, Calif. was ``not a retrenchment,'' McDonnell said. Some workers will be transferred and others were let go because they did not have the necessary skills. But the overall picture remains healthy, he said, adding that the division hired 10,000 workers last year.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates with morning Nikkei, comments
DOC.TEXT: The dollar fell marginally against the yen Tuesday morning and share prices slipped on the Tokyo Stock Exchange in slack trading. The dollar was changing hands at 159.05 yen at late morning. It opened at 159.09 yen, up 0.01 yen from last Friday's close, and ranged narrowly between 159.00 yen and 159.11 yen during morning trading. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average lost 45.21 points, or 0.15 percent, ending the morning session at 29,539.59. The index had gained 160.22 points last Friday. Tokyo markets were closed Monday for a national holiday and holidays later this week kept activity very thin Tuesday, said Tomoya Kohda, a trader with New Japan Securities Co. ``Today's trading is so quiet and boring,'' he said. ``Participants will just remain on the sidelines for the rest of the day and tomorrow.'' Many Japanese companies are taking a long ``Golden Week'' break, stretching a series of holidays between last Saturday and next Sunday into one continuous vacation. Markets are open only on Tuesday and Wednesday before the four-day weekend starting Thursday, which is Constitution Day. Akihiko Kagawa, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo, said currency trading was very quiet. Adding to the market's inactivity was the scheduled closure later Tuesday of most major European markets for May Day, he said. The price of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell to 85.71 from last Friday's close of 85.83. That boosted the yield to 7.43 percent from 7.405 percent.
